content.text:
Political authorities are working hard on fighting the spread of the Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19). Corresponding interventions often address cooperative behavior, because they pose restrictions on the individual level (e.g., limiting one’s physical contacts) with the aim to serve the greater good (e.g., not overtaxing the health systems). In a sample of Danish adults (N = 799) randomly drawn from a representative sample, we link different personality characteristics to people’s willingness in accepting personal restrictions for fighting COVID19. When simultaneously considering all characteristics including the basic traits from the HEXACO personality model, we find that, next to people’s age, Emotionality as well as the Dark Factor of Personality (D) explain who is more willing to accept restrictions. D further explains acceptance based on whether restrictions aim to protect oneself rather than others. The results show the importance of individual differences for following large-scale interventions that should serve the greater good.
Keywords: Personality; Cooperation; Coronavirus Disease 2019; HEXACO; Dark
Factor of Personality

content.heading: TRAITS AND ACCEPTING RESTRICTIONS TO FIGHT COVID-19 2
content.text:
Individual differences in accepting personal restrictions to fight the COVID-19
pandemic: Results from a Danish adult sample
The outbreak and rapid spread of the Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) has
posed (life-)critical threats and challenges to individuals and societies (World Health Organization, 2020). In the absence of an effective vaccine, it is of utmost importance to reduce the spread of COVID-19 to allow timely treatment of infected individuals as well as not to overtax health systems at large (Flatten the curve, 2020; World Health Organization, 2020). Slowing down the spread of COVID-19 is not only beneficial for oneself because it reduces the risk to contract the disease at times when resources for treatment are scarce, but also for others who are likely to severely suffer in case of infection (e.g., elderly people).
In order to slow down the spread of COVID-19—i.e., ‘to flatten the curve’—, health
and political authorities around the world have introduced rules and recommendations aimed at limiting the number of physical contacts between people. Examples include closing kindergartens, schools, and universities, enforcing home office, prohibiting border crossing, or staying at home in general (e.g., The White House, 2020). Clearly, following the rules and recommendations poses severe restrictions on the personal life of many citizens.
Whereas most people follow the rules and recommendations by health and political
authorities, some have ignored them, and yet others have even celebrated parties or mass tourism (e.g., BBC, 2020). Slowing down the spread of COVID-19, however, requires cooperative actions by many (if not all) people, because the spread is slowed down most effectively if everyone bears the personal restrictions. This request for cooperative action might particularly apply to people who—given the current knowledge—seem less likely to be at risk to severely suffer from COVID-19 (health-wise), e.g., younger people (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2020).

content.heading: TRAITS AND ACCEPTING RESTRICTIONS TO FIGHT COVID-19 3
content.text:
Herewith, we aim to identify factors explaining whether individuals rather accept
personal restrictions to slow down the spread of COVID-19, and, if so, whether there are differences in the acceptance depending on whether one aims to protect oneself as compared to others. More specifically, based on the large body of research showing that personality traits account for differences in (pro-)social and cooperative behavior across various domains (e.g., Thielmann, Spadaro, & Balliett, 2020), we explore whether personality traits also account for differences in accepting personal restrictions to support collective efforts of slowing down the spread of COVID-19. To this end, in a timely data set of Danish adults, we consider several individual difference constructs that cover personality in breadth, including traits that have repeatedly been linked to anti/social behavior and non-/cooperation, namely, Honesty-Humility (Ashton, Lee, & De Vries, 2014) and the Dark Factor of Personality (Moshagen, Hilbig, & Zettler, 2018). Overall, we are able to link a broad set of potentially relevant individual difference constructs to people’s acceptance of restricting themselves at personal cost to societally—and, in fact, globally—fight COVID-19.
Measures

content.heading: Procedure and Participants
content.text:
Data for this study stem from an online data collection for a different pre-registered
purpose; the pre-registration can be found at https://osf.io/djevb/?view_only=f009b253ba0f4403808ebe36ad1d3889. Thus, all analyses reported herein are exploratory, and must be interpreted with caution. We also provide Supplemental Material with further analyses.
The sample was recruited as follows: In 2018, the first author received contact
information from 100,136 Danish citizens via Statistics Denmark (https://www.dst.dk/en). These citizens were chosen per random, but so that the group was—at that time— representative for the Danish adult population with regard to the distribution of age, gender,

content.heading: TRAITS AND ACCEPTING RESTRICTIONS TO FIGHT COVID-19 4
content.text:
and place of residence. From these citizens, on March 16th 2020 a random set of 10,000 people were invited to participate in an online survey on personality traits.1 The invitation— with links to the survey—was sent to people’s official digital mail, so-called e-boks in Denmark (https://www.e-boks.com/danmark/en/). Note that 949 invitation letters could not be delivered (most likely, because people moved abroad or passed away since the contact information were retrieved), resulting in 9,051 delivered study invitations.
The online survey was set up via formr (formr.org; Arslan, Walther, & Tata, 2019).
People could fill out the survey in either Danish or English. When entering the survey, participants were first informed about the survey, and then asked to provide consent. Hereafter, participants answered three demographic questions (about their gender, age, and fluency in Danish and English, respectively). Next, people saw the first page with personality items, including the measures (see below) for the HEXACO traits, risk-seeking tendency, as well as accepting personal restrictions to fight the COVID-19 threat. Items were randomized and included one attention check item. Following this page, people saw the second page with personality items, consisting of the assessment of the Dark Factor of Personality as well as one attention check item. Afterwards, some people filled out a brief cognitive ability measure (depending on the condition, this was mandatory or optional fur successful study completion), and all were finally thanked and incentivized (the incentive differed between conditions).
Even though people can still participate in the survey, data for these analyses were
retrieved on March 22nd 2020. Specifically, until then 890 started to fill out the survey
1 Note that these 10,000 people were randomly allocated to eight different groups (1,250 people each)
for the purpose of the pre-registered study. The conditions only differed with regard to the offered incentive for people’s participation in the survey as well as whether filling out the cognitive ability measure (which is not used herein) was mandatory for study completion or not, so that we merged participants from all conditions for the current analyses.

content.heading: TRAITS AND ACCEPTING RESTRICTIONS TO FIGHT COVID-19 5
content.text: (response rate of 9,33%), and 799 (89.78%) were included for the analyses. Participants were included when they had a unique Study ID (which was sent to them in the study invitation), filled out at least the two pages with the personality items, and answered all attention check items correctly. The final sample consists of 409 women, 390 men, 0 others, with a mean age of 48.69 (SD = 17.74) years.

content.heading: Measures
content.text:
HEXACO Personality Traits. We assessed people’s broad, basic personality trait
dimensions in line with the HEXACO Model of Personality (Ashton & Lee, 2007). The HEXACO model comprises six basic trait dimensions—Honesty-Humility, Emotionality, Extraversion, Agreeableness vs. Anger, Conscientiousness, and Openness to experience— which have been meta-analytically linked to a broad array of important outcomes (Zettler, Thielmann, Hilbig, & Moshagen, 2020). Each trait was assessed via the respective subscale of the HEXACO-60 (Ashton & Lee, 2009), consisting of 10 items each. Example items are ‘I think that I am entitled to more respect than the average person is’ (Honesty-Humility, reverse keyed), ‘I worry a lot less than most people do’ (Emotionality, reverse keyed), ‘The first thing that I always do in a new place is to make friends’ (Extraversion), ‘I tend to be lenient in judging other people’ (Agreeableness vs. Anger), ‘I always try to be accurate in my work, even at the expense of time’ (Conscientiousness), and ‘People have often told me that I have a good imagination’ (Openness to experience). For all personality measures, we used a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 = “strongly disagree” to 5 = “strongly agree” as response format. Cronbach’s α was > .72 for each of the six HEXACO subscales.
Dark Factor of Personality. We assessed people’s levels in the Dark Factor of
Personality (D) via the D70 (Moshagen, Zettler, & Hilbig, 2020), which consists of 70 items. Sample items are ‘My own pleasure is all that matters’, ‘It is hard to get ahead without cutting corners here and there’, and ‘People who get mistreated have usually done something to bring

content.heading: TRAITS AND ACCEPTING RESTRICTIONS TO FIGHT COVID-19 6
content.text:
it on themselves.’ Notably, the D70 consists of an equal number of positively and negatively keyed items. Out of the D70, one can also create a 35-item (D35) as well as a 16-item (D16) version to assess D. Originally, Moshagen et al. (2020) recommend to use bi-factor modelling for assessing D, but for equal measurement approaches across the personality constructs, we use the mean score across all items for our analyses. Cronbach’s α was .93 for the D70.
Risk-taking tendency. We assessed people’s general risk-taking tendency via an
adapted version (so that it fits the response format) of the risk-taking tendency item from the German Socio-Economic Panel (2020). Our items read ‘I am a person who is generally willing to take risks.’
Accepting personal restrictions to fight COVID-19. We created four items to assess
people’s willingness to accept personal restrictions to fight COVID-19, varying whether the willingness depends on who would (likely) benefit from the restrictions. All items started with ‘I accept serious constraints to my quality of life (e.g., staying at home) to reduce the risk of infection with the coronavirus/covid-19 for,’ and then ended either with ‘myself’ (Protectionself), ‘family members and friends’ (Protectionothers/family), ‘people in general’ (Protectionothers/general), or ‘others who are at risk’ (Protectionothers/risk).
Further variables. On the first page with personality items—i.e., among the
HEXACO-60, the risk-taking tendency item, and the items about accepting personal restrictions—, we also assessed people’s interest in insights about their personality via five items (e.g., ‘I seek both positive and negative feedback about my personality’, Cronbach’s α = .76), as well as potential hoarding behavior in the light of COVID-19 via one item: ‘Because of the recent coronavirus/covid-19 outbreak in Denmark, I have bought much more than usual from some groceries (food, toilet paper, yeast, flour, etc.)’. Further, some participants filled out the 16-item version of the International Cognitive Ability Resource (ICAR-16; Condon & Revelle, 2014) measure as a measure of cognitive abilities. For the current investigation, we

content.heading: TRAITS AND ACCEPTING RESTRICTIONS TO FIGHT COVID-19 7
content.text: do not consider any of these three constructs (interest in self-insights, hoarding in the light of COVID-19, cognitive abilities).

content.heading: Analyses
content.text:
We used zero-order correlations as well as multiple regression analyses for the
analyses presented herein. A sensitivity analysis using G*Power (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007) suggests that with N = 799, we have power = .95 to detect a correlation of r = |0.13| (alpha = .05, two-tailed).
Results
In order to get first insights into the relation between demographics, personality traits,
and the acceptance of personal restrictions to fight COVID-19, we computed zero-order correlations among all variables included in this study: the six HEXACO traits, D, risk tendencies, accepting personal restrictions to fight COVID-19, age, and gender. A correlation matrix/plot is shown in Figure 1.

content.heading: TRAITS AND ACCEPTING RESTRICTIONS TO FIGHT COVID-19 8
content.text:
As can be seen in Figure 1, several personality traits correlated significantly with the
acceptance of personal restrictions to fight COVID-19 across all four items (i.e., accepting restrictions with the aim to protect oneself, family members and friends, people in general, or others who are at risk). From these, Honesty-Humility and D showed the largest correlation estimates (all rs > .21, p < .001). Importantly, the correlation estimate between D and

content.heading: TRAITS AND ACCEPTING RESTRICTIONS TO FIGHT COVID-19 9
content.text:
Protectionself was significantly smaller than the correlation estimates between D and Protectionothers/family (z = 2.35, p = .019), Protectionothers/general (z = 3.41, p < .001), and Protectionothers/risk (z = 3.1336, p = .002), indicating that D is even more relevant when it comes to own constraints that are associated with the risk of others as compared to oneself. D was the only personality trait for which we found such differences.
As a next step, we ran four multiple regression models—each with one of the four
items assessing the acceptance of personal restrictions to fight COVID-19 as the outcome—, in which we included all personality variables as well as gender and age. The corresponding results are shown in Table 1. Across the models, age, Emotionality, and D turned out to be significant predictors of acceptance of personal restrictions to fight COVID-19, such that younger participants, as well as participants with lower levels of Emotionality and higher levels of D, respectively, were less willing to restrict themselves.2 Moreover, only Openness to experience was a significant predictor in one model, namely, with regard to the willingness to restrict oneself in order to protect oneself.
Because older individuals seem to be at higher risk to severely suffer due to COVID-
19 (health-wise), one might consider age as a proxy for self-interest. That is, for younger individuals, self-interest should strongly decrease from restriction to protect oneself > family and friends > others in general > others at risk. In contrast, for older people, self-interest should be rather stable as they are at high(er) risk themselves. Correspondingly, one could
2 Honesty-Humility was not found to be a significant predictor in any of the four models, arguably
because of its overlap with the (low) Dark Factor of Personality. One potential explanation for this finding—that D was a consistent predictor, while Honesty-Humility not—is the use of the HEXACO-60 assessing HonestyHumility with 10 items ‘only’, whereas D was assessed via 70 items. However, we observed a similar pattern (D continues as a significant predictor across all four models, Honesty-Humility only in one model) if D was assessed via 16 items (the D16; Moshagen et al., 2020). Please see also our Supplemental Material in this regard.

content.heading: TRAITS AND ACCEPTING RESTRICTIONS TO FIGHT COVID-19 10
content.text: expect interactions between D and age in predicting the willingness to restrict oneself to benefit different target groups, such that acceptance should be more strongly related to D in younger individuals. Indeed, exploratory multiple regressions including the interaction term of D and age (and controlling for curvilinear effects of both) indicate corresponding significant interaction effects (for Protectionothers/general as well as Protectionothers/risk), which are reported in the Supplemental Material.

TRAITS AND ACCEPTING RESTRICTIONS TO FIGHT COVID-19 12
content.text:
Discussion
In this explorative study, we find that people’s age (positively), as well as their levels
in Emotionality (positively) and the Dark Factor of Personality (D; negatively) are substantially related to their willingness in accepting personal restrictions to fight COVID-19. Age might be an important predictor because elderly people are more likely to directly suffer from COVID-19 health-wise. Emotionality might be an important predictor because people with higher (vs. lower) levels are more prone to anxiety, fear, and being emphatic towards others (Ashton et al., 2014). D might be an important predictor because it indicates to which degree people aim to maximize their utility, “disregarding, accepting, or malevolently provoking disutility for others” (Moshagen et al., 2018, p. 657). Correspondingly, we not only observed a general link between D and people’s acceptance of personal restrictions for a greater good (the fight against COVID-19), but also that this link differed depending on who would benefit from the restrictions in particular. Note that the described effects hold when considering people’s basic (HEXACO) personality traits next to Emotionality, risk-taking tendency, and gender (and please see the Supplemental Material for an interaction between D and age). As a particular strength, we could rely on data randomly drawn from a representative sample of a population; on the other hand, self-selection effects as well as the way COVID-19 has been addressed in Denmark at the time of our study might limit the generalizability of the results.
Our findings have important implications for both current attempts to fight COVID-19
and policy making in general. They can contribute to the understanding why people have responded differently to the calls by health and political authorities to reduce physical interactions.

content.text:
We investigated the perception and the frequency of various protective behavior
measures against COVID-19. Although our sample (German general public, N = 419, age = 38.07 (15.67) years, female = 71.1 % (diverse = 0.5%), students = 34.37%) consisted mostly of prosocially oriented individuals, we found that, above all, participants used protective measures that protected themselves. They consistently shunned measures that have higher protective value for the public than for themselves, which indicates that public protective value comes second even for prosocially oriented individuals. Accordingly, health communication should focus on emphasizing a measure’s perceived self-protective value by explaining how it would foster public protection that in the long run will protect the individual and the individual’s close relations.

content.heading: Keywords:
content.text:
Social-value orientation, COVID-19, protective behavior
Even prosocially oriented individuals save themselves first:
Social Value Orientation, subjective effectiveness and the usage of protective measures during
the COVID-19 pandemic in Germany
Crises are times that challenge people to care for themselves and others. But as we know
from research in economics and psychology, individuals differ in their willingness to focus on the individual versus public good (e.g.; Fehr & Schmidt, 2005; Murphy & Ackermann, 2014; Ruch, Bruntsch, & Wagner, 2017). The case of COVID-19 is especially tricky as people can infect others before they experience symptoms themselves. Furthermore, the infection carries a risk that is much more serious to older people and people with previous medical conditions. Thus, adopting preventive measures is often a burden to the individual while having positive consequences for the public.
Around the world governments are attempting to curb the spread of Corona (COVID-19).
However, particularly democratic societies rely heavily on the individual to use protective measures to slow down the spread of COVID-19. Whether an individual uses a specific protective measure depends on whether or not the individual deems the protective behavior as effective (Floyd, Prentice-Dunn, & Rogers, 2000; Peters, Ruiter, & Kok, 2013; Sheeran, Harris, & Epton, 2014).
In the current COVID-19 outbreak protective measures can either serve the individual,
which means they reduce the likelihood of becoming infected, or they can serve the public by reducing the likelihood of spreading the infection to others. However, it is yet to be investigated how much people base their decision to use a protective measure on the subjective protective value for themselves or the subjective protective value for the public.
Based on theorizing and empirical research in decision-making, prosocial behavior in
general (e.g.; Hilbig, Glöckner, & Zettler, 2014) and social risk-taking in particular (Leder & Betsch, 2016) are linked to personality traits. We investigate if individuals differ regarding their willingness to use protective measures depending on whether they protect the self or the public and if this difference could be linked to the individual’s social value orientation (Messick & McClintock, 1968).
Social value orientation (SVO; Van Lange, Otten, De Bruin, & Joireman, 1997) reflects
three social motives that guide decisions that have social and personal consequences: cooperation, competition, and individualism. SVO motives influence behavior because it modulates the weight individuals assign to the consequences that an interpersonal decision has for themselves and others (Van Lange et al., 1997). High SVO (i.e., a stronger prosocial orientation) is positively related to choices that maximize joint outcomes, whereas low SVO is associated with choices that maximize personal payoffs (Balliet, Parks, & Joireman, 2010; Baumert, Schlösser, & Schmitt, 2014; Fung, Au, Hu, & Shi, 2012; Hilbig & Zettler, 2009; McClintock & Allison, 1989). Present Study
In the present pre-registered study, we sought to address the question whether SVO is
related to the use of protective measures against COVID-19 depending on the assumed protective value of the behavior for oneself or the public. We preregistered two hypotheses (https://osf.io/8faeb): (1) With increasing SVO, protective measures will be seen as more effective for protecting the public. (2) High SVO will result in more usage of measures that are perceived to protect the public and low SVO will result in more reliance on measures that are
assumed to protect the self. To test these hypotheses, we conducted an online study with a convenience sample from the general population in Germany.
Method

content.heading: Participants and Design
content.text:
We recruited participants from a database (ORSEE; Greiner, 2015) and via postings in
university Facebook groups. We collected data from N = 419 (age = 38.07 years (sd = 15.67), female = 71.1 % (diverse = 0.5%), students = 34.37%, for a detailed description see the supplement). We excluded seven participants who had extreme responses (1 or 101) for all responses in at least one category. Participants completed an online survey available from 3/20/2020 until 3/23/2020, and as a thank you for participation, respondents were offered to take part in a lottery for six Amazon gift certificates of 20€ each. Materials
We measured social value orientation (SVO; Van Lange et al., 1997) with the slider
measure (Murphy, Ackermann, & Handgraaf, 2011) and asked participants to rate 17 behaviors regarding their protective value for themselves and the public. Then we asked participants how often they currently exhibit these behaviors. As control variables, we assessed honesty-humility with the Hexaco60 (Ashton & Lee, 2007) and trait anxiety (German version of the BFI-2; Danner et al., 2016).
Personality measures SVO was measured using the primary items of the SVO slider measure (Murphy et al.,
2011). Honesty-humility was measured with the Hexaco60 subscale (Lee & Ashton, 2018). To assess trait-anxiety we used the four items forming the anxiety subscale in the BFI-2 (Danner et
al., 2016). The Cronbach's Alphas, means and standard deviations of the scale scores are reported in Table 1 Internal consistencies, means, and standard deviations of scales..

content.heading: Protective behaviors
content.text:
The participants rated 17 behaviors (see Fig. 2 and Fig. 3 for the complete list), 14 of
these behaviors had been endorsed as protective measures against COVID-19 by the WHO (www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/advice-for-public). The three other behaviors were (1) one behavior that is not protective (going to corona parties), (2) one behavior that has high public protective value (shopping for members of high-risk groups), and (3) one behavior that has more protective value for the self than for the public (stockpiling food). All three behaviors were used as a consistency check of responses. These three behaviors were analyzed together with all other items. The responses to the item “attend corona parties” were reversed and it was renamed “avoid corona parties” so that all behaviors were protective and not hazardous. The behaviors in Figs. 2 and 3 are ordered based on the reported frequency of usage. However, their order was randomized in the survey.
The perceived protective value of behavior for the self and the public was measured with
the response to the items, respectively, “Behavior protects me (‘Verhalten schützt mich’)” and “Behavior protects the public (‘Verhalten schützt die Allgemeinheit’)”. Each behavior was rated on a slider measure with the anchors not at all – totally and no numeric values were presented. Both items were portrayed with sliders next to each other so that participants could quickly complete the questionnaire. Participants rated each of the 17 behaviors in a matrix.

We used a similar slider measure to assess the frequency of engaging in a specific
protective behavior. The question “How often do you show this behavior these days (‘Wie häufig zeigen Sie derzeit aufgrund von COVID-19 die folgenden Verhaltensweisen?’)” was used but with the anchors never – very often.
As stated in the preregistration and because the study is part of a larger project, we also
assessed risk perception, attitudes towards measures against COVID-19, flexible goal adjustment and tenacious goal pursuit, and state anxiety. Procedure
Participants gave their consent to the study and then responded to the survey which had
the following sequence: (1) SVO Slider measure (Murphy et al., 2011), (2) Hexaco60 items for the Honesty-humility subscale (Ashton & Lee, 2007), (3) items assessing trait anxiety, (3) items of the FLEXTEN (Bak & Brandtstädter, 1998), (4) ratings of the protective value of behaviors for the self and the public, (5) risk perception regarding COVID-19, (6) attitudes towards COVID-19 measures, (7) reports on the frequency of engaging in specific protective measures, and (8) short version of the state anxiety measure (Grimm, 2009). Finally, participants were able to register for a lottery of six Amazon gift certificates of 20€ each. Statistical Methods
The analysis was performed in R version 3.6.3 (R Development Core Team, 2020) using
Tidyverse packages (Wickham et al., 2019). We used library glmmTMB (Brooks et al., 2017) for generalized linear mixed model analysis and psych (Revelle, 2019) for psychometric tools. Responses regarding the self-protective value and public protective value, and frequency of use behaviors was transformed by subtracting one from the raw response and dividing it by 100 so that final values were between 0 and 1.
Results
First, as preregistered, we checked the validity of the slider measure of social value
orientation (SVO) within our sample. SVO was correlated with Honesty-Humility, r = .29, p <. 0001, Bayes Factor >1000 but not with trait anxiety, r = .019, p = .6834, Bayes Factor =0.12. Inspecting the distribution of SVO in the sample depicted in Fig. 1 shows that 92.2% of participants fall into the prosocial type.
Attending corona parties (reversed and renamed to “avoid corona parties” for the analysis) received low ratings for the protective value and usage. Participants were sensitive to the objective protective value of behavior and rated shopping for individuals of high-risk groups as particularly as being valuable for the public and rated stocking up on food as particularly valuable for the self. In general, the density of the responses was concentrated at the extreme positive endpoints of self and public perceived protective values with some behaviors (e.g., not shaking hands, wash hands for 30 seconds, etc.) exhibiting almost no variation (see Fig. 2).
Fig. 2. Distribution of behavior ratings for self-protection versus public protection. The geometric density depicts the perceived self-protective value on the x-axis against the perceived public protective value on the y-axis. See supplementary information for the same data replotted for different SVO levels.
The frequency of usage of each behavior was clearly dependent on the perceived public
protective value and particularly the perceived self-protective value (Fig. 3). Behaviors fell into two clusters: behaviors that people engaged in frequently and behaviors that people engaged in less frequently with almost no middle ground between the two. Although both self and public protective values were positively correlated with the frequency of the behavior, it is only the former that had a strong and a statistically significant effect (see Table 2 for a generalized linear mixed model, beta family with self-protection, public protection and their interaction with SVO

as fixed factors, behavior and participant ID as random factors). Thus, it is the perceived selfprotective value of behavior that is most important for its usage. Behaviors that were low on selfprotective value (e.g., wearing face masks, wearing gloves, etc.) were reported less frequently despite having medium scores regarding their perceived public protective value.

Discussion
The present study sought to investigate the effect of social value orientation (SVO) on the
perception and use of protective measures against COVID-19. We found that people use protective measures that foremost protect themselves with public protective value only being a secondary concern. This was found despite the fact that most participants (92.2%) in the present sample can be classified as prosocial according to the SVO measure.
The present study shows that health communication was effective in influencing people’s
perceptions. Protective measures such as social distancing and washing hands, which had been communicated as being effective ways to protect the self and the public, were perceived as such and adopted. Other measures, such as wearing face masks that had been portrayed over and over again as important for the public and but not for self-protection were used much less. Future health communication could build on that finding and elaborate on how public prevention, in the long run, will also affect the individual and the individual’s close relations to increase the perceived self-protective value of protective behavior.
We found no evidence that SVO influenced either the perception or the frequency of
usage of protective measures. However, the majority of the present sample were categorized as prosocial, thus the finding that SVO did not influence the perception of protective measures or
their use cannot be generalized. But the homogeneity of the sample also increases the importance of the present study, as it shows that even individuals who are prosocial and who are motivated by cooperation and fairness seek first to protect themselves in the case of the pandemic. Limitations
The current study is based on a non-representative sample and data does not reflect the
perceptions and behaviors of the general public. Participants in the current study were volunteers and, as the data on SVO indicates, in general very prosocial. Furthermore, the responses in the current study were based on self-reports and therefore are not objective indicators. Self-reports may have been affected by social desirability in that people wanted to present themselves as behaving in a way that is approved of by the public. Still, preventive behavior that does not serve the self was not reported frequently. It is to be expected that endorsing public protection would be socially desirable. Thus, taking social desirability into account, actual behavioral data may be even more extreme, that is, self-protective value may be even more important. Most importantly, the present study was cross-sectional and therefore causal inferences cannot be drawn. Conclusions
We reported that even prosocially oriented individuals seek self-protective measures first
and foremost with public protection being only a secondary motive. Thus, when communicating the importance of a public protective behavior the emphasis should be on how public prevention, in the long run, will affect individuals themselves and their close relations.

content.text: This working paper has not yet been peer reviewed. Date: March 23, 2020

content.heading: Introduction
content.text:
The COVID-19 pandemic presents a unique challenge to societies all over the globe. In recent history, most major societal crises (e.g., the financial crisis of 2008) could be successfully addressed through the interventions of politicians, and citizens should essentially just ”keep calm and carry on.” An epidemic crisis, however, is different. To hinder an accelerating growth in infections, changes in the core social habits of citizens are necessary and these behavioral changes are required to happen exceptionally fast. Specifically, citizens need to engage in rapid “physical distancing,” that is, the minimization of close contact with others.1 Physical distancing reduces the probability that an infected person spreads the virus SARS-CoV-2 to those not infected (1) and, hence, aims to reduce the excessive demands on health systems and thus allowing effective treatment of the most vulnerable (2). Physical distancing is recommended and promoted by national and international institutions (The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention; World Health Organization) as well as national governments around the globe. To enforce physical distancing, many health institutions and authorities have opted for a combination of encouragement and the implementation of strong regulatory decisions such as from limiting social life in public spaces over shutting down public institutions and private companies to strict curfews. To understand psychological motivations to engage in physical distancing, it is important to note that it comes at considerable personal cost since it implies reducing social contact with valued close others. At the same time, however, practicing physical distancing does not only protect oneself but has clear prosocial aspects in the sense that it helps to protect other individuals, especially those most vulnerable to the virus. Building on this notion, we tested the idea that physical distancing can reflect, and be encouraged through the engagement of a genuine prosocial motivation—empathy for those most vulnerable to the virus. In three studies that include samples from the US, the UK, and Germany, we test whether (i) empathy is related to the motivation for physical distancing, and (ii) whether inducing empathy for those most vulnerable to the virus causally increase the motivation to adhere to physical distancing. In this way, the present studies identify a basic motivation to adhere to a crucial measure to fight the COVID-19 pandemic. Even more importantly, the present research provide direct evidence for policymakers on how to tailor their communication to achieve greater public compliance, and ultimately to save lives. Empathy can be defined as an umbrella term capturing the range of a person’s responses to another individual’s experience (3). Past research has convincingly demonstrated the beneficial consequences of both affective as well as cognitive empathy for the welfare of others. Specifically, cognitive empathy (i.e., taking the perspective of others) has been linked to reductions of inter-group conflicts and prejudice, while affective empathy (i.e., a concern for and an understanding of vulnerable others) has been shown to promote altruism and caring (4–6).
1 The World Health Organization initially referred to ”physical distancing” as “social distancing” but now recommends the use of the present term. The reason is that it is important to encourage continued social interaction (e.g., via telecommunication) during epidemic isolation periods.
Anthropologist Margaret Mead considered caring about vulnerable (harmed) others—who would, as is in the animal kingdom, die without the help of a caring individual—to be the first sign of civilization in a culture (7). In the modern health context, affective empathy in particular has been shown to improve health outcomes. For instance, physicians’ affective empathy levels are positively associated with reduced metabolic complications and better self-care in diabetic patients (8, 9). Affective empathy has further been shown to promote healthcare professionals’ adherence to hand washing compliance to protect others in hospitals (10, 11). Overall, past research has shown that empathy reflects a basic motivation that promotes a variety of behavioral outcomes aimed at helping and protecting vulnerable others. Here, we show, first, that empathy for those most vulnerable to the virus (e.g., the elderly, who are more likely to suffer from severe symptoms and have a higher mortality (12)) is associated with increased physical distancing (Studies 1 and 2) and, second, that experimentally induced (affective) empathy promotes the motivation to adhere to physical distancing (Study 3).

content.heading: Results
content.text:
Study 1 consists of three non-representative samples (each N > 300) from western countries being affected by the COVID-19 pandemic: The US, the UK, and Germany. The sample in the US was collected on March 17, 2020 (UK and Germany: March 18). At that time, none of the countries was completely locked down; in fact, it was possible to still go to bars and shops; home office was promoted but not implemented nationwide (this status also holds for the other studies reported in this article). In each sample of Study 1, individuals indicated their physical distancing practice via self-report on a 5-point Likert scale (possible range 1–5); a sample item reads, “Because of coronavirus COVID-19, I am massively curtailing social contact (so-called ’social distancing’).” In the items, we used the term “social distancing” instead of “physical distancing” because “social distancing” was much more common in the media and news at the time data was collected. We observed relatively high levels of physical distancing in each country, with some variability (US: M = 4.44, SD = 0.80; UK: M = 4.27, SD = 0.85; Germany: M = 4.24, SD = 0.89). We further assessed individuals’ self-reported empathy for those most vulnerable to the virus (possible range: 1–5); a sample item reads, “I feel compassion for those most vulnerable to coronavirus COVID-19.” We observed relatively high levels of empathy, with some variability (US: M = 4.46, SD = 0.74; UK: M = 4.56, SD = 0.61; Germany: M = 4.02, SD = 0.93). In line with the idea that physical distancing is motivated by empathy, we document in all three countries a positive relation between empathy and physical distancing (US: r = .61, P < .001; UK: r = .29, P < .001; Germany: r = .48, P < .001; see Figure 1). In Study 2, conducted on March 19, 2020, we replicated the findings of Study 1 in a different German sample (N = 359). We applied the same measurement of empathy as in Study 1 (possible range 1–5, M = 4.06, SD = 0.94) but assessed physical distancing in a more concrete and prospective way (overall M = 4.56, SD = 0.65); a sample item reads, “During my free time in the next days, I will visit elderly people (e.g., parents, grandparents, elderly friends).” The items were re-coded for the analyses of Study 2 so that higher values reflect more physical distancing. In Study 2, we also found that empathy relates to physical distancing (r = .32, P < .001; see
Figure 1).
Study 3 was built on the knowledge gained from Studies 1 and 2 and sought to test whether we can use empathy to promote physical distancing. Study 3 (N = 868) was run in Germany on March 19 and 20, 2020. We measured motivation to adhere to physical distancing as in Study 2 and tested whether we can increase this motivation by inducing empathy. Study 3 had three randomized between-subjects conditions. In an information only condition, we provided participants with mere background information about why it is important to reduce contact between persons (i.e., physical distancing); it was stated that researchers consider physical distancing to be an effective tool to slowing the spread of the COVID-19 disease, preventing the collapse of hospitals, and protecting those being most vulnerable to the virus. In an information + empathy condition, in addition to the information, we showed participants a one-minute video, in which a 91-year-old man sadly reports that he stops visiting his chronically sick wife due to the virus (see https://osf.io/pq3ky/ for the video). The video was pretested and elicited high levels of affective empathy (see Materials and Methods). In the control condition, no information and no video were given, resembling a situation of no intervention.
A one-way ANOVA shows that the motivation to adhere to physical distancing differed between conditions, F(2, 865) = 6.06, P = .002 (see Figure 2). Additional analyses revealed that the motivation to adhere to physical distancing did not significantly increase by information only, control condition: M = 4.30, SD = 0.76, information only condition: M = 4.39, SD = 0.74; t(608) = 1.577, P = .115, Cohen’s d = .13. In contrast, the motivation to adhere to physical distancing increased significantly by inducing empathy; the information + empathy condition had a significantly higher mean of 4.51 (SD = 0.66) compared to the control condition, t(561) = 3.523, P < .001, Cohen’s d = .30. The information + empathy condition and the information only condition also did differ significantly from each other, t(561) = 1.973, P = .049, Cohen’s d = .17. In further analyses, we show that empathy significantly increases the percentage of individuals who indicate that they want to adhere strictly to physical distancing (as measured by the percentage of individuals indicating maximal approval of every single physical distancing statement; see https://osf.io/pq3ky/ for these analyses).

content.heading: Discussion
content.text:
The present investigation has two major findings. First, empathy for those most vulnerable to the virus is a basic motivation for physical distancing. Second, we can actually use empathy to promote the motivation to adhere to physical distancing. Importantly, providing individuals with
mere background information about why it is important to adhere to physical distancing was not enough to significantly increase motivation; only if empathy was added did the motivation for physical distancing increase. The present research has important policy implications. Specifically, in the effort to reach very high levels of physical distancing, it might not be sufficient to provide only basic information about why physical distancing is important. Basic information certainly is important. However, an emotional ingredient—affective empathy—seems to be necessary to reach very high levels of physical distancing. As such, when designing interventions and communication materials to change behavior during the COVID-19 pandemic, policymakers should consider enriching mere informational content with emotional content. As shown in the present investigation, empathy for those most vulnerable to the virus might be a promising candidate here. In discussing the findings, we want to acknowledge limitations of the present research and point to future directions. The present set of studies was conducted in western countries only, and the samples were not representative of the entire population in these countries. The studies were conducted online using self-reports. The intervention (inducing empathy) was applied and tested on only a short-term scale. As such, it might be useful to replicate the present studies’ findings using different stimuli as well as representative samples; to conduct the studies in other (non-)western countries; to assess actual behavior (instead of self-reported motivation); and, to measure the long-term consequences of (repeated) induction of empathy. Nonetheless, we argue that these shortcomings do not limit the basic conclusions and the potential of the findings in mitigating the COVID-19 pandemic. In fact, the present research highlights the potential of using empathy as a tool to promote physical distancing and to save lives, especially of the most vulnerable members of our societies.

content.heading: Materials and Methods
content.text:
Participants gave informed consent before starting the study. All studies were preregistered. Data, sample characteristics (demographics), materials, and the preregistrations are available on the Open Science Framework (https://osf.io/pq3ky/). All results remain robust in terms of significance levels and effect size when controlling for participants’ gender and age. Participants were recruited via the crowdsourcing platforms Prolific (Study 1) and Clickworker (Study 2 and 3) to complete a short survey on “coronavirus (COVID-19)” in exchange for 0.40£ (~0.47 US Dollar). Both platforms provide reliable data. We applied two attention check items to secure high data quality (see OSF at https://osf.io/pq3ky/). Sample size for Studies 1 and 2 was based on an a priori power analysis to detect effects of r > .20 with high statistical power (Power = .95; alpha-level .05, two-tailed). Based on this analysis, we aimed to collect at least 314 participants in each sample (final samples Study 1: 322 participants from the US; 317 from the UK; 326 from Germany; Study 2: 361 from Germany). Study 3 was powered to enable detecting effects of f > .13 with high statistical power (Power = .90; alpha-level .05, two-tailed). Based on this analysis, we aimed to collect at least 800 participants. We finally collected data from 868 German participants.
In Study 1, we measured empathy for those most vulnerable to the virus with three items, adapted from Pfattheicher et al. (13) (in all samples, Cronbach’s α > .81). All items are available on the OSF (https://osf.io/pq3ky/). If not indicated otherwise, labels in the studies always ranged from 1 = “strongly disagree” to 5 = “strongly agree.” The items measuring empathy were mixed with three filler items to reduce demand characteristics. We measured physical distancing with two items (in all samples, α > .79). In Study 2, we measured empathy with the same items as in Study 1 (α = .89), and we measured physical distancing with five concrete and prospective items (α = .76). A sample item reads, “During my free time in the next days, I will visit elderly people (e.g., parents, grandparents, elderly friends).” Labels ranged from 1 = “very unlikely” to 5 = “very likely” for this scale (for the reported findings of Studies 2 and 3, the scale was reversed, such that higher values reflect more physical distancing). In Study 3, participants were randomly assigned to one of three conditions: the information only condition (n = 305); the information + empathy condition (n = 258); and, the control condition (n = 305). Conditions did not significantly differ in terms of the assessed demographics: gender, χ2(2, N = 864) = 1.08, P = .582), age, F(2, 865) = 0.58, P = .558, and household size, F(2, 865) = 1.09, P = .337. Participants in the information only condition read (translated from German), “At the time of the COVID-19 pandemic: Researchers emphasize that reducing contact between persons is an effective tool to slowing spreading of the virus. A slowed spread of the virus relieves pressure from the hospitals. A collapse of hospitals would be particularly dangerous for those most vulnerable in our society, in particular elderly and sick people. Therefore, it is important to reducing contact between persons.” In the information + empathy condition, in addition to the information that was presented in the information only condition, we showed participants a one-minute video where a 91-year-old man sadly reports that he stops visiting his chronically sick wife due to the virus. Participants could not proceed with the study before the video ended. The video was pretested in an independent study (N = 51; detailed results are available at https://osf.io/pq3ky/) and elicited high levels of affective empathy. In the control condition, no information and video were given. As the central dependent variable, we measured adherence to physical distancing with the same items as in Study 2 (α = .76). In Study 1, we additionally measured “motivation to stay in self-quarantine if infected”; “motivation to stay in isolation if infected”; and, “motivation to follow major rules imposed by the government.” All constructs were significantly correlated with empathy in each sample (all rs > .22 , all Ps < .001). See OSF for all analyses (https://osf.io/pq3ky/). In addition, in the US sample of Study 1 only, political orientation was measured using the item, “How would you place your political views generally speaking?” The response format for this question was a Likert-type scale ranging from 0 = “extremely liberal” to 10 = “extremely conservative.” Political orientation was negatively correlated with physical distancing (r = -.26, P < .001) and negatively with empathy (r = -.21, P < .001), and it did not significantly moderate the relation between empathy and physical distancing (P = .818).

content.text:
COVID-19 threatens lives, livelihoods, and civic institutions. Although public health initiatives (i.e., social distancing) help manage its impact, these initiatives can further sever our connections to people and institutions that affirm our identities. Three studies (N=1,195) validated a brief 10- item COVID-19 threat scale that assesses 1) realistic threats to physical or financial safety, and 2) symbolic threats to one’s sociocultural identity. Studies reveal that both realistic and symbolic threat predict higher anxiety and lower wellbeing, and demonstrate convergent validity with other measures of threat sensitivity. Importantly, the two kinds of threat diverge in their relationship to public health behaviors (e.g., social distancing): Realistic threat predicted greater self-reported compliance, whereas symbolic threat predicted less self-reported compliance to these social-disconnection initiatives. Symbolic threat also predicted using creative ways to affirm identity even in isolation. Our findings highlight how social psychological theory can be leveraged to understand and predict people’s behavior in pandemics.

Key words: COVID-19, Scale Validation, Realistic Threat, Symbolic Threat, Psychological Health, Public Health.
Psychological Threats of COVID-19
Measuring Two Distinct Psychological Threats of COVID-19 and their Unique Impacts on
Well-being and Adherence to Public Health Behaviors
“An almost ‘perfect killing machine’ ”
(Sanchez, CNN, March 15, 2020, referring to COVID-19)
“America, as we knew it, is on hold”
(Maxouris, Almasy, McLaughlin, CNN, March 12, 2020)
In December 2019, an outbreak of pneumonia was reported in Wuhan, China, which
scientists attributed to a novel coronavirus: SARS-CoV-2 (or, colloquially, COVID-19). Months later, this novel coronavirus unleashed a global pandemic of sickness on a scale unseen since the Spanish flu pandemic of 1918. The spread of the coronavirus is clearly reshaping the fabric of social life, and social psychology is at the forefront of studying these changes (Everett, Colombatto, Chituc, Brady, & Crockett, 2020; Priniski & Holyoak, 2020; Van Bavel et al., 2020.) Essential to this nascent research movement is understanding—and measuring—how people perceive the threat of the virus (Flake, Pek, & Hehman, 2017).
Laypeople (Sanchez, 2020), public health leaders (Hennekens, George, Adirim, &
Johnson, 2020), and social psychologists (Sherif, 1966; Esses, Jackson, & Armstrong, 1998) often conceptualize threat as realistic threat, a concrete attack on physical and material wellbeing. Although realistic threat is undoubtedly important, social psychology research highlights another important kind of threat: symbolic threat, an assault on our cultural and national identity (e.g., Kachanoff, Kteily, Khullar, Park, & Taylor, in press; Stephan, Ybarra, & Morrison, 2006; Tajfel & Turner, 1979). Although both realistic and symbolic threat likely increase psychological distress, they may differentially predict public health behaviors—which can have important implications for how well people and communities respond to pandemics. Here, we validate a
Psychological Threats of COVID-19
brief ten-item scale that assesses the experience of both symbolic and realistic threat of COVID19, and examine each of their consequences for well-being and public health behaviors.

content.heading: Disease and Threat
content.text:
The threat of disease powerfully impacts humanity by endangering physical health
(Hennekens, et al., 2020; Viboud, Tam, Fleming, Handel, Miller, & Simonsen, 2006), psychological health (Matsuishi, et al., 2012; O’Leary, Jalloh, Neria, 2018), and the economy (Smith, Keogh-Brown, Barnett, & Tait, 2009). The ubiquitous specter of disease across history has shaped the evolution of human behavior, emotions, and morality (Rozin, Lowery, Imada, & Haidt, 1999; Haidt, 2001), and the structure of sociocultural systems (Gelfand et al., 2011; Harrington & Gelfand, 2014).
Diseases most obviously pose realistic threats: concrete risks to an individual’s (or
group’s) physical health and economic well-being (Esses, et al., 1998; Kachanoff & Taylor, 2017). COVID-19 certainly represents a realistic threat through its attack on physical health and capacity to create mass-unemployment (Davies, Partington & Wearden, 2020; Patterson, 2020). Pundits (Sanchez, 2020) and global health leaders (Hennekens, et al., 2020) have emphasized realistic threats from COVID-19, calling the virus “an almost perfect killing machine”. A recent Pew research poll on Americans’ perceptions of threat from COVID-19 focused exclusively on realistic threat (Pew Research Poll, Wave 63.5, March 10, 2020).
Despite the importance of realistic threat, it is not the only threat caused by pandemics.
Humans are not just animals with basic needs for physical self-preservation; we are social animals who depend on our cultural groups for motivation (Oyserman, 2007), psychological well-being (Kachanoff, Wohl, Koestner, & Taylor, 2020), and structure (Gelfand et al., 2011). Threats to the “integrity or validity of the ingroup’s meaning system [such as] religion, values,
Psychological Threats of COVID-19
belief system, ideology, philosophy, morality, and world view” (Stephan, Ybarra, & Morrison, 2006, p.3-5) are called symbolic threats. COVID-19 poses a symbolic threat because social distancing—the primary method for combatting its spread—results in a weakened sense of community or national identity. The neighborhoods, religious communities, schools, and sports groups that give people a sense of meaning are unraveled by COVID-19 (ur-Rehman et al., 2020; Maxouris, et al., 2020). As one quote suggests, COVID-19 means that “America [and all Nations] as we knew it, is on hold” (Maxouris et al., 2020).
Although realistic threats can translate into symbolic threats—if everyone in a group dies,
so will its culture—theories of intergroup relations argue for the distinctness of these two kinds of threat. Social identity theory (1979) introduced symbolic (social identity) threat when the field was focused solely on realistic concerns (Sherif, 1966; see Jackson, 1993 for review). Later, integrated threat theory (Stephan & Stephan, 2000; Zárate, Garcia, Garza, & Hiltan, 2004) reconciled both literatures by showing the unique consequences of both types of threat for intergroup attitudes. Here, we apply this integrated approach and distinction between symbolic and realistic threat to a global pandemic1.

content.heading: Unique and Sometimes Opposite Consequences of Realistic Versus Symbolic Threats
content.text:
Examining realistic and symbolic threat of COVID-19 provides a unique opportunity to
test the predictions of integrated threat theory and may also help better understand people’s response to public health initiatives.
One clear prediction is that—as psychological threats—the experience of realistic and
symbolic threats should each independently predict increased distress (Beck, Epstein, Brown, & Steer, 1988; Horowitz, Wilner, & Alverez, 1979) and lower psychological well-being (Diener,
1 Our focus is not on whether pandemics exacerbate the symbolic or realistic threats of other groups, but, on the perceived threats posed directly by the pandemic.
Psychological Threats of COVID-19
Emmons, Larsen, Griffin, 1985; Watson, Clark, & Tellegen, 1988). Within intergroup contexts, threats to one’s personal or collective physical safety and resources (i.e. realistic threat), or to what it means to be a member of one’s group (i.e., symbolic threat), are both detrimental to psychological well-being (e.g., Kachanoff, Taylor, Caouette, Khullar, & Wohl, 2019, de la Sablonnière, Taylor, Perozzo, & Sadykova, 2009).
Although both kinds of threat should increase distress, they may be associated with
opposite reactions to public health outcomes such as social distancing. The goal of social distancing is to combat the dangers of contagion, but by isolating people from their social groups, it sacrifices social connection. In other words, social distancing might increase symbolic threat while attempting to decrease realistic threat. Accordingly, we hypothesize that feelings of realistic threat would predict increased self-reported support and adherence to public health initiatives, whereas feelings of symbolic threat would predict decreased self-reported support and adherence. The idea that people might compromise their physical health to protect their sense of social identity is clear in cases when people risk their lives to protect the causes and values of their group (Bélanger, Caouette, Sharvit, & Dugas, 2014; King & Taylor, 2011).
One final prediction is that symbolic threat might also have a more constructive aspect:
predicting when individuals find new ways to affirm their social identity, even while social distancing (e.g., interacting virtually online with cultural groups, family dinners). People may find creative solutions to the cruel ultimatum posed by global pandemics of physical safety versus social meaning.

content.heading: Present Research
content.text:
We conducted three studies using cross-sectional (Study 1 and 2) and longitudinal (Study
1 and 3) designs to achieve two core objectives. First, we developed a brief and psychometrically
Psychological Threats of COVID-19
sound 10-item scale measuring realistic or symbolic threat. To assess factor structure, we used principal component analysis (Study 1), confirmatory factor analysis (Study 2), and invariance analysis (Study 3). To examine convergent and divergent validity (Studies 1 and 2), we examined associations with individual differences related to threat sensitivity (need for cognitive closure (Rubin, 2018), beliefs in a dangerous world (Duckitt & Fisher, 2013), valuing conservation (Schwartz, Sagiv, Boehnke, 2000), and emotional (in)stability (Schneider, 2004)). Second, as outlined above, we examined the dissociable impact of realistic and symbolic threat on 1) psychological distress/well-being, 2) self-reported adherence to public health initiatives, and 3) new ways of maintaining social identity in the face of social distance.
Psychological Threats of COVID-19
Study 1
This study examined the convergent, divergent, and criterion validity of an initial set of
items developed to assess perceptions of symbolic and realistic threat of COVID-19. Half of our sample had previously completed a survey unrelated to COVID-19 in October 2019, which allowed us to assess scale validity both cross-sectionally (analyzing all responses during COVID-19), and longitudinally (analyzing pre- and post-COVID-19 differences among the same sample).
Method
Sample. Between March 19th and 20th, 2020, 399 American participants were recruited
from MTurk. After pre-registered exclusions, 346 participants (160 male, 184 female, 2 other; Mage=41.51, SDage=13.46; 80.9% White, 9.5% Black or African American, 4.9% Latinx/Hispanic) completed all measures during the COVID-19 crisis. One-hundred and ninetythree of these participants (after exclusions, 86 male, 105 female, 2 other, Mage=42.27, SDage=13.99; 85.5% White, 8.8% Black or African American, 3.1% Latinx/Hispanic) also had completed all non-COVID-19 items in October 2019. See Supplemental Materials and https://aspredicted.org/blind.php?x=zj99wh for more information, including statistical power considerations2
Measures. For brevity we only describe the Integrated COVID-19 Threat Scale in detail.
All questionnaires reported are available in the Supplemental Materials and detailed in Table 2.
Integrated COVID-19 Threat Scale. All items were framed with the opening: “How
much of a threat, if any, is the coronavirus outbreak to…” and were rated from 1 (Not a Threat)
to 4 (Major Threat). To assess realistic threat, we adapted 5 pre-existing items ( =.77) used by
2 We note that the scales focused on in Study 1 were part of a larger study focusing on the impact of COVID-19 threat and morality most broadly. See registration for all collected measures.
Psychological Threats of COVID-19
the Pew Research Poll (Pew Research Poll, Wave 63.5, March 10, 2020) to document perceived threat of COVID-19. Participants were asked about the threat of COVID-19 to “your personal health”, “the health of the U.S. population as a whole”, “your personal financial safety”, “the U.S economy”, and “day-to-day life in your local community”3
We used 5 items ( =.85) to assess symbolic threat of COVID-19. Four items were based
on Stephan and colleagues’ (2006) definition of symbolic threat cited above. We asked participants if they felt COVID-19 poses a threat to “What it means to be American”, “American values and traditions”, “The maintenance of law and order in America”, and “American Democracy”. We also included one item assessing threat to the “The rights and freedoms of the U.S. population as a whole” adapted from Kachanoff and colleagues (2019).
Results
For all studies, we provide a more detailed result summary in Supplemental Materials. Factor structure of Integrated COVID-19 Threat Scale. Principal component analysis
revealed a 2-factor solution: one factor with 5 items assessing symbolic threat (Eigen Value = 4.20, Variance Explained = 42.02%), and one factor with 5 items assessing realistic threat (Eigen Value = 1.64, Variance Explained = 16.34%). See Table 1 for factor loadings.
3 In this initial study we generated a pool of 20 items to explore different types of threat which go beyond the focus of this paper (e.g., threat to loved ones). All items are available in Supplemental Materials and OSF data. We do to focus on items pertaining to loved ones because of their substantial overlap with items pertaining to the self. We also limited the realistic threat items to only those used in the PEW poll so our findings can generalize to their report. Because of the exploratory nature of our initial scale construction we validated our scale structure in two subsequent pre-registered studies (Study 2 and 3) using only the 10-items we focused on.
Psychological Threats of COVID-19
COVID-19 was positively associated with the need for cognitive closure, belief in a dangerous world, values associated with conservation, and was negatively associated with emotional stability (whether both dimensions were combined or—largely—examined independently). Indicating divergent validity, threat of COVID-19 (combining both dimensions) was not significantly associated with any of the other dimensions of Schwartz’s value scale or the TenItem-Personality Inventory. See Table 2 for descriptive statistics and correlations.
Criterion validity. We examined the association between symbolic threat and realistic
threat, and the three criterion outcomes simultaneously with one structural equation path model (SEM; Byrne, 1994), see Supplemental Materials for full description of the analysis. Symbolic threat was significantly positively associated with COVID-19 impact avoidance (b=.98, 95% CI [.26, 1.70], p=.008) and COVID-19 impact intrusion (b=1.10, 95% CI [.43, 1.77], p=.001), but
Psychological Threats of COVID-19
was not significantly associated with anxiety (b=.56, 95% CI [-.14, 1.26], p=.114). Realistic threat was significantly positively associated with anxiety (b=2.79, 95% CI [1.85, 3,72], p<.001), as well as with COVID-19 impact intrusion (b=3.18, 95% CI [2.29, 4.07], p<.001), but was not associated with COVID-19 impact avoidance (b=.25, 95% CI [-.72, 1.22], p=.613).
Psychological Threats of COVID-19
Psychological Threats of COVID-19
Longitudinal evidence (repeat participants only). Convergent and divergent validity. Indicating convergent validity, and replicating our
cross-sectional results, the perceived threat of COVID-19 was positively associated with all four individual differences associated with threat sensitivity (whether both dimensions were combined or—largely—examined independently). Indicating divergent validity, threat of COVID-19 was largely not associated with other values or personality traits. See Table 3 for descriptive statistics and correlations.
Criterion validity. We regressed anxiety during the COVID-19 pandemic onto symbolic
threat, realistic threat, and base-line anxiety assessed 5 months prior to the global pandemic. Realistic threat (b=1,71, 95% CI [.67, 2.75], p=.001) but not symbolic threat (b=.28, 95% CI [- .50, 1.06], p=.486) was associated with anxiety during the pandemic, controlling for base-line anxiety.

content.heading: Discussion
content.text:
We found initial support in Study 1 for the factorial structure, as well as, evidence for the
convergent and divergent validity of our scale. While the threat of COVID-19 was robustly associated with individual differences linked to threat sensitivity, COVID-19 threat was not consistently associated with other individual differences. Demonstrating criterion validity, both symbolic and realistic threat were both uniquely related to psychological distress. Realistic threat was robustly associated with having intrusive thoughts about the virus, and heightened anxiety (even when controlling for anxiety five months prior). Symbolic threat (but not realistic threat) was associated with trying to avoid thinking about or dealing with the virus, as well as, intrusive thoughts. We further tested the validity of our scale in Study 2 and examined whether/how realistic or symbolic threat predict public health behaviors.
Psychological Threats of COVID-19
Psychological Threats of COVID-19
Study 2
Study 2 further examined the validity of the Integrated COVID-19 Threat Scale and also
whether realistic and symbolic threat might be differentially related to self-reported behavioral adherence and support for public health initiatives, and with finding new ways to maintain social identity while in isolation. We also assessed psychological well-being (Diener, et al., 1985) and affect (Watson, et al., 1988).
Method
Sample. Five-hundred and fifty American participants recruited from Mturk completed
the survey on March 26th, 2020. After pre-registered exclusions, 537 participants (256 male, 278 female, 3 other; Mage=41.51, SDage=13.46; 77.8% White, 11.7% Black or African American, 5.6% Latinx/Hispanic) were included in our analyses. See Supplemental Materials and http://aspredicted.org/blind.php?x=5uu4kf for more information (including statistical power).
Measures. All questionnaires reported are available in the Supplemental Materials and
are detailed in Table 5. In Table 4 we provide all items used to assess compliance with public health behaviors and social identity affirmation in isolation.

Results
Confirmatory factor analysis. Confirmatory factor analysis (CFA; Byrne, 1994)
indicated the two-factor model had acceptable model fit indices: comparative fit index (CFI)=.93, standard root mean square intervals (SRMR)=.06, root mean square error
Approximation (RMSEA)=.08, 90% CI[.07, .10], BIC=12206.97, 2 =161.08 (Hu & Bentler,
1999; Byrne, 1994; Steiger, 1990) and no negative error variances or improper solutions, see Figure 2. We compared the two-factor model to a one-factor model which did not differentiate between symbolic threat or realistic threat (CFI=.75, SRMR=.12, RMSEA=.15, 90% CI[.14,.16],
BIC=12519.63, 2 =480.37). The one-factor model had inferior model fit, dif2 =-319.29, p<.001.

Convergent and divergent validity. Overall, we found a consistent pattern of results
with Study 1, supporting both convergent and divergent validity. See Table 5 for descriptives and correlations and Supplemental Materials for full description of results.
Criterion validity. We examined the association between symbolic threat and realistic threat, and all
criterion outcomes of interest simultaneously within one structural equation path model (SEM; Byrne, 1994; using the Lavaan package in R, (Rosseel, 2012), see Supplemental Materials for full description of the analysis. See Table 6 for descriptive statistics and correlations.
Psychological distress. Replicating Study 1, symbolic threat was significantly positively
associated with COVID-19 impact avoidance and COVID-19 impact intrusion. In contrast to Study 1, symbolic threat was also significantly associated with anxiety. Replicating Study 1, realistic threat was significantly positively associated with anxiety and COVID-19 impact intrusion. In contrast to Study 1, realistic threat was also associated with COVID-19 impact avoidance.
Psychological well-being. Symbolic and realistic threat were positively associated with
negative affect. Realistic threat (but not symbolic threat) was negatively associated with life satisfaction. We observed an unanticipated significant positive relation between symbolic threat and positive affect. Exploratory parallel-mediation analysis revealed this effect was partially mediated by increased social identity affirming behaviors in isolation (but not decreased adherence to public health initiatives; See analysis in Supplemental Materials for details).
Support and adherence with public health initiatives. As predicted, realistic threat was
significantly and positively associated with support of and self-reported adherence to public
Psychological Threats of COVID-19
health initiatives like social distancing and handwashing. In contrast, symbolic threat was significantly and negatively associated with support and adherence to public health initiatives.
Social identity affirmation in isolation. As we expected, symbolic threat was positively
associated with engaging in creative behaviors (while in isolation) to affirm one’s American identity (e.g., cooking food subjectively associated with America). Realistic threats were also significantly positively associated with such behaviors.

Discussion
Study 2 provides further evidence for the psychometric properties of the integrated
COVID-19 threat scale (using CFA) and replicated findings pertaining to convergent and divergent validity shown in Study 1. Both threats were also consequential. People who experienced greater symbolic and realistic threat reported greater psychological distress, and realistic threats were associated with less life-satisfaction.
Symbolic and realistic threats had opposite associations with support and engagement
with important public health initiatives. People higher in realistic threat reported greater compliance and support for initiatives such as social distancing and hand-washing, while people higher in symbolic threat reported being less supportive and compliant. As predicted, experiencing symbolic threat was positively associated with engaging in social identity affirming behaviors in social isolation. Unexpectedly, realistic threat was also associated with identity affirming behaviors, potentially because individuals high in realistic threat were spending more time in isolation.
Study 3
In Study 3 we aimed to replicate Study 2’s findings pertaining to criterion outcomes,
using a longitudinal design in which we examined whether perceived threat of COVID-19 predicted outcomes one week later. To do this, we re-sampled as many participants who took part in Study 1 (Time 1: March 19th-20th) as possible and asked them to complete criterion measures one week later (Time 2: March 27th-28th). In addition, we asked participants to complete the ten-item COVID-19 threat scale at the end of the survey, so we could test the longitudinal invariance of the scale.
Psychological Threats of COVID-19
Method
Sample. Three hundred and eleven participants recruited from Mturk completed the
survey on March 27th-28th 2020. Three hundred and ten participants had completed the study one week prior (T1) on March 19th-20th (i.e., participants from Study 1). After pre-registered exclusions, our sample consisted of 259 participants (122 male, 137female; Mage=41.51, SDage=13.46; 81.9% White, 9.3% Black or African American, 3.5 % Latinx/Hispanic). See Supplemental Materials and https://aspredicted.org/blind.php?x=2ed62c for more information.
Measures. We assessed realistic and symbolic threat and all criterion validity measures
used in Study 2. See Tables 9 for reliability and the Supplemental Materials for the full questionnaires. Results
Scale invariance. We examined the invariance of both subscales using longitudinal
confirmatory factor analysis (Meredith, 1993) with the SemTools package in R (Jorgensen, 2019). Because we confirmed there being two distinct factors in Study 2, and because all our analyses focus on the separate sub-scales we explored the invariance of each sub-scale separately. We tested for configural invariance (i.e., does the scale assess the same construct over time), metric invariance (i.e., does the scale have the same meaning over time), scalar invariance (i.e., can we compare means over time) and the equivalence of means over time. See Supplemental Materials for full details. As illustrated in Table 8, we find evidence for configural, metric and scalar invariance, as well as equivalence in the latent means, for both the symbolic and realistic threat scales (all ΔCFIs<.003; all Δ Χ2 n.s; all ΔRmSEAs <.007; Cheung & Rensvold, 2002).

content.heading: Criterion validity.
content.text:
Using SEM, we examined the association between symbolic threat and realistic threat (at
T1), and all criterion outcomes assessed one week later (at T2), simultaneously in one model. See Table 9 for descriptive statistics and correlations.
Psychological distress. Symbolic threat (at T1) was significantly positively associated
with COVID-19 impact avoidance, COVID-19 impact intrusion, and general anxiety over the course of the following week (measured at T2). Realistic threat was also associated with COVID-19 impact intrusion and anxiety, but was not associated with COVID-19 impact avoidance.
Psychological well-being. Both types of threat (at T1) were positively associated with
negative affect experienced over the course of a subsequent week. Replicating Study 2, Realistic threat (but not symbolic threat) was negatively associated with life satisfaction. As in Study 2, we again observed an unanticipated significant positive relation between symbolic threat and positive affect. Consistent with Study 2, exploratory parallel-mediation analysis showed this effect was mediated by increases in social identity affirming behaviors in isolation (but not decreased adherence to public health initiatives).
Support and adherence with public health initiatives. Replicating Study 2, experiencing
realistic threat (at T1) was significantly and positively associated with support and compliance with public health initiatives to fight COVID-19 over the course of the subsequent week (assessed at T2). In direct contrast, experiencing symbolic threat was significantly and negatively associated with support and compliance.
Psychological Threats of COVID-19
Symbolic threat (but not realistic threat) assessed at T1 was positively associated with
engaging in behaviors (while in isolation) to affirm one’s American identity over the course of the next week.4
Discussion
Both dimensions of the 10-item threat scale were invariant over time. This provides
initial evidence showing the scale can be used to compare changes in perceived threat over time (Flake et al., 2017).
Consistent with Study 1-2, both threats were uniquely associated with greater
psychological distress and diminished psychological well-being one week later (with some nuance in terms of which outcome they impacted). Both threats had distinct consequences for adherence to public health initiatives, such that realistic threat predicted greater self-reported compliance and support, while symbolic threat predicted diminished compliance and support. However, symbolic threat (but not realistic threat) was associated with greater engagement in behaviors affirming American identity.

Across studies, total threat was not related to political ideology; symbolic threat was weakly and inconsistently positively associated with conservatism and; realistic threat was consistently negatively associated with conservatism. We repeated the SEM analyses assessing outcomes, including political orientation as a predictor. Results were consistent except: In Study 2 the positive association between positive affect and symbolic threat became n.s.; In Study 2 the positive association between social identity affirmation and symbolic threat became n.s; in Study 3 the negative association between life satisfaction and realistic threat became marginal.
