Appendix SA
Public-health Messages
Self-centered: "Keep yourself healthy! First and foremost, prioritize your own health. Control other people's distance from you, and keep them at least 6 feet away. Use soap and hand sanitizer often to keep other people's germs away. Leave your home only to take care of your basic needs (food and medical care). If possible, work from home." Responsible: "Take personal responsibility! You have an obligation to safeguard your health. Be mindful how far you are from other people, and maintain a distance of at least 6 feet. Carefully wash your hands with soap, or rub them with hand sanitizer thoroughly. You should not leave your home, except for such necessities as food or medical care. If possible, work from home." Compassionate: "Help protect the vulnerable! Consider the well-being of people who are older or have chronic health conditions. To reduce their and everyone's risk, try to keep a distance of at least 6 feet away from others. Help slow the spread of germs by washing your hands with soap and using hand sanitizer often. To protect my community, only leave the house if you need necessities, like food, medication, or to help a person in need. If possible, work from home." Avoidant: "Avoid the disease! It is essential to stay clear of the contagion. To remain disease-free, steer away from people by keeping a distance of at least 6 feet. To ward off germs, cleanse your hands thoroughly with soap or hand sanitizer often. Avoid leaving your home, except to get food or medical care. If possible, work from home." Sociable: “Distant socializing, not social distancing! You don't have to give up on the fun of socializing because of the coronavirus. You have to keep 6 feet a part in person, but you can meet up online or chat over the phone one-on-one or in a group session. That way, you can leave your home only for necessities, like getting food or medical care. And if you do, don't spoil the party - wash your hands with soap or use hand sanitizer often. If possible, work from home.”

claim2: However, consistent with previous research in social psychology,  a  large  survey  conducted  in  Europe  in  the  early  stage  of  the  COVID-19  epidemic shows that the majority of respondents was actually overly optimistic about the risk of infection.
claim3a: most  people  in  Europe  are more  subject  to  “unrealistic” optimism than an excessive pessimism
claim3b: using a Pearson Chi square test
claim4: On the other hand, the comparison between perceived risk of infection for oneself and that for others shows that these two variables are significantly different (P < 0.001). Thus, approximately half the participants judged coronavirus infection less likely to happen to them than to other people, demonstrating strong evidence of “unrealistic optimism” in their personal expectations related to the COVID-19 epidemic, whereas only around 5% expressed the opposite comparative risk judgment.

Are people excessively pessimistic about the risk of coronavirus infection?

Are people excessively pessimistic about the risk of coronavirus infection?
The recent emergence of the SARS-CoV-2 in China has raised the spectre of a novel, potentially catastrophic pandemic in both scientific and lay communities throughout the world. In this particular context, people have been accused of being excessively pessimistic regarding the future consequences of this emerging health threat. However, consistent with previous research in social psychology, a large survey conducted in Europe in the early stage of the COVID-19 epidemic shows that the majority of respondents was actually overly optimistic about the risk of infection.

content.heading: A rational panic?
content.text: Human behaviours play a fundamental role in the propagation of many pathogens by either amplifying or attenuating their transmission through person-to-person contact1. From an epidemiological perspective, the massive adoption by the population of health protective behaviour, through improved personal hygiene or social distancing measures, is generally effective in reducing or slowing down the transmission of respiratory infectious diseases2. However, from a social and economic perspective, avoidance behaviours can also have dramatic side effects when they result in discrimination towards sub-groups of individuals or a shortage of basic necessities such as food or pharmaceutical products3. In the early stage of the COVID-19 epidemic, the question as to whether the emergence of the coronavirus in China triggered a panic reaction, i.e. disproportionate public risk perceptions and emotion-driven behaviours with regard to the available epidemiological data, led to somewhat contradictory comments from famous experts. For instance, Dr. Michelle Dusart publicly decried the people’s exaggerated fear and hysterical reaction to the risk of the coronavirus infection, while Prof. Didier Raoult and Prof. Nassim Nicholas Taleb, on the other hand, argued that it was rational for people to fear such an emerging health threat. Nevertheless, as mass media have the tendency to highlight aberrant behaviours, and as we know little to date about what people really think about the risk of coronavirus infection, it is not possible to determine whether they are overly optimistic or pessimistic about the future consequences of the COVID-19 epidemic for population health.

content.heading: The research survey
content.text:
In late February 2020, prior to the Italian and French outbreak, an international research survey was conducted among large samples of citizens (N = 4,348) in four countries of the European Region (France, Italy, United Kingdom, and Switzerland) via a network for influenza surveillance4. Here, we examine public perceptions of risk of coronavirus infection by asking the participants to estimate on a discrete percentage scale, the probabilities for themselves and the general national population of getting the disease in the next few months. During the last decades, a great number of psychological studies have shown that risk perceptions are generally subject to an optimistic bias5,6. The optimistic bias tend

In the case of emerging infectious diseases, it is practically impossible to demonstrate that individual’s optimistic or pessimistic expectations about the future are unrealistic, as we cannot know in advance what the final prevalence rates of infection will be in various populations. However, it is possible to rely on opinions made and released to the press by some famous experts in the field of epidemiology of infectious diseases, in order to determine whether the current expectations of the public and experts are congruent. For instance, based on (unpublished) simple epidemiological models using basic assumptions about the transmission rate of SARS-CoV-2, Prof. Marc Lipsitch or Prof. Gabriel Leung roughly estimated that more than 40% of the worldwide population could become infected in the coming year7.

content.heading: Evidence of unrealistic optimism
content.text:
Figure 1 shows the distribution of the perceived risk of SARS-CoV-2 infection for oneself and that for others on a discrete percentage scale. Consistent with previous research in social psychology8,9, people were found to estimate the coronavirus risk in an optimistically skewed manner. On the one hand, both the perceived risk of infection for oneself, as well as that for others, were substantially lower than expert
coronavirus infection would affect less than 1% of the national population. However, as reliable epidemiological predictions related to COVID-19 are not yet available at this stage, we cannot exclude the hypothesis that mean expectations made by the European populations are actually more pessimistic than optimistic. On the other hand, the comparison between perceived risk of infection for oneself and that for others shows that these two variables are significantly different (P < 0.001). Thus, approximately half the participants judged coronavirus infection less likely to happen to them than to other people, demonstrating strong evidence of “unrealistic optimism” in their personal expectations related to the COVID-19 epidemic, whereas only around 5% expressed the opposite comparative risk judgment. Moreover, as presented in Table 1, people showed different levels of optimism across countries and socio-demographic groups, with the French, female and less educated participants exhibiting a greater optimistic bias in their comparative risk judgments (P < 0.001).
Overall, these empirical data suggest that most people in Europe were more subject to “unrealistic” optimism than an excessive pessimism concerning the risk of coronavirus infection. Of course, with the rapid spread of the disease in Europe, as well as potential developments in the biomedical sciences (such as the identification of an effective and affordable treatment against SARS-CoV-2), we could not expect to find the same pattern of risk perceptions and epidemiological predictions in the coming weeks10. However, the use of similar questions in future international surveys would make it possible to monitor the change in risk perceptions and health behaviours over time. This might provide us a valuable empirical material to understand and predict better the complex interplay between public risk perceptions, emotion-driven protective behaviours and key epidemiological parameters, such as the transmission and fatality rates of COVID-19.

This research examines chronic concerns about infectious diseases (using the Perceived Vulnerability to Disease questionnaire) and travel ban supports in response to the 2019-nCoV outbreak in January 2020. Two studies were conducted in the United States (Study 1; N = 241) and Singapore (Study 2; N = 138). For Americans who scored higher on the Perceived Infectability subscale, they were more likely to endorse travel bans on people coming from China and all of Asia. For Singaporeans who reported greater Germ Aversion, they were more supportive of travel bans on people from both China and their Malaysian neighbor. Saliency of the outbreak may account for differences in subscale predictors between Americans and Singaporeans.
Throughout history, diseases have universally threatened the survival of human beings
(Ackerman, Hill, & Murray, 2018; Schaller & Park, 2011). In response to such threat, humans engage in behavioral responses to avoid contact with pathogens to ensure survival such as lowering their sociability and movement at the interpersonal level (Mortensen, Becker, Ackerman, Neuberg, & Kendrick, 2010). At the intergroup level, pathogen threat triggers ethnocentrism to defend against outgroups (Faulkner, Schaller, Park, & Duncan, 2004; Green et al., 2010). Those who are more chronically concerned about the threat of diseases are more likely to engage in such adaptive behaviors or attitudes when diseases are particularly salient such as an outbreak (Green et al., 2010; Inbar, Westgate, Pizarro, & Nosek, 2016). At the current moment of this writing, the World Health Organization (WHO; 2020) had declared a 2019-nCoV coronavirus outbreak that originated in Wuhan, China, as a global health emergency. This naturally salient threat may trigger certain responses to protect one’s survival and health. This research examines how chronic sensitivities to diseases predict supports for restrictive travel bans in light of the outbreak among people in the United States and Singapore. Behavioral Immune System
Humans adapted a “behavioral” immune system that complements the biological immune
system, and it acts as a precautionary measure to prevent infection (Schaller & Park, 2011). When diseases are made salient (via images of diseases, odor, proximity to ostensibly sick individuals, etc.), people become more introverted and less sociable (Mortensen et al., 2010). Similarly, people who live in (historically) pathogen-rich environments also exhibit low levels of sociability (Schaller & Murray, 2008). This system minimizes likelihood of being infected by
diseases as measured using the Perceived Vulnerability to Disease questionnaire (PVD; Duncan, Schaller, & Park, 2009; Faulkner et al., 2004). For these individuals, avoidance or exclusion of an entire outgroup or country can be seen as beneficially outweighing the cost of infections.

content.heading: Current Research
content.text:
This research examines how PVD predicts support for travel bans in response to the
coronavirus outbreak among people in the United States (Study 1) and Singapore (Study 2). Both studies were conducted approximately 1 or 2 days after the coronavirus reached the respective countries, providing a unique context to understand how the behavioral immune system responds to a contextually salient pathogen threat. For people in both countries, greater PVD (specifically the Germ Aversion subscale) should predict more restrictive travel ban supports on travelers coming from Wuhan specifically and China broadly. Furthermore, this should extend even to travelers from a whole continent (Study 1) or a neighboring country (Study 2). Pre-registrations, data, and materials for both studies are on OSF: https://osf.io/rkxj4/?view_only=dbc38ac206e94a5884834cb60e89fd64

A total of 277 MTurk workers participated, but 36 participants did not pass an attention check and/or reported that they randomly responded to questions. After exclusion, 241 participants (40.2% women; M age = 35.44) remained.

Perceived Vulnerability to Disease (PVD). PVD measures individual differences in
people’s chronic concern over infectious diseases (Duncan et al., 2009). It is divided into two subscales of Perceived Infectability (7 items; α = .82) and Germ Aversion (8 items; α = .73), using a 7-point scale (1 = strongly disagree; 7 = strongly agree).
Perceived Infectability measures individuals’ perceptions of their own susceptibility to
infectious diseases. Example items of Perceived Infectability include “In general, I am very susceptible to colds, flu, and other infectious diseases” and “If an illness is ‘going around,’ I will get it.” Germ Aversion measures discomfort and fear of contexts in which disease transmissions are particularly likely. Examples of Germ Aversion are “I am comfortable sharing a water bottle with a friend” and “I prefer to wash my hands pretty soon after shaking someone’s hand.” While the two subscales are correlated, Perceived Infectability captures beliefs about likelihood of being infected in the future as well as threat to the self but Germ Aversion captures immediate affective responses to pathogen-salient contexts (Duncan et al., 2009; Wang et al., 2018).
Two items from the Germ Aversion subscale were modified from the original scale to be
more reflective of current culture. One item was changed from “I avoid using public telephones because of the risk that I may catch something from the previous user” to “I avoid using public bathrooms.” Another item was modified from “My hands do not feel dirty after touching money” to “My hands do not feel dirty after touching door handles.” These items were modified because public telephones and cash are less commonly used nowadays.

Among those who were unsure or unaware of the virus, Perceived Infectability
significantly predicted support for travel bans (standardized β = .45, p < .001) but Germ Aversion did not (β = .06, p = .470). Interestingly, Perceived Infectability was a stronger predictor when participants were unaware relative to aware of the virus, but Germ Aversion showed the reverse pattern (albeit weakly). This suggests that Perceived Infectability may be a stronger predictor when pathogen threat is more distal.

content.heading: Method
content.text:
Study 2 sought to replicate the findings in another geographic context: Singapore. The
first documented case of the coronavirus in Singapore was announced on January 23, 2020. Study 2 was conducted in Singapore between January 24 and January 28, 2020. Singapore provides a rich comparison given that the coronavirus outbreak is more salient among its population because China is relatively closer to Singapore than the United States with frequent travels between the two Asian countries, especially during Lunar New Year season.
Procedure was identical to Study 1 with the exception that attention and randomness
checks were not included. Participants were recruited via social media and likely less familiar

Malaysia is a neighboring country of Singapore with shared natural resources, close economic ties, and similar cultural backgrounds. It would provide a stringent test on the ethnocentric protective response since Malaysia and Singapore have bilateral relations. Supporting travel bans on Malaysia would be considered a fairly extreme response.
Participants and procedure. Participants were recruited via social media (e.g., Twitter,
Facebook, WeChat). Because it was unclear how many participants could be potentially recruited in this manner, pre-registration goal was set with at least 100 participants and ending on January 28, 2020. A total of 138 participants in Singapore (62.3% women; M age = 31.70) completed the study. Of the 138 participants, 136 were aware of the virus and 2 were unsure. With 138 participants, r = .24 could be detected with 80% power (two-tailed, alpha = 0.5).
All participants read a similar description of the coronavirus outbreak as Study 1, with

content.heading: Results
content.text:
As shown in Table 2, Germ Aversion emerged as the sole significant predictor of all
dependent variables. Germ Aversion predicted more restrictive policy, extending beyond China to Singapore’s neighboring country of Malaysia. Contrary to Study 1 and pre-registration, Perceived Infectability was not a significant predictor among the Singaporean sample.
General Discussion
The 2019-nCoV coronavirus outbreak ignited a global panic at the onset of 2020. Within
a week after Study 2 was run, Singapore declared a travel ban that prevented people with recent travels in any part of China from entering the country (Johnson, 2020). Although such restrictions may seem reasonable given the spread of the outbreak throughout China, Studies 1 and 2 demonstrated that such fear could generalize beyond the infected country. Americans with greater perceived susceptibility to infections were more willing to ban travelers from an entire continent. For more germ-averse Singaporeans, they would be willing to extend the ban to their Malaysian neighbor with whom they share important natural resources.
Studies 1 and 2 diverged in their predictors. In Study 1, Perceived Infectability was more
predictive of travel ban supports whereas Germ Aversion was more predictive in Study 2. One
proximity with China made Singapore a more vulnerable target than the United States. As such, Germ Aversion may be a stronger predictor among Singaporeans because it is more contextually salient and a more immediate threat. Exploratory analyses in Study 1 further showed that Perceived Infectability is more predictive among those who were unaware of the virus, suggesting that it is a stronger predictor when pathogen threat is not seen as an immediate environmental threat (Wang et al., 2018).
This research provides a unique snapshot into individual differences in response to a
naturally occurring pathogen threat within two countries. An outbreak such as this may threaten not only the health of a country’s citizens but also jeopardizes its relations with other countries.

content.text:
In response to the coronavirus outbreak, people may experience anxiety, empathy, and prosocial willingness. However, the relationship between emotions, empathy, and prosocial behaviour is unknown. It is said that empathy is affected by moods and influences pro-sociality. Thus, how does an emergency change people’s empathy and prosocial willingness? We
conducted a study with 1,190 participants before (N=520) and after (N=570) the coronavirus outbreak. We found that prosocial willingness decreased post-outbreak, maybe by the decreased empathy levels, in accordance with compassion fatigue theory. Trait empathy could affect prosocial willingness indirectly through the empathy level. News discriminability and distance from the outbreak epicentre played a role in the trait empathy change. Given how emergency health events influence emotion and the effects of personal traits on prosocial willingness, social media users and providers should understand the negative effects of information over-exposure on mental health during the outbreak.
The impact of the current global health emergency, termed COVID-19 by the World
Health Organization (WHO), has significantly changed people's lives worldwide, casting a shadow over the mind of an enormous population. The world is fighting a war against the new universal ‘enemy’. Compared to the outbreak of the SARS 17 years ago, more transparent and timely information is available, partially due to more advanced and diverse information platforms. Although clarity and immediacy guaranteed the right to be informed, people are bombarded by various information and their moods enter a cycle of complexity1, especially when effects can be broad, substantial, and long-lasting2.
Encouraging slogan and unequivocal instruction can stabilize mood, while aversive news
induces emotional responses to pain in others such as sadness and anxiety3. For example, when we see the pain or even death of a patient and the desperation of the health care workers, a heart-breaking feeling hits us and tears well up. The capacity associated with feeling and evaluating the pain level of other as well as further understanding others is specifically referred to as pain empathy4, which is a fundamental feature of our innate capacity for empathy5. Empathy is considered to be a developmental social function that helps individuals to understand others’ emotions or mental states6.
Two components in the psychological structure of empathy have been proposed:
empathetic concern (also known as trait empathy) and perspective-taking (also known as cognitive empathy)7. This division of empathy shows particular functions of empathy: cognitive empathy describes how people recognize others’ emotions and understand their perspectives, while affective empathy refers to the autonomic and vicarious emotional responses to others’ emotions8,9. Watching others’ pain experiences may activate one’s own sensory region of the brain10 as if it were a personal experience. A theoretical ‘pain matrix’ specifically describes the sensory and affective qualities of pain empathy11. It is said that people activate the ‘pain matrix’ networks when feeling self-pain; interestingly, the same neural network will also be activated when they observe and feel others’ pain11. However, prior work
examined the shared and unique networks for sensory and affective pain and the possibility that when empathy occurs, the ‘pain matrix’ is partially activated, specifically, only the affection related components mediate empathy12. In essence, EEG and fMRI studies on pain empathy have reached an explanation that a mirror neuron system may be the physiological basis of empathy5.
For decades, research on empathy has mainly focused on empathy for negative events,
such as physical pain4,5,13 or social pain14, resulting from the idea that empathy is a potential motivator for prosocial behaviours. From rescuing behaviour in ants15 to the feeding each other in bats, prosocial behaviour is observed throughout the non-human species16. In a graylag geese flock, an increase in heartrate (considered as distress levels) has been detected when they observe a conflict involving close kin, consistent with an empathic response17. Decety (2016) emphasized the mediation effect of empathy on pro-sociality in conspecifics, when one is sensitive to others’ stress and well-being. A growing body of research has indicated that a spontaneous motivation to alleviate the pain of others is generated from empathy when people feel others’ suffering19,20. Besides, the implementation of altruistic behaviour to a certain extent relieves negative feelings12, or even physical pain on oneself 21.
Although empathy is an aspect of social responsiveness, which is conducive to many
aspects, it is very energy-consuming and compassion fatigue happens when one’s empathy reaches its limit22. Compassion fatigue is defined as the stress and breakdown caused by a short-term, intense exposure to an unfortunate situation, as well as the numbness and depression caused by prolonged exposure23. Due to massive news updating, heavy exposure to victims’ pain is a serious problem not only for those who provide care and services, but for average individuals as well24. Hence, in the context of this global public health emergency, it is crucial to understand how this outbreak would influence people’s empathy and whether empathy could still drive prosocial behaviour, especially considering that altruistic behaviours can facilitate human sharing and cooperation and enable group members to collectively survive
various crises, such as food shortages and natural disasters25.
Regarding understanding of the effects of a socially traumatic event, the ripple effect
suggests that the impact of an unfortunate event decays gradually as ripples spread outward from the epicentre26. In contrast to the ripple effect, Li et al. (2009) proposed a counterintuitive model—the ‘Psychological Typhoon Eye’ effect (PTE) —which describes a psychological phenomenon observed during China’s Wenchuan earthquake, in which the closer one is to the epicentre of a devastated area, the lower a resident's concern/anxiety about health and safety. These two models indicate that the distance from the disease epicentre should play a role in human emotions and cast doubts regarding the influencing direction (i.e. facilitating or decreasing concern/anxiety levels along with further distance in the current context of the coronavirus). It has been found that negative mood harms empathy, as someone experiencing negative mood might be less empathic and motivated to help a suffering person than someone experiencing positive mood (Li, Meng, Li, Yang, & Yuan, 2017). Therefore, it is likely that the anxiety generated by this outbreak may impair empathy and prosocial behaviour, and distance could change this effect to some extent.
Given the importance of empathy and prosocial behaviour for collaboration during a crisis,
it is crucial to assess the relationship between empathy level and prosocial willingness. Moreover, exposure to adverse life events typically predicts negative outcomes, and it is unknown how the current aversive events may foster subsequent emotional responses and changes in empathy and pro-sociality. Despite its significance, there is a relative lack of empirical and theoretical work linking event outbreak, empathy, and prosocial tendencies. To address these issues, participants in the present study were presented with 12 video clips which displayed either real or faked expressions of pain (see Methods) before and during the coronavirus outbreak. We recorded a total of 1,190 (N = 520 in the first dataset, N = 570 in the second dataset, details in Table 1) participant pain ratings of the performer in each clip as well as participants’ empathy levels, vicarious experiences, and the degree to which they would like
to share the pain with the performer as an indicator of prosocial willingness (Figure 2, Figure S2). Additionally, Interpersonal Reactivity Index (IRI) scores were collected to investigate the potential effects of trait empathy and distance from the disease epicentre (i.e. Wuhan, China), and anxiety levels were also collected to investigate potential modulation effects on empathy and prosocial behaviours. For more information about people’s understanding of COVID-19, we also included an 18-item COVID-19 relevant questionnaire to investigate certain relationships related to how people’s information load affects their pain empathy (see supplemental materials).

In light of previous literature on pro-sociality, during a life-threatening period, people may
increase their avoidance of social interactions for the sake of survival27. However, from an evolutionary perspective, altruistic behaviours would be selected to facilitate cooperation and enable group members to collectively survive various crises, such as food shortages and natural disasters25. Further, the impact of quarantines strongly influences approach motives2. It is also well-established that empathy drives prosocial behaviour28,29, and people are now immersed in emergency-related information that can lead to compassion fatigue. Therefore, rather than promoting prosocial tendencies, we assumed that as the COVID-19 and news reports increase, empathy-induced prosocial tendencies (pain-sharing willingness) would decrease during the outbreak, and this prosocial tendency shift would be most strongly evidenced by empathy
levels (pain ratings of the performer) decreasing in our online task.
Furthermore, we considered that trait empathy would affect pro-sociality, and it could
establish a certain correlation with empathy levels in our task. During the epidemic time, we were interested in more possible impactors. Repeated exposure to news coverage of negative events has been linked to poor mental health outcomes30. Thus, in the current situation, people most likely keep experiencing overexposure to various information, similar to the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) period31, which particularly changes their state of mind32, and further influences empathy. Finally, it is possible that outbreak-generated anxiety may influence empathy and prosocial behaviour in terms of distance, according to the PTE.
Results

content.heading: Participants’ age and gender
content.text:
Firstly, we summarized the participants distribution regarding age and gender. The results
showed that in dataset1 (pre-outbreak) and dataset2 (post-outbreak), the groups were unevenly distributed in terms of age, t(1088)=6.64, P<0.001 and gender, χ2=14.89, P<0.001. Hence, age and gender were included as covariates in the following analysis to control for the mixed effect and the questionnaire results (Table S1). Video authenticity judgment significantly affected perceived pain in others (i.e. empathy level), self-pain (vicarious experience), and shared pain (i.e. prosocial willingness, supplementary Table 1). Therefore, it was controlled in the further model analysis as a possible confounding variable. Empathy levels and prosocial willingness pre- and post-outbreak
To determine the effect of the coronavirus outbreak on empathy and prosocial behaviour,
t-tests were conducted to compare the differences in perceived pain in others (i.e. empathy level) and shared pain (prosocial willingness) between pre- and post-outbreak. The results showed both empathy levels (pre: M=3.89, SD=1.55; post: M=3.60, SD=1.53; t=4.27 , P<0.001) and prosocial willingness (pre: M=3.73, SD=1.67; post: M=3.50, SD=1.63; t=3.16 , P<0.01) significantly decreased during the outbreak (Fig. 2).
Trait empathy pre- and post-outbreak
Since we were interested in the potential influence of the epidemic disease on trait
empathy, a t-test was also conducted on IRI subscales, including perspective-taking, triat empathy, personal distress, and fantasy. The results showed that when the outbreak occurred, a negative fluctuation was witnessed in the individuals’ empathy-related traits (Fig. 2). Except for personal distress (pre: M=23.53, SD=4.07; post: M= 4.14, SD= 3.50; t=-2.62, P<0.01) and fantasy (pre: M=24.54, SD=4.68; post: M=23.98, SD=4.49; t=2.03 , P<0.05), all other IRI subscale scores were significantly decreased in the post-outbreak: trait empathy (pre: M=25.05, SD=3.50; post: M=24.56, SD=3.03; t=2.48, P<0.05) , and perspective taking (pre: M=24.14, SD=2.97; post: M=23.43, SD=4.06; t=5.71 , P<0.001). However, the autism-spectrum quotient (AQ) seems to be stable in the two stages (pre: M=23.47 SD=3.27; post: M=23.52, SD=2.86; t=-0.27, P=0.79). The aforementioned results showed that empathy levels, trait empathy, perspective-taking, fantasy, and prosocial willingness decreased during the coronavirus outbreak. Simple mediation models
We further investigated whether empathy level would mediate the relationship between
individual differences in trait empathy and prosocial willingness by establishing three mediation models with trait empathy (empathy, perspective-taking, and fantasy) as the respective predictor, empathy level as a mediator, and prosocial willingness as the dependent variable. Data were standardized in the analysis of the moderation and mediation models and we used PROCESS in SPSS for the mediation and moderation analysis33.
The results showed a significant mediating model for trait empathy and perspective-taking,
but not for fantasy. Trait empathy positively predicted prosocial willingness (β=0.052, t(2095)=3.16, P=0.0016; path C’) and empathy level in a positive manner (β=0.057, t(2098)=3.49, P< 0.001; path A). Furthermore, empathy level robustly predicted prosocial willingness (β=0.70, t(2095)=21.97, P<0.001; path B) (Fig. 3).
Perspective taking significantly positively predicted prosocial willingness (β=0.096,
t(2095)=5.85, P<0.001; path C’), and empathy level as well (β=0.043, t(2098)=2.64, P=0.008; path A). Similarly, perspective taking significantly predicted prosocial willingness (β=0.62, t(2095)=22.07, P<0.001; path B) (Fig. 3).
Finally, the same model was not proved valid for fantasy. Fantasy did not predict empathy
level (β=0.03, t(2098)=1.96, P=0.05; path A); although, empathy level robustly predicted prosocial willingness (β=0.62, t(2095)=21.98, P<0.001; path B). In addition, fantasy did not predict prosocial willingness (β=0.01, t(2095)=0.69, P=0.49; path C’).
Our results indicated that empathy level could only mediate the predictive relationship
from empathy and perspective taking to prosocial willingness, but not from fantasy. We further included a binary variable of time (pre- and post-outbreak) as a moderator to test whether the coronavirus would have a moderating effect (model 14 in PROCESS). These results showed that the moderating effect happened on an empathy level predicting prosocial willingness (β=-
0.083, P = 0.012 < 0.05, 95% CI: [-0.15,-0.02], path B), suggesting that the predictive extent from empathy to prosocial behaviour decreased after the coronavirus outbreak (Fig. S5). Distance from the outbreak epicentre
To test the cognitive empathy-driven prosocial behaviour changes in terms of distance
under the emergency according to the PTE, a moderation model (model 1 in PROCESS) was used. The variable ‘distance to Wuhan’ is a binary value (near/far) separated by the mean of the distance calculated by the IP address (see supplementary Methods). There was no evidence that distance influenced how empathy level correlated with prosocial willingness (Fig. S5). Anxiety
We then investigated the effect of anxiety on this process, considering that anxiety would
have a negative influence on empathy and prosocial behaviours. To investigate this possibility, we established a serial two-part mediation model (model 6 in the PROCESS). The results showed that anxiety could influence prosocial willingness through trait empathy and empathy
level (Fig. 4). Regarding the current mental state development, the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI) was used to evaluate post-outbreak anxiety levels (Table 1), along with some direct questions about how people felt during the outbreak in terms of anxiety, depression, and fear (see more in supplementary material). Although state anxiety did not directly predict prosocial willingness, this pattern could be explained by suppressing effect34 (β=0.096, t(2095)=5.85, P<0.001; path C’).
Finally, we explored the effect of distance according to the PTE. We calculated each
participant’s distance to the disease epicentre, which was based on IP address (near and far) by the mean of the distance (see supplementary Methods). The interaction of state anxiety and distance to Wuhan was significant (β=0.17, P=0.007). In the post-outbreak stage, compared to
people near the outbreak epicentre, the state anxiety of people in the far region did not sensitively predict trait empathy (Fig. S10). Therefore, we continued to analyse the possibility that distance could play a role in the serial mediation chain. Our result indicated that distance moderated the influence that state anxiety has on trait empathy and further affected prosocial willingness (Fig. 4).

Excessive information exposure makes people become confused about news authenticity.
Again, a moderation model (model 1 in PROCESS) was used to examine how news discriminability induced anxiety-affected trait empathy (IRI subscale).
Fig.6 State anxiety changes across news discriminability
News discriminability moderated how state anxiety negatively predicted trait empathy
(STAI subscale). State anxiety in this model predicted empathy (β=-0.17, t(1119)=-5.62, P<0.001). News discriminability did not significantly predict trait empathy (t(1119)=0.02, P=0.98). The more anxious people felt, the less empathy they displayed. The interaction of news discriminability and state anxiety was significant (β=-0.07, t(1119)=-2.38, P=0.02). In the post-outbreak period, people became confused about overwhelming news which imposed a bad influence on trait empathy.

content.heading: Discussion
content.text:
The salient coronavirus threat may trigger government intervention and certain
psychological responses to public health problems. The goal of this study was to investigate the effect of an emerging infectious outbreak on people’s empathy levels and prosocial willingness and further explore the underlying mechanisms of the relationship between these variables. Importantly, our study provides several moderation and mediation models to examine the effects of empathy on prosocial behaviour before and after the COVID-19 outbreak. We explored the influence of other potential impactors like emotional states, particularly anxiety. Furthermore, the PTE effect was also tested under the infectious health emergency instead of geographical disasters as usual.
In line with previous studies, we found a significant empathy-driven prosocial
disposition14,19,21. From the evolutionary perspective, when people find others at a disadvantage such as physical pain and mental setback experiences, a motivation to help is generated for both individual and collective benefit35. People with more empathy tend to do more altruistic helping behaviours for others’ wellbeing. In other words, as our results suggested, the willingness to behave pro-socially would decrease as empathy levels (feeling other’s pain) decrease in the post-outbreak period. Moreover, we found trait empathy could influence sharing tendencies, which were mediated by the fundamental perception of others’ pain. In terms of emotional state, our data indicated the salience of trait empathy was markedly inhibited by
anxiety level, variations in distance difference (near and far regions), and different news authenticity discriminability.
‘Collateral damage from trauma’, that is, those who do not experience misfortune
directly, can also create a similar psychological impact when witnessing others’ pain experience 36. Staub and Vollhardt (2008) put forward the ‘suffering altruism’ (altruism born of suffering) concept for the sake of development38. Previous study investigated the explanation of the ‘suffering altruism’ found out people may gain more social support and thus generate a sense of gratitude that enhances prosocial inclination39. Nevertheless, instead of enhancing the possibility of benevolence under the current situation, less kindness was observed in the present study. First of all, the overall feeling of others’ pain significantly decreased after the outbreak. Emotion contagion as the primary stage of empathy, is widely seen in daily life, for example, yawning, tickling, and feeling distress, which represents certain sensitivity to what others are experiencing40. Our results also showed a decreasing tendency of perspective taking ability in the post-outbreak that people less stood the perspective of others to feel others’ pain feelings during the outbreak period. Considering the possible large energy costs associated with empathy, empathy is never easy, and requires the involvement of emotional and cognitive aspects41. This may explain why empathy avoidance may be a preferable choice as people only have limited one’s inner resources.
Additionally, individual differences in trait empathy exist, which largely influences
behaviour tendency18. In this study, trait empathy was measured by the IRI, which is considered a valid instrument to assess people’s ability to empathize. Besides, in accordance to previous studies, we considered the ‘feeling of others’ pain’ ratings as indicators of empathy levels4,5,13. Our findings indicated that empathy level was significantly predicted by the trait empathy, suggesting an effective induction of empathy in the study. We were primarily concerned with how trait empathy affected prosocial behaviour and the role of empathy level in the process. As expected, a robust mediation effect was established when the effect of COVID-19
(comparison between two-time stages) was taken into account. We found that trait empathy could predict prosocial willingness directly, but also indirectly through empathy level, which varied in pre- and post-timepoint. Perspective taking, the critical part of cognitive empathy, had similar mediating effects, referring to some extent to the theory of mind: an important aspect of empathy is the ability to put oneself in other people's shoes42.
Although emotional contagion of pain feeling weakened during the outbreak, other types
of emotion were widely spreading. Disaster makes people over-stressed and anxious, even leading to the development of post-traumatic stress disorder years after the event24. Moreover, negative mood such as anxious feeling, inhibits the neural underpinnings (i.e. mirror neuron system) of empathy36. As for emotional states, we further explored how they are affected by anxiety. We found that people who currently felt anxious (state anxiety) and more confused about the authenticity of the news showed a lower level of empathy. It is worth noting that state anxiety, in addition to being directly predictive of trait empathy, can also be moderated by information uncertainty. Understandably, when one’s own survival is at stake, one can no longer provide help or emotional support to others. Besides, other than the direct predictive effect, state anxiety also predicted trait empathy in terms of distance to the outbreak epicentre. Contrary to our hypothesis according to the PTE, an infectious pandemic disease indeed frustrated people near the epicentre more than people in regions farther away. Nevertheless, the moderation analysis indicated that distance predicted trait empathy post-outbreak. Unfortunately, as our results suggested, we did not learn that people far from the outbreak epicentre show different prosocial inclinations from the near population, even though they had the same empathy level. As the COVID-19 questions in dataset 2 (post-outbreak) suggested, people in the near region reported patients to receive more stigmatization and rejection from others. Stigma from others was a major theme throughout the literature43,44, and it may be a long-lasting issue, even after the outbreak is under control. Therefore, compared to the far distance regions, people may experience a heavier burden of psychological stress in the near
distance region. In terms of the effects that anxiety imposed on empathy during the outbreak, the direction was inverse to what is suggested by the PTE or ripple effect. The trait empathy in people near the epicentre declined faster as state anxiety grew, while in people outside the epicentre trait empathy did not change significantly when personal anxiety increased.
Whenever a major event occurs, all kinds of information can be mixed, especially novel,
eye-catching information with some degree of uncertainty. Admittedly, the nature of the media will make this type of information get more attention in more exaggerated ways1, and the news is still controlling our knowledge of the situation. It's always about breaking down the audience's defences and making every disaster feel worse than it is45. When watching a lot of news regarding topics such as disasters, illness, and homelessness, people experience symptoms similar to compassion fatigue, such as depression and anxiety to varying degrees46. Under the current barrage of information, we also verified compassion fatigue in our study, protecting people from burnout47. If empathy and compassion produce motivation, but there is no practical way of action, people will inevitably feel more anxious and miserable, which will further influence pro-sociality48. At a time when compassion fatigue is emerging, we may need to re-examine our psychological capacity and the environment around us. We have been amazed at how much technology has changed and connected us; however, in this rapidly changing world, there is only so much each of us can do. Instead of soaking oneself in the deluge of online emotions, one should need proper ways to do with compassion and empathy. Additionally, it is important to distract oneself from the anxiety-provoking pictures and headlines, and not simply retweet emotion-laden tweets (good or bad), but instead truly communicate, discuss, and analyse with others.
The present study has several limitations. First, data were obtained by self-report from a
sample that was not fully randomly distribute. Second, the participants were in isolation period during the second assessment. Third, we could not formally evaluate the specific psychometric properties of our questionnaire on the psychological effects of COVID-19. Fourth, due to the
anonymous nature of the data collection, we could not pair individuals at the two-time intervals. Fifth, using a dichotomous distance variable, the possible influence of a continuous geographical position was not explored. Sixth, even though a large sample was used in the study, the difference in IRI subscales between the two periods might have been caused by the unpaired sample that was actually systematically different. Besides, the slightly difference components of the data made it difficult to further examine the contrast between the two time stages.
To some extent, this study explains how individuals’ prosocial willingness changed pre-
and post- outbreak. The study provides a new perspective on how trait empathy can decrease pro-sociality behaviours. Empathy allows us to engage in more prosocial behaviours. However, being over-exposed to information generates anxiety, which dampens our prosocial motivation. Caring for disadvantaged people is conducive to resolving social contradictions, manifesting morality, easing conflict situations, and promoting harmonious social development14. As the basis of human social cooperation and progress, prosocial behaviour needs to be promoted and practiced in an organized way as a highlight point in psychological health education.
We all want to be kind-hearted people during a crisis; however, indifference is often
produced by news reports. As an energy-consuming ability, our care workers are especially experiencing the overconsumption of their own empathy and feeling much more stressed because of close contact with patients’ death over and over24. Thus, mental health services should be readily available for certain medical care workers worldwide.
To sum up, we aimed to investigate the effect of being chronically worried about the threat
of diseases on engagement in trait empathy, adaptive empathy, or prosocial behavioural
tendency, especially when diseases are particularly salient such as an outbreak. The
preconditions for intervention lay on the knowledge of changes in psychological states and the
potential mechanisms. For example, it is necessary to raise awareness about the potential
damage to mental health that over-exposure to information during the outbreak can cause. Thus,
it is important to distract oneself from the anxiety-provoking pictures and headlines. Future interventions to help people manage their emotions during public health crises are worthy of attention.
Methods

content.heading: Participants
content.text:
The first dataset (539 participants, 274 females, Mage = 28.43, SD = 7.84) was collected
before the emerging infectious disease outbreak of COVID-19 (2019.11.21~2019.11.23), while the second dataset (570 participants, 366 females, Mage = 25.08, SD = 8.75) was collected during the peak period of public concern about COVID-19 (2020.2.23~2020.2.24). We distributed the task and questionnaires on an online platform. As Table 1 shows, in pre- and post-outbreak, the groups were unevenly distributed in terms of age (t(1088)=6.64, P<0.001) and gender (χ2=14.89, P<0.001). Hence, when we compared the response variables cross the timepoint, we controlled for age and gender as possible confounding variables. Stimuli
The stimuli consisted of 12 video clips portraying actors telling either the truth or lies
about the pain induced by electric shocks. Twelve participants in Beijing (six females and six males, Mage = 22.4) were recruited as actors for video recording. All actors were asked to either express their true feelings about pain (electric shock pain) or lie when they were not really experiencing pain.
In the real pain scenario (i.e. telling the truth about their pain), participants were asked to
express and describe their genuine feelings of pain evoked by the electric shock induction approach. The electric shock approach is a commonly used pain induction method, in which an electric shock is delivered to the participants fingers.
In the fake pain scenario (i.e. lying about the pain), the participants were asked to pretend
to have been shocked and to describe those fake feelings. The actors in the fake pain scenario had been sitting in the room and watched videos of people getting electric shocks, but they
were not shocked personally. The research paradigm was approved by the China Academy of Science ethics committee, and all performers in the video recording gave informed consent to participate in the study. Online study task
Figure 1 illustrates the present study components in both the first and second online study
tasks. Video rating task
Twelve video clips (six genuine pain and six vicarious pain) were presented to the
participants in randomized order. After each video clip played, the participants judged whether the actors actually received electric shocks (choose ‘1’ if it is true, choose ‘2’ if it is not). Then, the participants were asked to rate (choose form ‘1’ = ‘None’ to ‘7’ = ‘very much’ ) ‘how much pain do you think the person felt?’ , followed by ‘how much pain you feel when you are watching this video clip?’, and ‘how much would you like to decrease the pain of this person?' There was no time limit to provide feedback, and the next video was played after all the ratings were completed. After watching and rating all 12 videos, participants completed a questionnaire. Questionnaires
The participants completed the IRI questionnaire at the end of the online task. The IRI is
a widely used scale to measure individual differences in empathy. It captures four separate aspects: Perspective Taking, Fantasy, Empathic Concern, and Personal Distress49. Participants rated how well each of the 28 statements in the IRI described their feelings on a scale ranging from ‘1 = totally not agree’ to ‘5 = totally agree’. The Cronbach's coefficient of the questionnaire in this study was 0.71.
Further, regarding the effect of quarantine, participants were asked to complete the
Autism-spectrum Quotient (AQ) 50,51, which has been used to assess autism spectrum disorder in adults52. The Cronbach's coefficient of the questionnaire in this study was 0.38.
Note that there were some differences in the questionnaires that were administered in the
second study given that it took place during the peak period of public concern about the coronavirus. Specifically, the second online task included the STAI to capture both the participants’ trait anxiety and state anxiety components53. The Cronbach's coefficient of the questionnaire in this study was 0.94. Moreover, an 18-item questionnaire about the emerging COVID-19 outbreak was included (Fig. 5, Fig. S10, more details in supplementary material). Demographic information
After the questionnaire session, participants were asked to provide demographic
information including location, age, gender, etc. Statistical analysis
A total of 520 and 570 participants in the first and second dataset, respectively, were
included in the final analysis. Nineteen participants with missing values of demographic information (three participants did not provide age data and 16 participants did not provide distance information calculated by IP) were removed from the final analysis.
Data were analysed using SPSS 25.0 statistical software (IBM Corp., Armonk, NY) and
R. Based on the hypotheses of the research, descriptive analysis were first conducted in SPSS. For the data characteristics comparison between the two datasets (pre vs. post-outbreak), group comparisons of nominal variables were analysed using the chi-square test, and independent samples t-tests were used to compare group differences (pre vs. post groups). Linear regression analysis exploration and correlation analysis were executed using R function lm() and cor.test(). As for model construction, mediation and moderation models were computed with PROCESS 3.4 in SPSS and R packages MeMoBootR for serial moderated mediation model. Data availability
The data supporting the findings of this study are available from the https://osf.io/9bgkt/
Code Availability
The code that supported the findings of this study is available from the https://osf.io/9bgkt/

content.text:
In the United States, widespread hostility towards Asian-Americans has unfortunately seemed to define a large component of Americans' response to the Coronavirus pandemic. Utilizing Google Trends data, I examine how sentiment towards minority racial groups has been affected by the Coronavirus pandemic. I find strong evidence that Coronavirus had caused an increase in anti-Chinese sentiment, but surprisingly I find that it has caused an even greater increase in anti-Hispanic sentiment. I discuss why this may be and also present evidence that Coronavirus has resulted in discrimination towards Chinese and Mexican
restaurants.
Trigger Warning: The following document contains racial epithets.

content.heading: Introduction
content.text:
The COVID-19, or Coronavirus, pandemic originated in Wuhan, China, in
late 2019. While for several months, the majority of cases were found in China, the virus has since moved to the United States, where at the time of this publication, there are nearly 100,000 confirmed cases. (Centers for Disease Control) Many occurrences of Anti-Asian hate crimes have been reported in the recent timeframe, with it generally being considered that the awareness of the notion that Coronavirus originated in China has led to an increase in anti-Chinese or antiAsian sentiment among Americans. In this paper, I utilize Google Trends data to examine the impact of Coronavirus on American's attitudes towards other racial groups. I find that Coronavirus has led to an increase in anti-Chinese and antiHispanic sentiment, with the effect of Coronavirus on anti-Hispanic sentiment larger than the effect on anti-Chinese sentiment. I attribute this effect to Americans’ tendency to perceive the threat associated with Coronavirus as representative of the larger notion of threat from immigrant's or foreign-born people not specifically from individuals of Chinese or Asian descent, the fact that Hispanic Americans making up a core group within the perceived immigrant out-group and that Americans tended to have more negative opinions of Hispanic Americans prior. I additionally find some evidence that anti-black sentiment has fallen in response to the Coronavirus pandemic, though this evidence is weak and mostly unclear in terms of the mechanisms at play. Finally, I find substantial evidence that Chinese and Mexican restaurants have been discriminatorily affected by the Coronavirus pandemic.

content.heading: Coronavirus
content.text:
Various anecdotes support the notion that racism and anti-Chinese
sentiment has increased directly in response to the Coronavirus pandemic. Many
incidents were publicized in the media or caught on video and featured widely on social media. In an incident in Manhattan, an individual yelled, "Where is your Corona mask you Asian b*tch?" at a Korean woman before punching and attacking her, dislocating her jaw. (ABC7 News) There were various instances reported similar to this, in which individuals of Asian descent were subjected to blatant
bigotry with perpetrators explicitly citing Coronavirus as their motive.
Further, large institutions alike have perpetrated anti-Chinese sentiment in
their messages. For example, UC-Berkeley's University Health Services published a document that stated that "Xenophobia: fears about interacting with those who might be from Asia and guilt about these feelings" is an acceptable response to the Coronavirus pandemic. (Asmelah 2020) Such a bigoted statement coming from such a place of high authority demonstrates the scale and pervasiveness of the xenophobic reaction to Coronavirus. Asian-Americans have also experienced plain discrimination in the wake of the Coronavirus pandemic. In Indiana, two HmongAmerican men were rejected from two hotels after reportedly the hotel staff thought the men might have had Coronavirus, presumably a discriminatory assumption
made based on their race. (Nottingham and Alsup 2020)
Trump's rhetoric related to Coronavirus has also been called racist and has
been accused of inciting racism against Chinese and Asian Americans, based on Trump's tendency to refer to Coronavirus as the "Chinese virus" and on other occasions simply the "foreign virus". This has been met with considerable controversy. Undoubtedly, it would seem that such language would lead to Coronavirus being more strongly associated with China and Asia than would be otherwise, which presumably could have an impact on how Chinese and Asian
Americans are treated.
Evidence has shown that commerce at Chinese businesses has fallen
substantially since the onset of the Coronavirus pandemic. It is commonly thought that this decline is due to the Americans' perceived association between Asian Americans and Coronavirus, in response to Coronavirus originating from and
initially primarily spreading in China. The New York City government cited an estimate that sales at Chinese businesses have fallen 40% within the city. (City of
New York)

content.heading: Xenophobia in the United States
content.text:
Integrated Threat Theory describes the circumstances and dynamics which
tend to produce prejudice, discrimination, and hostility towards identity groups. (Stephan and Stephan 2000) Integrated Threat Theory attributes prejudice towards out-groups to realistic threats, which are threats to the group's well-being, and symbolic threats, which are distinctions in the values of the in-group and out-group. There are additional factors that may influence the extent by which threat is perceived. The power dynamics between groups play a substantial role, as larger or higher-power groups may pose a greater perceived threat, additionally higher-power groups may have stronger reactions to perceived threats. (Corenblum and Stephen
2001, Stephan et al 2009)
Besides Asian Americans, another racial minority group typically subjected
to a high degree a large scale of Xenophobia in recent years in the United States has been Hispanic Americans. While there were large numbers of hate crimes against both Hispanic Americans and Asian Americans, in 2018 there were nearly four times as many against Hispanic Americans compared to Asian Americans. (Uniform Crime Reports 2018) Compared to Hispanic or Black Americans, Asian Americans are often viewed more favorably by White Americans. (Wong et al 1998) Asian Americans are less likely to report experiencing discrimination/hostility in specific
ways. (Pew Research Center)
Trump has increasingly used anti-Mexican and anti-Hispanic rhetoric
throughout his 2016 Presidential Campaign and subsequent presidency, at times referring to Mexicans as criminals and/or rapists. (Reilly 2016) His rhetoric has generally indicated he believes Mexican immigrants are threatening to the well-
being United States, threatening national safety and security and economic health. Most Hispanic Americans report the situation for Hispanic Americans has worsened since Trump took office. (Pew Research Center 2018) Trump's rise to power has generally led to a substantial increase in hate crimes in the United States. (Edwards 2018)
Group Threat theory hypothesizes that prejudice towards out-groups is
positively correlated with the relative size of the out-group. (Blalock 1967) Research has found that the level of Hispanic immigration in an area is correlated with increases in the rate of Hispanic hate-crime victimization in that area. (Stacey et al. 2011) Additional research has found that Hispanic hate-crime victimization is highest in white neighborhoods with recently growing Hispanic populations. (Green et al. 1998) Generally, violent Hate Crimes against Hispanic Americans have been rising substantially over recent years, increasing 300% between 2011 and 2012
alone. (Bureau of Justice Statistics)
Coronavirus has triggered national insecurity, fear of foreigners, and general
Xenophobia. Various anti-Asian hate crimes and incidents related to the Coronavirus pandemic demonstrate the common theme: Americans feel threatened by immigrants and/or individuals they perceive may be immigrants. In the case of Coronavirus, this has resulted in individuals racially discriminating against individuals that they perceive as potential carriers of Coronavirus as well as generally expressing hostility and violence towards the Asian race for being to blame for Coronavirus as they see it. Beyond these blatant actions, however, I hypothesize that Coronavirus will stimulate an increase in Xenophobic attitudes broadly in Americans. Since Americans recently have tended to manifest their Xenophobic attitudes in the way of hostility and discrimination towards Hispanic Americans, I hypothesize that Coronavirus will not only cause an increase in AntiAsian sentiment, as has been supported by anecdotal evidence, but that anti-
Hispanic sentiment will increase as well.
Spatially, I would expect that places with higher proportions of Asian
Americans to have higher increases in Xenophobic sentiment, since Integrated Threat theory hypothesizes that larger groups are perceived as more threatening. Thus, in the context of a new perceived threat, I would expect prejudice to rise the most in places with the largest populations of the perceived threatening out-group. In regards to Hispanic Americans, I would expect places with higher levels of antiHispanic sentiment to begin with to experience the largest increases in antiHispanic sentiment, since a large component of anti-Hispanic sentiment generally has to do with the perception that the group consists largely of immigrants, the population in these places tend to likely already be sensitive to perceived threats from out-groups with large immigrant/foreign-born populations, and thus are primed to respond to threats from immigrant or foreign-born populations with anti-
Hispanic sentiment.
From an additional point of view, evidence also supports the hypothesis that
racism/hatred towards other racial minority groups may fall in response to rising anti-Asian sentiment. Past research has additionally shown an inverse relationship between how White Americans view Asian Americans and how they view African Americans. (Ho and Jackson 2001) Ho and Jackson (2001) found that White subjects that had more favorable stereotypes of Asian Americans tended to have subsequent less favorable stereotypes of African Americans, they attributed this finding to the notion that the groups are viewed in contrast to one another. Additionally, it is possible increasing media focus and attention on Coronavirus and Asian Americans may subsequently reduce the salience of and attention on AfricanAmericans, a "distraction" of sorts. Since African-Americans are generally viewed as Americans and not stereotyped as immigrants or viewed as a group with a large foreign-born population, I would not expect Coronavirus to have any type of positive effect on bigoted/racist attitudes towards African-Americans in the way that it would on Asian-Americans or Hispanic-Americans, and instead would in total
expect a slight negative effect.

content.heading: Methods
content.text:
Stephens-Davidowitz (2013) created a method for spatially-proxying an area's
level of anti-black racial sentiment. His proxy for anti-black sentiment rests in the proportion of searches for a particular black slur that starts with “n”, and ends with “er”. Stephens-Davidowitz controls for the proportion of searches for another variation of the racial slur that ends in “a” and is commonly used in rap songs, "african american" (in order to control for some areas simply having higher interest in African-Americans) and a particular swear word (to simply control for the fact that some areas simply having higher interest in expletives). Stephens-Davidowitz found the proxy to be significantly-correlated with other spatial measures of
racism/bigotry towards Black Americans.
To measure anti-black sentiment, I will follow the same method Stephens-
Davidowitz utilized. To measure anti-Chinese sentiment, I will be examining the proportion of searches for a specific racial epithet used to describe a person of Chinese descent. To measure anti-Hispanic sentiment, I will similarly be examining the proportion of searches for a specific racial epithet used to describe a Hispanic person. Following in line with Stephens-Davidowitz's methodology, I will also be controlling for the search rate for "chinese american" and "hispanic american"
respectively, and the proxy search rate for profanity. (See models in Appendix)
Additionally, I will also measure the relationship between "coronavirus"
searches and "chinese food" and "mexican food" and "chinese restaurant(s)" and "mexican restaurant/restaurant(s)" google searches controlling for "food" and "restaurant(s)" searches respectively and "coronavirus" searches for both. This operationalizes the discriminatory impact of the Coronavirus pandemic on people's
relative interest in Chinese and Mexican restaurants.
Temporally, I will examine the timeframe from December 24th, 2019 to
March 24th, 2020, a 90-day timeframe, looking at day-by-day search rates. This
timeframe is broad enough to contain dates in which the search rate frequency was extremely low (less than 1% of what it was at its peak in the timeframe) but specific enough to minimize the risk of confounding variables. Spatially, I will look at current search rates with states as my geographical level of analysis over the 30- day period February 24th to March 24th, 2020. Spatially, I control for past search rates, utilizing the period September 23th, 2019 to December 23rd, 2019, again focusing on utilizing a recent enough timeframe to minimize the risk of confounding variables, but long ago enough for interest in Coronavirus to be minimal/irrelevant, as well as for there to be no overlap between that date range and the date range I
utilize for my temporal analysis.

content.heading: Results and Discussion
content.text:
Temporally, I find evidence that days with higher search rates for
Coronavirus had higher search rates for anti-Chinese and anti-Hispanic slurs, even controlling for variation in search rates for "chinese american" and "hispanic american" respectively as well as the search rate for profanity. Table One shows the model for anti-Hispanic sentiment, while Table Two shows the model for antiChinese sentiment. I find the effect of daily search rates for Coronavirus actually to have a significantly larger effect on search rates for anti-Hispanic slurs than antiChinese slurs. I find no evidence that the daily search rate for Coronavirus has a
significant effect on search rates anti-black slurs.
Temporally, I additionally find some evidence that Coronavirus has
discriminatorily affected search rates for Chinese and Mexican cuisine. As Table Five and Six show, the effect of search rates for Coronavirus on search rates for "chinese food" and "mexican food" are both negative and significant, approximately the same size. As Table Four shows, I find no significant negative effect of search rates for Coronavirus on search rates for "chinese restaurant/restaurants". I do find a slight negative effect of search rate for Coronavirus on search rates for "Mexican
restaurant/restaurants", again highlighting the seriousness of Coronavirus on anti-
Mexican and, by association, anti-Hispanic discrimination.
Spatially, I find a positive interactive effect between the local Coronavirus
search rate and prior anti-Hispanic sentiment on present anti-Hispanic sentiment. In other words, as expected, Coronavirus presumably primed individuals with high levels of anti-Hispanic sentiment already to expand on that sentiment and hatred. I find a negative interaction between the percent Asian in a state and the Coronavirus search rate and anti-Chinese sentiment. There is a strong positive effect of percent Asian as a constant, however, indicating that there may not be enough variation in public interest in Coronavirus as proxied by Coronavirus search rates from state to state for noticeable variation in increases in anti-Chinese sentiment to arise, but that generally, the Coronavirus pandemic has increased anti-Chinese sentiment more greatly in states with larger Asian-American
populations.
Notably, I find evidence that anti-black sentiment has decreased more in
states with higher search rates for Coronavirus. As Table Ten shows, controlling for differences in anti-Chinese and anti-Hispanic sentiment mediates much of this effect, though not in the way I hypothesized. I find that differences in anti-Chinese and anti-Hispanic sentiment are positively correlated with differences in anti-black sentiment. Thus, the negative effect of Coronavirus on anti-black sentiment cannot be attributed to Coronavirus's positive effect on anti-Chinese and anti-Hispanic
sentiment.
Spatially, I find evidence that state-to-state variation in interest in
Coronavirus as proxied by Coronavirus search rate, has a negative effect on search rate for "chinese restaurant/restaurants" as indicated by Table Eleven. I additionally find an interacting negative effect between search rates for "coronavirus" and differences in anti-Chinese sentiment on search rates for "chinese food" thus specifically implicating anti-Chinese sentiment in discrimination against Chinese restaurants. I otherwise do not find any significant effects of Coronavirus
interest spatially in interest in Chinese or Mexican cuisine. I again believe this may be somewhat attributable to the lack of substantial variation in interest Coronavirus between states in the US. The state with the least interest in Coronavirus still had 68% of the level of interest as of the state with the most interest.
To summarize, I find evidence that Coronavirus has increased anti-Hispanic
and anti-Chinese sentiment. I find some evidence that anti-black sentiment has fallen in response to Coronavirus, though this evidence is weaker, and the mechanisms remain unclear. I additionally find evidence that both Chinese and Mexican restaurants have been discriminatorily impacted by the Coronavirus pandemic. Broadly, the most insightful finding of this paper is that despite not being a racial group broadly perceived to be associated with Coronavirus, Hispanic Americans are faced with substantial increases in bigoted sentiment towards their racial/ethnic group, possibly even larger than the effect towards Chinese/AsianAmericans. From an Integrated Threat Theory point of view, this demonstrates an instance in which an in-group's perceived threat from an out-group has been
responded to with prejudice towards a distinct out-group.
