Fig. 2. Regression tables for predicting intentions to disseminate COVID-19 conspiracy theories. National narcissism remains a significant predictor of intentions to disseminate COVID-19 conspiracy theories when adjusting for several covariates (including national identification, dissemination intentions of conspiracy theories unrelated to CVID-19, and dissemination intentions of true facts about COVID19). Regression tables are displayed for Study 1 [a] and Study 2 [b].
Dissemination patterns. Next, we explored whether people high in national narcissism
gravitate towards specific social media platforms to share their beliefs online. When we asked participants where they would post about the presented statements, the majority of participants chose Facebook (40.3% in Study 1 and 67% in Study 2). Multinomial logistic regressions
revealed that national narcissism predicted which platform participants intended to use (Study 1: 𝛘2(6) = 12.88, p = .045, Nagelkerke R2 = .05 ; Study 2: 𝛘2(8) = 20.77, p = .008, Nagelkerke R2 = .03).
Participants scoring high in national narcissism were especially likely to gravitate
towards Facebook for spreading their opinions. To formally test this observation, we re-coded platform choice into a binary variable (Facebook = 1, other online platforms = 0). We conducted a binomial logistic regression to predict Facebook choice as a function of national narcissism. Stronger national narcissism was related to a greater likelihood to choose Facebook over other popular social media platforms for sharing posts (Study 1: B = .24, SE = .12, Wald 𝛘2(1) = 3.94, p = .047, eB = 1.27 CI95(eB) = [1.00, 1.61], Nagelkerke R2 = .02; Study 2: B = .46, SE = .12, Wald 𝛘2(1) = 14.69, p < .001, eB= 1.59, CI95(eB) = [1.25, 2.01], Nagelkerke R2 = .05). In Study 1, we further found that national narcissism was associated with the likelihood to choose to post about a conspiracy theory related to COVID-19 over a conspiracy theory unrelated to COVID-19 (B = .34, SE = .13 Wald 𝛘2(1) = 6.51, p = .011, eB = 1.40 CI95(eB) = [1.08, 1.82], Nagelkerke R2 = .03).
Health-related behavior and attitudes. Study 2 additionally tested whether national narcissism and belief in COVID-19 conspiracy theories were linked to health-related behavior and attitudes. More specifically, we examined participants’ engagement in handwashing and social distancing, and their support for public-policies mitigating the spread of COVID-19. Recent research suggests that self-reported social distancing is highly correlated with actual social distancing behavior30. The data were negatively skewed. On average, participants reported very high
engagement in handwashing and social distancing and strong support for the presented publicpolicies.
For our analyses on conspiracy theories, we grouped our COVID-19 conspiracy theories
into two categories: (a) Denial – the COVID-19 pandemic is a hoax; and (b) Deflection – the COVID-19 pandemic is created and/or spread by a powerful group of people. In the light of recent work32 we were open to the possibility that these different types of conspiracy theories would be associated with different health-related behavior and attitudes and conducted separate analyses for these two types of conspiracy theories.
We first explored belief in COVID-19 conspiracy theories as the predictor of behavioral
intentions. We found that the belief in Denial conspiracy theories was only marginally related to handwashing (B = .10, SE = .06, t(635) = 1.68, p = .093, CI95 = [-.02, .22], adjusted R2 = .003) but was linked to less social distancing (B = -.26, SE = .05, t(635) = -5.41, p < .001, CI95 = [-.35, -.16], adjusted R2 = .043) and lower public-policy support (B = -.27, SE = .05, t(635) = -5.86, p < .001, CI95 = [-.36, .18], adjusted R2 = .050). Belief in Deflection conspiracy theories was related to handwashing (B = .10, SE = .04, t(635) = 2.45, p = .014, CI95 = [.02, .17], adjusted R2 = .008) and linked to less social distancing (B = -.15, SE = .03, t(635) = -4.96, p < .001, CI95 = [-.21, - .09] , adjusted R2 = .036) and lower public-policy support (B = -.14, SE = .03, t(635) = -4.76, p < .001, CI95 = [-.20, -.08], adjusted R2 = .033). Together, both types of COVID-19 conspiracy theory beliefs (Denial and Deflection) were negatively associated with social distancing and public-policy support. Belief in Deflection conspiracy theories was additionally positively associated with handwashing.
Next we turned to national narcissism as a predictor and found that it was positively
associated with handwashing (B = .13, SE = .04, t(635) = 3.70, p < .001, CI95 = [.06, .20],
adjusted R2 = .020) but did not predict social distancing (B = -.04, SE = .03, t(635) = -1.29, p = .198, CI95 = [-.09, .02] , adjusted R2 = .001) or public-policy support (B = -.04, SE = .03, t(635) = -1.26, p = .209, CI95 = [-.09, .02], adjusted R2 = .001).
We tested whether the relationship between national narcissism and handwashing is
mediated by greater belief in conspiracy theories. We probed a parallel mediation model in which we specified national narcissism as the predictor, belief in the two types of conspiracy theories as the mediators, and handwashing as the outcome. We found no evidence of a mediation (BDenial = .003, SE = .01, CI95 = [-.01, .02] ; BDeflection = .01, SE .01, CI95 = [-.01, .04]; both 5000 bootstrap samples). The relationship between national narcissism and handwashing appeared to be independent of belief in COVID-19 conspiracy theories.

content.heading: Discussion
content.text:
Across two studies in different countries, we found a strong and robust relationship between national narcissism and COVID-19 conspiracy theories. National narcissism was associated with stronger belief in COVID-19 conspiracy theories. Further, national narcissism was linked to greater intentions to disseminate COVID-19 conspiracy theories online, which was mediated by greater belief in these theories. We also found that people scoring higher in national narcissism were more inclined to post about conspiracy theories related to COVID-19 than conspiracy theories unrelated to the virus (Study 1) and preferred Facebook over other social networks for sharing their beliefs (Study 1 & 2). We also found that belief in COVID-19 conspiracy theories and national narcissism were related to certain health-related behaviors and attitudes. These findings provide important and novel insights for research on conspiracy theories and national identity and may also hold practical relevance.
Our study expands previous work on conspiracy theories related to public-health crises
by examining the role identity processes might play in fostering the spread of these theories. We argued that existential threats of public-health crises may extend to the social self by threatening in-group image (for an overview of identity processes during public-health crises, see ref. 33). We found that insecure and defensive national identification – national narcissism – was a powerful predictor of the spread of conspiracy theories during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Critically, we accounted for a number of variables which could potentially confound the
relationship between national narcissism and belief in COVID-19 conspiracy theories. We isolated the belief in COVID-19 conspiracy theories from factual knowledge about the pandemic (Study 2) and the tendency to judge nonsensical information as profound (i.e., bullshit receptivity29, Study 1). To our knowledge, we are the first to provide direct empirical evidence that these concepts are not identical (for a theoretical distinction, see ref. 34). Notably, we also found that high national narcissism was related to greater belief in COVID-19 conspiracy theories even after adjusting for participants’ tendency to believe conspiracy theories in general and that it was further linked to a preference for posting about conspiracy theories particular relating (vs. not relating) to COVID-19 (Study 1). These results suggest that conspiracy theories related to COVID-19 are psychologically distinctive from other conspiracy theories and false beliefs. While we are cautious to draw strong conclusions from such correlational findings, we interpret these results as preliminary evidence that conspiracy theories related to a public-health crisis may have unique psychological functions during such crises. One function may be the reinforcement of an idealistic national image.
Our study adds to the burgeoning research on the spread of misinformation and
conspiracy theories online (e.g., refs. 6,27). Vast work exists on who believes in conspiracy
theories (see refs. 14,15) and how conspiracy theories spread on a system level (e.g., refs. 7,35,36). Less is known about who spreads conspiracy theories, particularly during public-health crises. We identified national narcissism as a risk factor that might contribute to the dissemination of conspiracy theories online. Exploratory analyses in both studies found that Facebook was the most popular platform to share one’s beliefs – especially – amongst people high in national narcissism. While more work is needed to replicate and extend our findings to real online sharing, this finding might eventually offer guidance in how to allocate resources for the fight against misinformation.
Our findings also advance research on collective narcissism. For instance, research on
collective narcissism has mainly focused on how belief in conspiracy theories implicating outgroups constitutes a strategy to manage inter-group conflicts (e.g., ref. 21). Our work provided initial evidence that during a pandemic people high in national narcissism seem to be drawn to conspiracy theories specifically about this pandemic, potentially to manage induced national image threat. These results suggest that, in the sphere of collective narcissism, public-health crises may evoke psychological processes analogous to inter-group threats. This may suggest that conspiracy theory beliefs are a generalized maladaptive ingroup defense strategy amongst people high in collective narcissism. Our research also provides evidence that the relationship between national narcissism and belief in conspiracy theories mediates intentions to disseminate these theories. This finding may inform how collective narcissism advances societal movements including neo-fascist political movements (for a review, see ref. 37).
Our results suggest that the belief in COVID-19 conspiracy theories was associated with
lower engagement in social distancing and support for public-policies. For handwashing, we found that behavioral intentions diverged based on the specific types of COVID-19 conspiracy
theories. While belief in Deflection conspiracy theories (i.e., the virus was intentionally created and/or spread) was related to greater engagement in handwashing, belief in Denial conspiracy theories (i.e., the pandemic is a hoax) was unrelated to handwashing. These results dovetail with previous work linking conspiracy theory beliefs to distrust of authorities (refs. 31,41), noncompliance with social norms (refs. 39,40), and a stronger need for control and agency31. Social distancing and public-policies related to COVID-19 require social cooperation and the compliance with norms and government orders (see ref. 33). In contrast, handwashing is often private and self-guided. While there are many ways to interpret these results, we speculate that participants with stronger belief in COVID-19 conspiracy theories were more hesitant to adhere to social distancing guidelines and to support related public-policies in part because both were prescribed by authorities. Yet, those of them who were still aware of the threat posed by COVID19 were nevertheless receptive for health guidelines that maintained a sense of agency (handwashing).
Similarly, we found that national narcissism was positively associated with handwashing
but did not correlate with social distancing and support for public policies. These results may reflect greater autonomy concerns associated with collective narcissism42. To the extent that handwashing is a convenient, self-protection measure while the adherence to social distancing and public-policies is rather inconvenient yet protects the community, our results are also consistent with recent work showing that collective narcissism is linked to prioritizing one’s personal needs42,43 and the protection of the ingroup’s image over the care and loyalty for fellow citizens 20,44,45.
We would like to stress that all results are correlational. Though we suspect that national
narcissism motivates the belief in COVID-19 conspiracy theories and translates into health-
related behaviors and attitudes than the reverse, more work is needed to justify such a conclusion. We should also note that beliefs in conspiracy theories were quite low, on average. As such, our work is best understood as examining people who depart from a norm of skepticism towards conspiracy theories. Further, our results are specific to the context of COVID-19. It remains an open question whether these results generalize across different types and times of public-health crises. At the same time, we believe that studying the spread of medical conspiracy theories during an actual pandemic also adds unique value to our work and may offer insights into a particularly dangerous moment for the spread of misinformation.

content.heading: Conclusion
content.text: Ultimately, we hope that our studies are not only relevant for researchers but also for practitioners. Yet, little is known about how to increase or decrease the link between collective narcissism and conspiracy theories. Therefore, we urge future research to examine if focusing on the protection of the national image influences the spread of COVID-19 conspiracy theories, and the implications of these associations for public-health communication. For instance, underscoring that the national in-group is in some way disadvantaged in fighting the pandemic might increase the need to assert the image of the group and further fuel conspiracy theories49. Conversely, public-health messages might benefit from stressing that the adherence to health guidelines and policies also helps protect the nation’s image. Exploring such and other interventions could help limit the current ‘infodemic’1.

content.heading: Methods
content.text:
Samples. Study 1 was exploratory using an ad-hoc sample of 300 U.S. participants recruited between 10th and 12th of March, 2020. The sample was nationally representative for age, gender, and race of an adult population (146 female, 144 male, 3 other; 25 Asian, 47 Black or African American, 200 White, 21 other; MAge= 44.41, SDAge= 16.11). Seven participants failed our attention check and were excluded from the analyses. The total sample size was 293. We conducted a post-hoc sensitivity analysis in which we specified the number of tested predictors as one (national narcissism) and total number of tested predictors as four (national narcissism plus three adjustment variables: national identification, belief/dissemination intentions of conspiracy theories unrelated to COVID-19; bullshit receptivity). Alpha was set to .05 and power to .80. With these parameters, our sample size was sensitive to detect an effect size of f2 = .027.
Study 2 served as a conceptual replication. We recruited a sample of 650 U.K.
participants on April 28, 2020 (440 female, 193 male, 4 other; 15 Asian, 11 Black or African American, 589 White, 22 other; MAge= 37.20, SDAge= 12.40). The sample was balanced in its ideological beliefs approximated by a 50-50 split in participants who voted Leave versus Remain in the “Brexit” referendum. Data of two participants was deleted due to missing consent. Eleven participants failed the attention check and were excluded from all analyses. The total sample size was 637. We conducted a post-hoc sensitivity analysis in which we specified the number of tested predictors as one (national narcissism) and total number of tested predictors as three (national narcissism plus two adjustment variables: national identification, knowledge/dissemination of true facts about COVID-19). Alpha was set to .05 and power to .80. With these parameters, our sample size was sensitive to detect an effect size of f2 = .012. Study 2 was pre-registered (osf.io/7vjr2). For the exploratory measurements (i.e., dissemination behavior,
health-related behaviors and attitudes), we pre-registered the analysis plan but were agnostic to the results. For all other analyses, we pre-registered analysis plans and predictions. Note that our initial, pre-registered analyses in Study 2 distinguished between belief in conspiracy theories claiming that the COVID-19 pandemic is a hoax (Denial conspiracy theories) and conspiracy theories claiming that COVID-19 is created and/or spread by a powerful group of people (Deflection conspiracy theories). Both types showed similar patterns in their relationships with national narcissism and we report aggregated results. Separate analyses and results are reported in the supplementary.
In both studies, we observed no outliers, defined as participants whose responses to the
dependent variables exceeded 3 standard deviations above or below the mean. Further, in both studies, the patterns of results did not change when we analyzed all participants.

content.heading: Procedure and Measurements.
content.text:
Belief and Dissemination Intentions. In both studies, participants read a series of statements and rated their agreement (1 = strongly disagree to 5 = strongly agree in Study 1; 1 = not at all to 5 = very much in Study 2) and dissemination intentions (1 = not at all to 5 = very much in Study 1 & Study 2) for each of them.
In Study 1, participants read two conspiracy theories related to the COVID-19 pandemic.
One conspiracy theory claimed that the pandemic was a hoax (COVID-19 pandemic is exaggerated by the media to hurt the Trump administration) and one conspiracy theory claimed that the pandemic was caused by humans (China created COVID-19 as a bioweapon). Participants also read eight conspiracy theories that were unrelated to the pandemic (e.g., 9/11 was an inside job). We averaged agreement with the two COVID-19 conspiracy theories to
create an index of the participant’s overall belief in COVID-19 conspiracy theories (r(291) = .45, M = 1.95, SD = 1.07). Intentions to disseminate the COVID-19 conspiracy theories were averaged to an index of the participant’s overall intentions to disseminate COVID-19 conspiracy theories (r(291) = .72, M = 2.14, SD = 1.41). Indices of belief and dissemination intentions concerning conspiracy theories unrelated to the COVID-19 pandemic were created correspondingly ( ɑBelief = .83, MBelief = 1.90, SDBelief = .77 ; ɑDissemination = .94, MDissemination= 2.07, SDDissemination = 1.19).
In Study 2, participants read seven conspiracy theories related to the COVID-19
pandemic. Two conspiracy theories claimed that the pandemic was a hoax (e.g., COVID-19 is a coverup for the harmful effects of 5G radiation), two conspiracy theories claimed that COVID19 was engineered by humans (e.g., COVID-19 is a bioweapon), and three conspiracy theories claimed that COVID-19 was intentionally spread by humans (e.g., the pharmaceutical industry spreads COVID-19 for financial gains). We grouped these conspiracy theories into two categories. The first two conspiracy theories were categorized as Denial conspiracy theories. The remaining five conspiracy theories were categorized as Deflection conspiracy theories. Participants also read three factual statements related to the COVID-19 pandemic. We created three different types of belief indices and three different types of dissemination indices for the COVID-19 conspiracy theories. First, we averaged agreement with all COVID-19 conspiracy theories to an index of the participant’s overall belief in COVID-19 conspiracy theories (ɑ = .85, M = 1.64, SD = .71) and averaged intentions to disseminate these theories to an index of the participant’s overall dissemination intentions of COVID-19 conspiracy theories (ɑ = .90, M = 1.31, SD = .62). Second, we averaged agreement with the two Denial conspiracy theories to an index of the participant’s overall belief in Denial conspiracy theories (r(635) = .57, M = 1.21,
SD = .54) and averaged intentions to disseminate these theories to an index of the participant’s overall dissemination intentions of Denial conspiracy theories (r(635) = .61, M = 1.16, SD = .53). Third, we averaged agreement with the five Deflection conspiracy theories to an index of the participant’s overall belief in Deflection conspiracy theories (Cronbach ɑ = .84, M = 1.82, SD = .84) and averaged intentions to disseminate these theories to an index of the participant’s overall dissemination intentions of Deflation conspiracy theories (Cronbach ɑ = .89, M = 1.37, SD = .71). Indices of belief and dissemination intentions concerning factual information about the COVID-19 pandemic were created correspondingly ( ɑBelief = .24, MBelief = 3.27, SDBelief = .76 ; ɑDissemination = .77, MDissemination = 1.89, SDDissemination = .99).
Across all belief and dissemination indices that we created, higher scores reflected
stronger manifestation of the measured construct (e.g., stronger belief in Deflection conspiracy theories). Notably, belief and dissemination intentions of COVID-19 conspiracy theories were on average very low in both studies.
Directly after responding to the statements, participants specified which online platform
they would choose if they were to post about these statements. Participants selected from a list of popular platforms (e.g., Facebook, Twitter, Reddit, “other”). In Study 2, they also had the option to choose “I don’t post things”. In Study 1, participants additionally saw a list of the conspiracy theories they just read and indicated which of the ideas they would be most likely to post about online. In both studies, we left it free to the participant whether their posts would be supporting or opposing the idea.
National narcissism. National narcissism was measured with a short 3-item version47 (ɑ =
.82, M = 2.10, SE = .99) of the Collective Narcissism Scale17 in Study 1 and the 5-item version46 (ɑ = .89, M = 2.32, SD = .92) in Study 2.
Additional measures for robustness analyses. We measured national identification using
a 1-item measure in Study 1 (I identify with being American; 48 M = 3.90, SD = 1.1849) and a 5- item measure in Study 2 (ɑ = .94, M = 3.54, SD = 1.03). Study 1 further administered a scale that captured people’s tendency to judge nonsensical information as profound (Bullshit Receptivity Scale29). This scale presents a number of nonsensical statements and asks participants to evaluate how “profound” each statement was (sample statement: Wholeness quiets infinite phenomena). Participants in both studies also responded to a series of demographic questions including age, gender, race, education, political ideology, and party support, and vote in the “Brexit” referendum (Study 2), and whether they or close others have been infected by COVID-19 (Study 2). Robustness analyses including these variables are reported in the supplementary.
Health-related behavior and attitudes. Study 2 included measures of participants’
engagement in health-related behaviors (handwashing and social distancing) and attitudes towards public-policies mitigating the spread of COVID-19. Participants read four scenarios. Two scenarios captured participants’ engagement in social distancing (e.g., going to a friend’s birthday party, reverse-coded) and two scenarios captured participants’ engagement in handwashing (e.g., washing hands before preparing a snack). For each scenario participants indicated how likely they were enacting a certain behavior (1 = definitely, 2 = probably not, 3 = maybe, 4 = probably, 5 = definitely not). In addition, participants indicated how often they washed their hands on an average week and how frequently they left the house for reasons other than grocery shopping, exercising, medical needs, and taking care of a pet (1 = not very frequently to 5 = very frequently). Responses to the handwashing scenarios and self-reported frequency of handwashing were averaged to an index of the participant’s engagement in handwashing (ɑ = .69, M = 4.17, SD = .82). Responses to the social distancing scenarios (both
reverse-coded) and self-reported frequency of non-compliance with social distancing guidelines (reverse-coded) were averaged to an index of the participant’s engagement in social distancing (ɑ = .46, M = 4.50, SD = .66). Further, we presented participants four public-policies currently in place in the U.K. to limit the spread of COVID-19 (e.g., closed schools). Participants indicated how much they supported each policy (1 = not at all to 5 = very much). Responses were averaged to an index of the participant’s overall support of public-policies that limit the spread of COVID-19 (ɑ = .81, M = 4.60, SD = .64). For both behavioral indices, higher scores reflected more engagement in the measured behavior. Higher scores in the policy support index reflected stronger overall support for public-policies that limit the spread of COVID-19. The data were negatively skewed. Means for both behaviors and policy support were on average very high indicating that participants overall supported health-related guidelines and public-policies.
Within each scale, the presentation order of items was randomized. The presentation
order of all scales was randomized. Demographic questions were always presented last. At the end of each survey, participants responded to a simple attention check.
Data availability. Data and analysis codes for both studies are uploaded on Open Science Framework with the accession code osf.io/7vjr2. Material and additional analyses are reported in the Supplementary document.
The authors declare no competing financial interests. In conducting this research, we complied with APA ethical standards in the treatment of our human sample. These data have not been published previously, nor are they under consideration for publication elsewhere.

claim2: In an exploratory study 1 (N = 409), two subdimensions of COVID-19 conspiracy theories were robust predictors of negative attitude toward vaccine science.
claim3a: the more participants endorse COVID-19 conspiracy beliefs, the less likely it is that they hold a positive attitude toward vaccination.
claim3b: hierarchical regression analysis were carried out to examine whether belief in the “outgroup” sub dimension of COVID-19 conspiracy theories predicted attitudes toward vaccination
claim4: Attitudes towards vaccines were negatively predicted by “outgroup” conspiracy theories, beta = -.45, 95% CI[-.36; -.54], t = -10.16, p < .001

content.text:
Many conspiracy theories appeared along with the COVID-19 pandemic. Since it is documented that conspiracy theories negatively affect vaccination intentions, these beliefs might become a crucial matter in the near future. We conducted two cross-sectional studies examining the relations between COVID-19 conspiracy beliefs, vaccine attitudes and intention to be vaccinated against the COVID-19 when a vaccine becomes available. In an exploratory study 1 (N = 409), two subdimensions of COVID19 conspiracy theories were robust predictors of negative attitude toward vaccine science. These results were replicated and extended in a pre-registered study 2 (N = 396). Moreover, we found that COVID19 conspiracy beliefs (among which, conspiracy beliefs about chloroquine), as well as a conspiracy mentality (i.e., predisposition to believe in conspiracy theories) negatively predicted participants’ intentions to be vaccinated against COVID-19 in the future. Interestingly, none of the conspiracy beliefs referred directly to the dangers of the vaccines, nor to pharmaceutical companies. Last, we observed a strikingly high level of COVID-19 vaccination hesitancy. Implications for the pandemic and potential responses are discussed based on existing literature.
Keywords: Conspiracy beliefs; Conspiracy mentality; Vaccination; Covid-19; Chloroquine.
significant social and political events and circumstances with claims of secret plots by two or more powerful actors” (Douglas et al., 2019, p.4). These beliefs tend to appear in social crisis situations, which are times of heightened collective uncertainty and fear (van Prooijen & Douglas, 2017). It has been proposed that these beliefs are responses to psychological needs (Douglas, Sutton, & Cichocka, 2017; Klein & Nera, 2020), and might constitute attempts to understand complex, otherwise hardly understandable and predictable threatening situations (Franks, Bangerter, & Bauer, 2013; van Prooijen, 2019). Hence, it is not surprising that conspiracy theories have flourished with the COVID-19 pandemic, and that medical misinformation spreads at a spectacular rate (Kouzy et al., 2020). Interestingly, conspiracy theories also surged during the 1918-1919 Spanish flu pandemic (Spinney, 2017) and the 2009 H1N1 outbreak (Bangerter et al., 2012).
Conspiracy theories may also influence the course of a crisis that initially favored
their appearance. Indeed, conspiracy theories have consequences, notably in the health domain (Douglas, Sutton, Jolley, & Wood, 2015; Van Prooijen & Douglas, 2018). For example, exposure to anti-vaccines conspiracy theories decreases vaccination intention (Chen, Zhang, Young, Wu & Zhu, 2020; Jolley & Douglas, 2014). A Big Data analysis even suggests that distrust of vaccines, which is fuelled by conspiracy theories, may have had a negative impact on the worldwide measles immunization rate (Mavragani & Ochoa, 2018). Moreover, there is evidence that belief in conspiracy theories is associated with a generic belief system, so that the endorsement of some conspiracy theories is a powerful predictor of the endorsement of others, even those that are seemingly unrelated (Swami et al., 2011). As a result, authors have proposed that belief in conspiracy theories is symptomatic of a “monological belief system” (Goertzel, 1994), or “conspiracy mentality” (Moscovici, 1987;
beliefs unrelated to vaccination (e.g., about JFK, Martin Luther King, the Moon Landing, …) is also associated with negative attitudes toward vaccination (Lewandowsky, Gignac, & Oberauer, 2013).
However, these studies were conducted before the sanitary crisis that the world is
currently experiencing. Replicating past results in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic is needed for at least two reasons. First, replication is necessary to establish the validity of frequentist statistical inferences (Krueger, 2001), which is the overwhelmingly dominant statistical approach in the psychological literature (Blanca, Alarcón & Bono, 2018). Second, given that research in psychology is in a post-replication crisis era (Anvari & Lakens, 2018), advice from psychological science must be taken with great caution, especially in a situation such as the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic (Ijzerman et al., 2020). In this context, replication studies might strengthen social psychological knowledge (Rosenfeld, 2020) and constitute a safety baseline needed to build evidence-based policies and effective sanitary guidelines.
In the context of the COVID-19 pandemic, conspiracy theories may foster distrust
towards health authorities and their recommendations, which could potentially seriously impede efforts to put an end to the pandemic. In the short term, respect for containment behaviour guidelines (e.g., washing hands, social distancing, …) is crucial to limit the spread of the pandemic, because the development of a treatment (including a vaccine) could take months (World Health Organization, 2020). However, in the long run, the development and distribution of a vaccine against COVID-19 might be a necessary step to put an end to the pandemic (Le et al., 2020). In this research, we examine how the endorsement of various COVID-19 conspiracy theories is predictive of two vaccine-related outcomes: attitude toward vaccination science (study 1 and 2), conceptually replicating Lewandowsky, Gignac, &
available (study 2), conceptually replicating Jolley & Douglas (2014).
Study 1
In Study 1, our goal was to explore the relationship between COVID-19 conspiracy
beliefs and attitudes toward vaccines science. Data, materials in French (with English translation) and analyses are available on the OSF repository at the following address: https://osf.io/3qyf4/?view_only=c2aa291fb1604b73aef9057cfc41980e.
Method
Sampling and procedure. The study was conducted online and disseminated on
Facebook, Twitter and Linkedin from March 19 (i.e., two days after the official beginning of the lockdown in France) to March 27. In total, 609 participants participated in the survey. Two hundred participants were removed from the data for not completing the questionnaire, failing the attention or seriousness checks, or being under 18 years old. The final sample was constituted of 409 participant (299 women and 3 “other”, Mage = 28.4 , SD = 11.4, min = 18, max = 72), which is above the threshold of N = 250 requested to achieve correlations stability (Schönbrodt & Perugini, 2013). For a given power of .90, this sample size enabled us to detect correlations of r = .16 with two tailed tests.
Materials. For each scale, participants were asked to give their response on a 5-point
scale ranging from Strongly Disagree (coded 1) to Strongly Agree (coded 5).
COVID-19 conspiracy theories. 9 items were designed to capture the
endorsement of some COVID-19 conspiracy theories currently popular in France (Conspiracy Watch, 2020). Given the wide variety of COVID-19 conspiracy theories (Van Bavel et al.,
threatening specified outgroups (three items, e.g. “COVID-19 is a bacteriological weapon used by the Chinese Communist Party to create panic in the West”), conspiracy theories involving unspecified threatening (i.e., not referring to any foreign country outgroups (three items, e.g. “Industrials will use the coronavirus pandemic to justify higher prices and make a profit”), and conspiracy theories involving members of the national ingroup (three items, e.g. “The French government uses the current pandemic to keep quiet significant reforms and challenges”). Some authors have emphasized the theoretical and empirical relevance of distinguishing between national ingroup and outgroup conspiracy beliefs (e.g. Cichocka, Marchlewska, Golec de Zavala & Olechowski, 2015). Exploratory factor analysis revealed a two factor structure yielding a satisfactory fit, CFI = .95, TLI = .94, RMSEA = .09, one consisting of the three “specified outgroup” and two “unspecified outgroup” items (α = .88), and one combining the three “ingroup” items and one “unspecified outgroup” (α = .77). The two factors were correlated, r = .53, p < .001. Out of convenience, the dimensions were labeled “outgroup conspiracy beliefs” and “ingroup conspiracy beliefs”, respectively. Only the “outgroup” dimension was significantly associated with political orientation, r = .25, p < .001, so that right wing participants endorsed these beliefs more than the left.
Attitude toward vaccination. We translated into French the 5-items scale (1
reverse coded) developed by Lewandowsky and colleagues (2013). We used three items due to length restrictions (e.g. “I believe that vaccines are a safe and reliable way to help avert the spread of preventable diseases”, α = .83).
(M/F/Other), and political orientation on a scale ranging from 1 (far left) to 9 (far right), with the possibility to tick “other”.
Results and discussion
[ insert table 1 ]
Descriptive statistics and correlations between variables are displayed in table 1. We
carried out a hierarchical regression analysis to examine whether belief in the two dimensions of COVID-19 conspiracy theories predicted attitudes toward vaccination. Gender and age were controlled for at step 1, and COVID-19 conspiracy theories were introduced as independent variables at step 2. Since the two factors of COVID-19 conspiracy beliefs were substantially correlated both to each other and to attitudes toward vaccines, they were first tested as predictors in separate regressions. Attitudes towards vaccines were negatively predicted by both “outgroup” conspiracy theories, β = -.45, 95% CI[-.36; -.54], t = -10.16, p < .001, and “ingroup” conspiracy theories, β = -.41, 95% CI[-.32; -.49], t = -10.16, p < .001. Finally, in a model integrating both dimensions as predictors, the effect remained significant for both the “ingroup” factor, β = -.23, 95% CI[-.13; -.33], t = -4.61, p < .001, and the “outgroup” factor, β = -.33, 95% CI[-.22; -.43], t = -6.37, p < .001.
Hence, regardless of their specific content, the more participants endorsed COVID-19
conspiracy beliefs, the less likely it was that they held a positive attitude toward vaccination. This result is congruent with past research showing that endorsement of conspiracy theories is related to negative attitudes toward vaccination (Lewandowsky et al., 2013).
We designed a second study to first replicate and strengthen results from study 1.
Second, we examined if COVID-19 conspiracy theories were also a negative predictor of the intention to be vaccinated against the disease in the future in an attempt to conceptually replicate Jolley and Douglas (2014). Third, we wanted to examine if these outcomes - attitude toward vaccination and intention to be vaccinated - were also negatively predicted by belief in conspiracy theories surrounding (hydroxy)chloroquine. Lamberty & Imhoff (2018) showed that the conspiracy mentality predicts a preference for alternative therapies over biomedical therapies. Chloroquine is a well-known anti-malarial drug has been promoted by the French infectious disease expert Didier Raoult as an effective treatment for COVID-19 (a claim which has not yet been confirmed by any empirical evidence), and a recent poll reports that 59% of the French population believes this treatment to be effective (IFOP, April 2020). Many chloroquine advocates argued that pharmaceutical companies want to discredit this treatment because it would jeopardize the potential profits of a future cure. The use of this drug to treat COVID-19 extends beyond French borders, as Donald Trump reported in midMay that he was taking hydroxychloroquine "to protect himself", despite warnings from the FDA and Facebook’s deleting a video of Jaïr Bolsonaro praising the drug (Reuters, May 8 & 18, 2020). Thus, following Van Bavel et al. (2020) who hypothesized that COVID-19 conspiracy beliefs may be associated with a heightened interest in alternative remedies, we expected conspiracy beliefs to predict support for chloroquine treatment.
Several previous research studies found a conspiracy mentality to be related to
negative attitudes toward vaccination (Lewandowsky, Gignac, & Oberauer, 2013) and with positive attitudes toward alternative remedies (Lamberty & Imhoff, 2018). Conspiracy
intending individuals or groups for important societal phenomena” (Bruder, Haffke, Neave, Nouripanah, & Imhoff, 2014). It is conceptually distinct from conspiracy beliefs measured by means of inventories such as the COVID-19 and chloroquine conspiracy beliefs scale we used in the present studies. In Study 2, we measured conspiracy mentality to explore its relation to attitude toward vaccine science, attitude toward chloroquine and intention to vaccinate against COVID-19.
Whereas Study 1 was exploratory, Study 2 aimed at testing a set of pre-registered
hypotheses (see: https://osf.io/x43na/?view_only=531273ec519a4914a52bd5577f6c68f5). First, we hypothesized that COVID-19 conspiracy beliefs would be a negative predictor of both pro-vaccination attitudes and vaccination intention. Moreover, we hypothesized that the same pattern would be observed with chloroquine conspiracy theories as a predictor. Finally, we hypothesized that pro-chloroquine attitude would be positively predicted by both COVID19 conspiracy theories and chloroquine conspiracy theories. Lastly, we included conspiracy mentality as an exploratory measure.

content.heading: Method
content.text:
Sampling and procedure. The study was disseminated online both among students
who were awarded course credit for answering, and on social media in order to diversify the sample, from April 17 to April 25. 469 participants participated in the study, out of which 396 remained (280 women and 6 “other”, Mage = 26.1, SD = 10.3, min = 18, max = 70) after excluding participants who did not comply to the exclusion criteria (cf pre-registration form). For a given power of .90, the sample size enabled us to detect correlations of r = .16 with two tailed tests.

Attitudes and conspiracy theories about chloroquine, as well as vaccination intention, were pretested in an online preliminary study (N = 81, see the supplementary materials in the OSF repository for further details).
COVID-19 conspiracy theories. We used the same scale as in Study 1, and added
a conspiracy theory about the creation of the coronavirus by a famous French laboratory (“Coronavirus has been created and patented by the Pasteur Institute in the early 2000s”). Since both factors had similar relations to the outcomes in Study 1, all items were averaged into a single COVID-19 conspiracy beliefs score (α = .84).
Chloroquine conspiracy theories. We designed a 6-items scale to assess
participant beliefs in popular “pro-chloroquine” conspiracy theories (e.g. “Pharmaceutical industries, together with the government, avoid chloroquine based treatment diffusion to protect its financial interests”, 88).
Conspiracy Mentality Questionnaire (CMQ). General conspiracy beliefs were
measured with a validated French translation of the Conspiracy Mentality Questionnaire (CMQ; Bruder, Haffke, Neave, Nouripanah & Imhoff, 2013, translation by Lantian, Muller, Nurra, & Douglas, 2016), a 5-item measure designed to assess an individual's tendency to engage in general conspiracist ideation (e.g. “I think that many very important things happen in the world, which the public is never informed about”, α = .84) . Participants rated how true they thought a given item was on an 11-point scale (from 0% = ‘Certainly not’ to 100% = ‘Certain’).

Items were introduced by a paragraph introducing the question of chloroquine (“We hear a lot about the potential of a drug, chloroquine, to cure COVID-19 [...] what is your opinion on the topic?”).
Attitude toward vaccination. We used the full 5-items scale (e.g. “Vaccinations
are one of the most significant contributions to public health”, α = .84) developed by Lewandowsky et al. (2013).
Vaccination intention. We adapted the single item used by Jolley and Douglas
(2017), to assess behavioural intention to be vaccinated against COVID-19. We asked participants what they would do if a COVID-19 vaccine were developed and validated by the health authorities, and they had the opportunity to be vaccinated next week. Participants answered on a scale ranging from 1 (“I would definitely not be vaccinated under any circumstances”) to 7 (“I would be vaccinated without any hesitation”).
Sociodemographic measures. Participants reported their age, gender
(M/F/other), and political orientation.
Results
[Insert table 2]
Confirmatory analyses. To test our hypotheses, we carried out hierarchical
regression analyses that controlled for age and gender at step 1 (see table 3). As can be seen in the table, all of our hypotheses were corroborated, as COVID-19 and chloroquine
intention to get vaccinated for the disease in the future. Last, both types of conspiracy beliefs positively predicted a pro-chloroquine attitude.
[insert table 3]
Exploratory analyses. We also tested the extent to which conspiracy mentality,
rather than belief in specific conspiracy theories, predicted the three outcomes (see Model 3 in Table 3). Conspiracy mentality had the same relations as COVID-19 and chloroquine conspiracy beliefs with vaccine attitudes, intention to be vaccinated, and pro-chloroquine attitudes.
Last, we examined the extent to which the effect of conspiracy beliefs on the
outcomes held when controlling for participants’ conspiracy mentality. Note that COVID-19 and chloroquine conspiracy beliefs were treated as independent variables in separate models. When controlling for conspiracy mentality at Step 1 (as well as gender and age), vaccine attitudes were still positively predicted by COVID-19 conspiracy beliefs, β = -.33, 95% CI[-.42; -.22], t = -6.60, p < .001, and chloroquine conspiracy beliefs, β = -.49, 95% CI[-.58; -.40], t = -10.74; p < .001. Intention to be vaccinated against COVID-19 was still negatively predicted by COVID-19 conspiracy beliefs, β = -.20, 95% CI[-.31; -.11], t = -4.02, p < .001, and chloroquine conspiracy beliefs, β = -.34, 95% CI[-.44; -.24], t = -6.84, p < .001. Last, the effect also remained significant for attitudes toward chloroquine, as they were still positively predicted by COVID-19 conspiracy beliefs, β = .19, 95%CI [.08; .29], t = 3.58, p < .001, and chloroquine conspiracy beliefs, β = .58, 95% CI[.49; .67], t = 13.13, p < .001.
Furthermore, contrary to our expectations, we did not find a strong ceiling effect for
the vaccination intention scale (M = 4.72; SD = 1.80). Strikingly, 22% of the sample (N =

General discussion and conclusion
Our results are congruent with past research and suggest that when a vaccine against
COVID-19 becomes available, conspiracy theories, regardless of their specific content, might become a serious sanitary issue. Also alarming is the fact in our sample, more than one participant out of five leaned toward refusal of the hypothetical COVID-19 vaccine, even though it was described as having been approved by the health authorities (however, we did not specify if the vaccine was refunded by social security or not). This is congruent with data showing that the French population is extremely distrustful of vaccines (Ward, PerettiWatel, Bocquier, Seror & Verger, 2019). If a coronavirus vaccine were available, 26% of French people would refuse to be vaccinated according to a longitudinal study of a representative sample (Yamey et al., 2020). This proportion, measured for the fifth time since the start of the CoConel survey (27 March), remains very stable.
In our studies, COVID-19 conspiracy theories were substantially and negatively
related to both positive attitudes toward vaccination science and intention to be vaccinated against COVID-19 in the future. This relationship was observed for all the types of conspiracy beliefs considered, namely, conspiracy theories accusing foreign powers, conspiracy theories involving the French government, and conspiracy theories pertaining to chloroquine treatments and a conspiracy mentality.
We wish to emphasize that none of the conspiracy beliefs or conspiracy mentality
items referred to the dangers of vaccines. Hence, regardless of their content, belief in COVID19 conspiracy theories, as well as a conspiracy mentality, seem to be associated with a
congruent with the idea that conspiracy beliefs are underpinned by a generic belief system which is characterized by negative attitudes towards powerful groups (Imhoff & Bruder, 2014). It therefore conceptually replicates research conducted before the pandemic (Imhoff & Lamberty, 2018; Jolley & Douglas, 2014; Lewandowsky et al., 2013).
Although our samples were not representative of the French population, with an
overrepresentation of female participants and those describing themselves as politically leftwing. However, according to a recent poll conducted on a French representative sample, conspiracy beliefs are higher among men and right-winged participants (Conspiracy Watch, 2019). Thus, one can infer that the results of the present studies might not be overestimated because of sampling error. Further research is however needed to assess the generalizability of our results to different contexts, especially in non-western culture, since the pandemic is a worldwide crisis, in order to determine whether the relationship between conspiracy beliefs and vaccination rejection of vaccination is Western-specific or has some kind of universality. Such a replication effort to delineate the consequence of conspiracy beliefs for vaccination will hopefully allow a fruitful development of remediation tools to cope with the harmful feature of the infodemic (Zarocostas, 2020).
Previous research has shown several ways to reduce the detrimental consequences of
conspiracy beliefs. First, Jolley and Douglas (2017) tested ways to reduce directly the influence of anti-vaccine conspiracy beliefs on vaccination intention. Their findings indicate that anti-conspiracy arguments can restore hypothetical intention to vaccinate children, but only when the corrective message was presented before conspiratorial discourses. As for Chen and collaborators (2020), they observed that pre-existing knowledge about the HPV vaccine nullified the impact of exposure to anti-vaccines conspiracy theories on HPV vaccination
the corrective message beforehand for efficiently restoring vaccination intention. Their results indicate that both corrective messages presented before and after the conspiracy content helped in reducing the related beliefs. Altogether, these results emphasize the relevance of both proactive information and misinformation correction initiatives before the public is exposed to misinformation, and debunking efforts after exposure, to reduce the impact of COVID-19 conspiracy theories. To minimize the spread of misinformation, recent research indicates that nudging people, by simply asking them to think about whether or not information is true, is efficient in preventing them from sharing false information (Pennycook, McPhetres, Zhang & Rand, 2020).
Besides these concrete intervention possibilities, a more generic recommendation could
be to to develop interventions aiming at fostering analytical thinking (Swami & Barron, 2020; Swami, Voracek, Stieger, Tran & Furnham, 2014) and scientific reasoning (Cavojova, Šrol and Mikušková, 2020). The former has been shown to reduce conspiracy beliefs, while the latter is associated with positive vaccines attitudes.
In conclusion, past literature as well as the present research, provide theoretical and
empirical reasons not to underestimate the potential sanitary harm of COVID-19 conspiracy theories. While our research does not measure participants’ actual behaviour, the robustness and magnitude of the reported results, as well as the prevalence of vaccination hesitancy as a global phenomenon in France, should encourage academics, policy makers, health authorities, and journalists to start working on concrete initiatives to tackle this issue.

content.heading: In the coronavirus “infodemic”, people are exposed to both official recommendations and to
content.text:
potentially dangerous pseudoscientific advice claimed to protect against COVID-19. We examined whether irrational beliefs predict adherence to COVID-19 guidelines as well as susceptibility to such misinformation. Irrational beliefs were indexed by cognitive intuition, Type I error cognitive biases, COVID-19 knowledge overestimation, and belief in COVID-19 conspiracy theories. Participants (N=407) reported (a) how often they followed guidelines (e.g., handwashing), (b) how often they engaged in pseudoscientific practices (e.g., consuming garlic, colloidal silver), and (c) their intention to receive a COVID-19 vaccine. Conspiratorial beliefs consistently predicted all three outcomes. Cognitive intuition and knowledge overestimation predicted lesser, while cognitive biases predicted greater adherence to guidelines. Cognitive intuition and cognitive biases predicted greater use of pseudoscientific practices. Our results highlight the irrational beliefs predictive of COVID-19 related health behaviors, with conspiracy theories proving to be the most detrimental.
Keywords: COVID-19 Health Behavior, Pseudoscience, Conspiracy Theories, Cognitive Biases, Knowledge Overestimation
Practices During the COVID-19 Pandemic
With the developing coronavirus pandemic, societies are forced to introduce new
measures to curb the infection rate. This means that, among other things, ordinary people are asked to adopt enhanced protective health behaviors, such as social distancing and frequent handwashing. However, along with these official recommendations, people are exposed to medical misinformation and unverified content pertaining to COVID-19, which have proliferated rapidly through social media (Depoux et al., 2020; Kouzy et al., 2020; Mian & Khan, 2020; Zarocostas, 2020). In fact, we are “not just fighting an epidemic; we’re fighting an infodemic. Fake news spreads faster and more easily than this virus, and is just as dangerous” (WHO, 2020). Pseudoscientific recommendations such as consuming garlic, drinking ginger tea or rinsing nose with saline, became so pervasive that the WHO (n.d.) had to officially debunk the claims about their effectiveness. Certain pseudoscientific practices (PSPs) are extremely dangerous – for example, more than 700 Iranians were reported dead of methanol poisoning falsely believing it was a miracle cure for COVID-19 (Associated Press, 2020). Another “victim” of the infodemic is the COVID-19 vaccine, which is still in development. Even amid the pandemic, the topic of vaccination has provoked an online backlash (e.g., Mooney, 2020). Given the grave consequences of vaccination refusal, such as failure to reach herd immunity, it is important to understand why some people might be reluctant to get immunized.
Both adherence to official public health recommendations and the use of PSPs might be
embedded in a set of irrational beliefs. We refer to irrational beliefs as an umbrella term that covers beliefs which lack a solid evidence base or defy principles of normative rationality (Žeželj & Lazarević, 2019). In this study, we explored whether people who differ in their predisposition
for COVID-19. More precisely, whether irrational beliefs such as cognitive intuition, susceptibility to type I error cognitive biases, overestimation of one’s own COVID-19 knowledge, and belief in COVID-19 conspiracy theories predict adherence to COVID-19 guidelines, use of PSPs, and intention to receive a COVID-19 vaccine if it were available. While cognitive intuition and cognitive biases can be seen as general, content-independent types of irrational beliefs, knowledge overestimation – a miscalibration error resting on a discrepancy between objectively measured and self-estimated knowledge – and belief in conspiracy theories – potential source of false knowledge about a particular subject – are content-laden irrational beliefs pertaining to a specific event or a class of events. The effect of each irrational belief on the chosen health behaviors was examined together with the three other types of irrational beliefs to discern its relative predictiveness.
Cognitive intuition is often assessed with the Cognitive Reflection Test (CRT; Frederick,
2005), which consists of three items that lead most people to answer quickly and incorrectly. Previous research has shown that misleading intuitions predict paranormal beliefs (Pennycook et al., 2012; Ståhl & van Prooijen, 2018) as well as religious beliefs (Pennycook, Fugelsang, & Koehler, 2015; Shenhav et al., 2012). In the health domain, cognitive intuition was related to beliefs about the effectiveness and self-reported use of complementary and alternative treatments both before (Browne et al., 2015; McPhetres & Pennycook, 2019; see also Lindeman, 2011) and during the COVID-19 pandemic (Čavojová et al., 2020; Erceg et al., 2020; Pennycook et al., 2020). However, recent findings on the relation between CRT performance and adherence to official COVID-19 guidelines are mixed – while some found a negative relation (Stanley et al., 2020), others failed to establish any link (Čavojová et al., 2020; Erceg et al., 2020; Pennycook et
lesser adherence to COVID-19 guidelines (H1a), greater use of PSPs (H1b), and weaker intention to get vaccinated against COVID-19 (H1c).
Cognitive biases, as systematic departures from what is normatively defined rational
behavior, can be viewed as yet another broad category of irrational beliefs. Although they have been proven to be predictive of some paranormal (Bressan, 2002; Pennycook et al., 2012; Šrol, 2020; van Prooijen et al., 2017) and pseudoscientific beliefs (Pennycook, Cheyne et al., 2015; Redelmeier & Tversky, 1996; Šrol, 2020), cognitive biases remain underexplored in the domain of both PSPs and adherence to public health guidelines. The list of cognitive biases is considerably heterogeneous and ever evolving (Kahneman & Frederick, 2005; Pohl, 2004; Stanovich, 2009; Teovanović et al., 2015). Therefore, in our study, we opted to include only a subset based on a general tendency to make a type I error, that is, to make false conclusions on relations between unrelated phenomena. These biases included illusory correlation detection, base-rate neglect, gambler’s fallacy, and hot-hand fallacy. We expected that a higher susceptibility to such cognitive biases would predict lesser adherence to COVID-19 guidelines (H2a), greater use of PSPs (H2b), and weaker intention to get vaccinated (H2c).
Knowledge overestimation is typically calculated as a difference between self-estimated
and objectively estimated knowledge on a certain subject (Ackerman et al., 2002; Harvey, 1997; Kleitman & Stankov, 2001; Kruger & Dunning, 1999; Stankov, 2000). Pennycook and colleagues (2017) showed that intuitive individuals tended to be more overconfident on the CRT, rating themselves as relatively reflective, despite their test scores showing otherwise. Thus, it is their non-reflexivity prevents them from recognizing their ignorance (see also Dunning, 2011; Kruger & Dunning, 1999). Disagreement between self-assessed and objectively assessed
2004), which carries obvious negative implications for people’s safety. In this study, we expected that higher levels of COVID-19 related knowledge overestimation would predict lesser adherence to COVID-19 guidelines (H3a), greater use of PSPs (H3b), and weaker intention to get vaccinated (H3c).
The COVID-19 pandemic is a public health crisis and, as such, a fertile ground for
conspiracy theories (Gonçalves-Sá, 2020; van Prooijen & Douglas, 2017). This aspect of the infodemic might be especially dangerous since medical conspiracy theories have been consistently associated with a range of risky health behaviors including less sunscreen use, not getting annual check-ups or vaccinations, less contraceptive use, and HIV medication nonadherence (e.g., Bogart et al., 2010; Jolley & Douglas, 2014; Oliver & Wood, 2014; Setbon & Raude, 2010; Thorburn & Bogart, 2005). However, recent studies examining the relation between belief in COVID-19 conspiracy theories and self-reported adherence to recommended behaviors have produced inconsistent results. While some found a relation with adherence to health guidelines (Imhoff & Lamberty, 2020; see also Swami & Barron, 2020), others did not (Čavojová et al., 2020; see also Plohl & Musil, 2020). Furthermore, conspiracy theories might be predictive of some, but not other types of recommended protective behaviors – for example, believing in COVID-19 conspiracy theories was related to less social-distancing but unrelated to personal-hygiene behaviors (Pummerer & Sassenberg, 2020). As for pseudoscientific practices, it was shown that people more prone to conspiratorial thinking were more likely to endorse claims related to the effectiveness of complementary and alternative medical treatments in general (Lamberty & Imhoff, 2018; Lobato et al., 2014; Pennycook, Cheyne et al., 2015) and that they reported greater use of PSPs to prevent contracting coronavirus (Čavojová et al., 2020;
converging evidence suggesting that conspiracy theories are predictive of PSPs, more studies are needed to explore their influence on adherence to COVID-19 guidelines. We expected that stronger beliefs in COVID-19 conspiracy theories would predict lesser adherence to COVID-19 guidelines (H4a), greater use of PSPs (H4b), and a weaker intention to get vaccinated (H4c).
In sum, the present study builds upon emerging research on evidence and non-evidence
based COVID-19 related recommendations by examining the predictiveness of different irrational beliefs for COVID-19 related health behaviors in a single design. We will examine if both content-independent (i.e., cognitive intuition and susceptibility to type I error cognitive biases) and content-laden irrational beliefs (i.e., overestimation of one’s own COVID-19 knowledge and belief in COVID-19 conspiracy theories) are relevant for adherence to official COVID-19 guidelines, use of PSPs, and intention to receive a COVID-19 vaccine.
Methods

content.heading: Sample and Procedure
content.text:
We recruited a total of 754 participants via a snowball procedure and through social
networks (Facebook and Viber groups), between April 10 and April 22. The final sample (N = 407) included participants who did all of the following: fully completed the questionnaires, accurately responded to all three attention check items, and confirmed that they did not search for information online while completing the questionnaires. The mean age of participants was 34.88 years (SD = 12.81). Females were overrepresented in the sample (76.9%), as were participants with higher education: about 0.5% of participants completed elementary school, 42.5% completed high-school, 30.2% completed undergraduate studies, and 26.3% completed graduate studies. The questionnaire was administered in Serbian language.
available at https://osf.io/qk9nf/.

content.heading: Instruments and Variables
content.text:
Cognitive Intuition was assessed via the CRT (Frederick, 2005), consisting of three items
which cue a fast but incorrect response (we initially tried out three additional tasks, but decided to use the ones in the original version). One example of an item is the following question: “A racket and a ball cost 1100 RSD [Serbian currency] in total. The racket costs 1000 RSD more than the ball. How much does the ball cost?”. Although the correct answer is “50 RSD” approximately 40% of participants answered “100 RSD”. A total score was calculated as a sum of intuitive responses (α = .63).
Type I Error Cognitive Biases were measured with six heuristics-and-biases tasks which
tap into peoples’ tendency to erroneously recognize relations between unrelated phenomena. They were represented with two covariation detection problems as measures of illusory correlation (Smedslund, 1963), two base rate problems (Tversky & Kahneman, 1974), and two probability judgment tasks measuring hot-hand fallacy (Gilovich et al., 1985) and gambler’s fallacy (Tversky & Kahneman, 1974). We calculated the total score as the average of biased responses across tasks (α = .52).
Belief in COVID-19 Conspiracy Theories Scale was developed for the purpose of this
study. It consisted of 13 items representing most popular conspiracy theories circulating in digital media and conversations on social networks (e.g., “5G electromagnetic field exposure played a role in the coronavirus pandemic”). Response options ranged from 1 (Completely Disagree) to 5 (Completely Agree). The scale was highly reliable (α = .90). We averaged responses for the 13 items to form a total score.
standardized scores of subjectively estimated and objectively assessed knowledge. Subjective estimation of knowledge relating to COVID-19 was represented with a single item (“How would you rate your knowledge about the new coronavirus?”) on a scale ranging from 1 (Insufficient) to 5 (Excellent). Objective knowledge was assessed using a previously developed test (Lep et al., 2020), which consisted of nine true or false statements relating to COVID-19 (e.g., “The coronavirus is transmitted through respiratory droplets”); the total score was summed and ranged between zero and nine.
Adherence to COVID-19 Guidelines was measured with 12 items based on the official
WHO and the Serbian Ministry of Health COVID-19 guidelines (α = .69). Five items related to newly introduced (e.g., social distancing) or enhanced (e.g., thorough handwashing) health behaviors, in the previous two weeks, rated on a scale ranging from 1 (Never) to 5 (Very Often). Additional seven items referred to behaviors recommended to be avoided during the outbreak (e.g., visiting other households or attending social gatherings). Participants rated the frequency of these behaviors in the previous two weeks by entering a number. These seven items were multiplied by -1 so that higher scores would always correspond to greater adherence to recommended practices. To convert into a common metric, all item scores were standardized. To handle outliers, z-values above 3.29 were winsorized. A total score was calculated as an average of all 12 items.
Use of PSPs related to COVID-19 was assessed via a 12-item scale created for the
purpose of this study (α = .73). Five items were based on the list of common myths indicated on the WHO website (WHO, n.d.), while the remaining seven were based on PSPs against COVID19 commonly reported in digital media outlets. Participants rated how often they used PSPs in
from 1 (Never) to 5 (Very Often). We averaged the participants’ responses for all 12 items to create a total score.
Vaccination intention was assessed by asking participants to rate their willingness to
receive a COVID-19 vaccine if it were available at that time. The scale ranged from 1 (Definitely would not) to 5 (Definitely would).
Results
The dataset (https://osf.io/cpe5t/) and analysis code (https://osf.io/5rabw/) are available at
the OSF.
Table 1 shows descriptives for health related behaviors during the pandemic. Frequencies
regarding adherence to COVID-19 guidelines indicate that 76.7% (n = 312) of the participants reported adhering to at least three out of five newly introduced or enhanced health behaviors often or very often. As for behaviors that were recommended to be avoided (e.g., visiting other households), as much as 27.8% (n = 113) of participants reported always avoiding all of them. In terms of use of PSPs, responses were more diverse. While 67.6% (n = 275) of participants reported having used at least one PSP often or very often, 11.3% (n = 46) had rarely or never used any of the listed PSP. Finally, although 49.1% (n = 200) of participants reported they would definitely or probably receive a COVID-19 vaccine, a significant percent (26.8%; n = 109) of participants stated they definitely or probably would not.
Descriptive statistics and bivariate correlations between all measured variables are
presented in Table 1. Regarding content-independent beliefs, even though participants did not produce many intuitive responses on the CRT, they showed moderate susceptibility to type I error cognitive biases. As for content-laden irrational beliefs, participants moderately endorsed
191. Eight out of twelve zero order correlation coefficients between four types of irrational beliefs and the three health behaviors were statistically significant (ps < .05), all in the expected direction.

To further test the hypotheses, that is, to discern the predictive power of a single variable
in the set when the effects of others were controlled for, we ran three multiple regression models with adherence, PSPs, and vaccination intention as outcome variables. Cognitive intuition, susceptibility to type I error cognitive biases, Overestimation of COVID-19 knowledge, and belief in COVID-19 conspiracy theories served as predictors (see Table 2).
The model predicting adherence to COVID-19 guidelines had relatively low explanatory
power (F(4,402) = 7.78, R2 = .07, p < .001). As expected, cognitive intuition, overestimation of COVID-19 related knowledge, and belief in COVID-19 conspiracy theories, negatively predicted adherence to COVID-19 guidelines (H1a, H3a, and H4a respectively). Contrary to our hypothesis (H2a), susceptibility to type I error cognitive biases positively predicted Adherence to COVID-19 guidelines.
When it comes to use of PSPs, susceptibility to type I error cognitive biases,
overestimation of COVID-19 related knowledge, belief in COVID-19 conspiracy theories significantly contributed to the model, explaining 14% of the variance (F(4,402) = 16.89, R2 = .14, p < .001). This suggested that those with more biased thinking, knowledge overestimation and beliefs in COVID-19 conspiracy theories were more likely to follow pseudoscientific advice, which is in line with H3b, and H4b, but not with H2b.

In line with H4c, belief in COVID19 conspiracy theories negatively predicted COVID-19 vaccination intentions, suggesting that those endorsing COVID-19 conspiracy theories may be less likely to get vaccinated when a vaccine becomes available. Contrary to our expectations (H2c), we observed that susceptibility to type I error cognitive biases positively contributed to the model, suggesting that those that were more prone to cognitive biases may be more likely to get vaccinated against the virus. To make sure that the inclusion of a vaccine-related conspiracy in the total score (i.e., “One should be careful when a vaccine against coronavirus is developed because no one knows what they will inject in us”) did not artificially increase the predictivity of the model, we conducted a sensitivity analysis omitting this question. This model accounted for 26% of the variance (F(4,402) = 35.2, p < .001), corroborating the robustness of the relation between Beliefs in COVID-19 conspiracy theories and COVID-19 vaccination intentions.
Across all regression models, Belief in COVID-19 conspiracies and type I error cognitive
biases were the most consistent predictors of health behaviors related to COVID-19.

that the significant regression models were not the result of p-value inflation, we conducted a canonical correlation analysis, a multivariate type of the general linear model (Thompson, 2005). The results are presented in Table 3, suggesting that two out of three canonical correlations were significant.

These results indicate that vaccination hesitancy and use of PSPs have relations with intuitive and biased thinking and belief in conspiracy theories. This component explained more than 10% of the variance across the two sets of variables. Moreover, the proportions of explained variance support the examination of irrational beliefs as predictors of health behaviors.
The second canonical function reflects the relations between a greater susceptibility to
type I error cognitive biases and lesser COVID-19 knowledge overestimation, on the one hand, and a higher rate of acceptance of all available preventive practices, on the other. This suggests that following all types of health practices is related to a greater susceptibility to type I error cognitive biases and lesser COVID-19 knowledge overestimation. However, since this component explained only 3% of the variance across the variable sets, this finding should be interpreted with caution.
Discussion
We found that health behaviors related to COVID-19 – adherence to COVID-19
guidelines, use of PSPs, and intentions to get vaccinated against COVID-19 – were all predicted by irrational beliefs to some degree.
Belief in COVID-19 conspiracy theories was the most consistent predictor of each type
of health behavior. This is in line with previous findings showing positive relations between conspiratorial thinking and use of PSPs (Čavojová et al., 2020; Oliver & Wood, 2014), nonadherence to medical or public health recommendations (Imhoff & Lamberty, 2020; Oliver &
strengthens the view of conspiratorial beliefs as a part of “contaminated mindware” (Rizeq et al., 2020; Stanovich et al., 2016) or unwarranted beliefs detrimental to one’s rational thought process, thus influencing decisions that may lead to detrimental health outcomes. In our study, the relation between conspiratorial beliefs and unwillingness to get vaccinated against COVID19 was particularly strong. Importantly, this relation held even the total score in this model deliberately excluded vaccination conspiracy theory, leaving instead a number of theories about the origin of the virus and political abuse of the health crisis that do not necessarily lead to vaccine refusal. For example, it may be possible that a person believes that the virus was fabricated in a laboratory, but still considers it dangerous and is willing to protect themselves with a vaccine. Our data, however, show that even such beliefs are related to a weaker vaccination intention. This could be due to a more general assumption common to both phenomena: that key information, such as the truth about the harmfulness of vaccines or about the source of pandemic, is hidden from the general public and that one cannot trust official sources (Wood et al., 2012; Lukić et al., 2019).
Other irrational beliefs were also somewhat predictive of the health behaviors. While
Type I error cognitive biases were directly related (zero order correlation) only to PSPs, after controlling for other irrational beliefs in the regression analyses, they positively predicted each health behavior. This seemingly surprising finding may be due to the cost asymmetry between false-positive and false-negative errors (Haselton & Buss, 2000) particularly in critical situations such as a global pandemic. More precisely, the cost of a type II error – refraining from preventive practices that may result in an avoidable COVID-19 infection – could be perceived as higher than the cost of a type I error – following ineffective practices. Thus, the susceptibility
associated with opting to uncritically pursue any health recommendation.
We also found that, to a lesser degree, those that rely on cognitive intuition and follow
their “gut feelings” may be more susceptible to pseudoscientific advice as well as being more relaxed when it comes to following evidence-based recommendations. Finally, those who overestimated their COVID-19 knowledge reported lesser engagement in recommended behavior, but were also somewhat less prone to using PSPs.
Both content-laden and content-independent irrational beliefs were to some degree
predictive of COVID-19 health behaviors. Conspiratorial beliefs regarding COVID-19, as a content-laden irrational belief, was most strongly tied to all three types of behaviors; however, susceptibility to type I error cognitive biases also proved to be significant for all three outcomes, after controlling for other predictors. This is important, as the effects of content-independent irrational beliefs may have the potential to be generalized to various types of behaviors, beyond the pandemic. However, the relative power of content-independent beliefs to predict health outcomes, in comparison to content-laden ones, remains to be studied further.
Of note, adherence to COVID-19 guidelines was the most weakly predicted health
behavior. A relatively modest predictive power of irrational beliefs on adherence to COVID-19 guidelines might be due to ceiling effects that have likely resulted from lockdown policies and campaigns (e.g., #StayAtHome), both world-wide and locally. This has left people with fewer behavioral choices, particularly with regards to social distancing. On the other hand, engaging in PSPs was optional and may have permitted greater influence of intrinsic dispositions, including irrational beliefs, on health behaviors. Similarly, at the time of data collection, there was no vaccine developed against COVID-19, meaning that no vaccination policies were in place. In
This may have led to a greater influence of intrinsic dispositions on the outcome.
Strengths, limitations, and suggestions for future work
Our study adds to the existing literature in several ways. First, we put together a
comprehensive battery of irrational beliefs to predict health behaviors, which allowed us to compare their predictive power. Second, we examined different types of health behaviors pertaining to evidence-based and non-evidence-based recommendations related to the COVID19 pandemic. In addition, the instruments we developed for their assessment proved to be discriminative and reliable. Third, the fact that the data were collected during the peak of the pandemic (Serbia Coronavirus, n.d.) adds to their validity.
Several limitations merit comment. The fact that only behaviors included in official
guidelines were assessed, precluded other preventive behaviors, such as wearing masks or gloves. Importantly, the guidelines were supported by lockdown policies, which may have reduced the variability and influence of irrational beliefs on these behaviors. In addition, the health behaviors were self-reported. Future studies could examine observed behaviors (e.g., assessing social distancing using location tracking apps) to increase the confidence attached to the current findings. This study addressed the question of content overlap between predictors (irrational beliefs) and criteria (health behaviors). To further disentangle the differential effects of content-laden and content-independent beliefs, following studies need to include more diverse representatives of both types of beliefs and compare their relative contribution. This may be useful to inform future interventions targeting beliefs – for example, the relative importance of targeting cognitive belief systems versus health communication regarding a particular content.

Nonetheless, this and other assessments included in our study revealed meaningful relations between irrational beliefs, namely conspiratorial thinking, and relevant health behaviors during the COVID-19 pandemic.
The rapid proliferation of COVID-19 related misinformation through social media
(Depoux et al., 2020; Kouzy et al., 2020; Mian & Khan, 2020; Zarocostas, 2020) may have the potential to substantially impact health outcomes. We propose that future interventions should focus on conspiracy theories, which, in our study, were detrimental for a range of preventive health behaviors. Some of the promising interventions to counter science misinformation and conspiracy theories include presenting people with factual corrections (e.g., Porter et al., 2018; Porter et al., 2019), combining factual corrections with personal/social narratives (Lazić & Žeželj, under review), “inoculating” them by presenting anti-conspiracy information prior to conspiracy theories (e.g., Jolley & Douglas, 2017), and exposing misleading argumentation techniques (e.g., Roozenbeek & van der Linden, 2019).

content.heading: Conclusion
content.text:
A starting point for social and behavioral sciences to mitigate the effects of global
pandemics (Van Bavel et al., 2020) is to understand the psychological underpinnings of health behaviors during the course of the crisis. Our study highlights that people prone to a particular set of irrational beliefs are less likely to follow official COVID-19 guidelines and more likely to engage in PSPs. Once again, and strongly corroborating our hypotheses, conspiracy theories have shown to pose a serious threat to public health – one that demands future attention to
intuition and COVID-19 knowledge overestimation was less robust, but mostly in line with initial expectations. Somewhat unexpectedly, susceptibility to type I error cognitive biases predisposed people to engage in any type of preventive behavior, whether it is evidence-based or not. Together, the findings show that irrational beliefs are an important factor to consider when tailoring behavioral health policies, especially in a global health crisis.
