content.text:
We examined whether scientific reasoning predicts health-related beliefs and behaviors over
and above the general analytic thinking ability in general public (N = 783, aged between 18 –
84 years). Health-related beliefs included: the anti-vaccination attitudes, conspiracy beliefs
related to the COVID-19 disease, and some generic epistemically suspect beliefs related to
health. Scientific reasoning predicted generic pseudoscientific and conspiracy beliefs related
to health and also conspiracy beliefs related specifically to COVID-19. Crucially, scientific
reasoning was a stronger independent predictor of unfounded beliefs (including anti-
vaccination attitudes) than general analytic thinking, however, its role in the health-related
behaviors was more modest.
Key words: scientific reasoning, analytic thinking, conspiracy beliefs related to COVID-19,
anti-vaccination attitudes, preventive behavior, COVID-19
reasoning not only for dealing with global challenges, such as climate change and its consequences but also for their informed decision-making related to consumer behavior or health. But never has the importance of scientific reasoning been so crucial as in the current crisis launched by the COVID-19 outbreak in more than 100 countries.
People are presented with statistics, medical terms, new insights both by experts and nonexperts from various fields ranging from virology to economics, they are more than ever invested in watching closely the process of finding the cure/vaccine for SARS-CoV-2 virus, all in the context of great uncertainty. However, as always in times of crisis, many false and ambivalent information occur and people need to sift through them and make important decisions regarding their safety and safety of others. It has been already shown that scientific reasoning is linked to lesser susceptibility to cognitive biases and unfounded beliefs (Čavojová et al., 2020) and lower belief in the efficacy of alternative medicine (Čavojová & Ersoy, 2019b). Building on this line of work, we examined the effect of scientific reasoning on a broader range of health-related behavior and beliefs in the context of the recent COVID19 outbreak.
Scientific reasoning vs. knowledge of science
First, we should make clear that by scientific reasoning we do not mean simply having more science knowledge. Rather, we use the term scientific reasoning to signify the ability to understand methods and principles of scientific inquiry and skills required to formulate, test and revise theories and reflect the process of generating evidence; or, more specifically, as the “application of the methods or principles of scientific inquiry to reasoning or problem-solving situations“ (Zimmerman, 2007, p. 173, see also Koslowski, 1996; Kuhn & Franklin, 2007; Wilkening & Sodian, 2005). In this sense, scientific reasoning is a subset of critical thinking
scientists only. Although the majority of people will not earn their living by doing science, to be scientifically literate (i.e. to be able to reason scientifically) is beneficial when we want to properly function in society (Trefil, 2008). This is true especially now when we need to distinguish reliable information related to the outbreak of COVID-19 from disinformation and engage in effective preventive measures against it.
Although studies directly examining the role of scientific reasoning and scientific literacy in actual health-decisions are rather rare, there is ample evidence that people with better scientific reasoning hold beliefs more consistent with the scientific consensus. For example, more scientifically literate people were more likely to believe that vaccines and genetically modified foods are safe; to believe in human evolution; or to believe in the Big Bang theory (Drummond & Fischhoff, 2017).
A positive relationship between scientific reasoning and holding more beliefs consistent with scientific consensus may be because people who are interested in science, have generally more knowledge about science. Research, indeed, suggests that this is the case. People with better scientific reasoning tend to have also more science-related knowledge (Dieckmann & Johnson, 2019; Downs et al., 2008; Drummond & Fischhoff, 2017; Kaygısız & Gürkan, 2018). On the other hand, the relationship between knowledge of science facts (e.g. to know how much time it takes for Earth to revolve around the Sun, or what is an atom) and scientific understanding (e.g. to understand the principles of gravity and how they apply to the movement of planetary bodies) is not so straightforward – while the two are correlated, their correlations are modest at best (Johnson, 2003). This also suggests that assessing science understanding only through the knowledge-based tests has its limits. This issue was addressed recently by Drummon and Fischhof (2017) who devised the Scientific Reasoning Scale (SRS), consisting of eleven short scenarios designed to measure a person’s ability to evaluate
have good psychometric properties and it was successfully used and validated also in nonEnglish speaking countries (Bašnáková et al., n.d.; Kaygısız & Gürkan, 2018).
More importantly for the present study – besides having more general scientific knowledge, people with better scientific reasoning could also better interpret numerical information regarding the effectiveness and side effects of certain drugs (Drummond & Fischhoff, 2017). It suggests that people with better scientific reasoning do not simply know more scientific facts or conform more to scientific consensus, but that they can use the probabilistic and numerical information to make more informed choices about over-counter medication or health-related advice.
In a recent study, Drummond and Fischhoff (2019) found that priming scientific reasoning leads participants to evaluate evidence more critically. In the follow-up study they included another condition – priming general analytical thinking – but this time neither priming scientific reasoning nor priming analytical skills had any effect on myside bias. They concluded that when we want people to engage critically in evaluating evidence, it is not enough to rely on their general critical thinking skills, but their specific knowledge about scientific methodology is needed. Thus, in this paper, we will measure participants’ level of analytic thinking as well as their scientific reasoning and we expect that scientific reasoning will be a better predictor of various health-related behaviors and beliefs.
Scientific reasoning and unfounded beliefs
Understanding science by having more knowledge and/or better scientific reasoning skills is also reflected in more positive attitudes toward science and less epistemically suspect beliefs, i.e. paranormal, conspiracy, and pseudoscientific beliefs (e.g. Pennycook et al., 2015; Šrol, n.d.). This was shown in two studies using the SRS, in which scientific reasoning correlated
suspect beliefs (Čavojová et al., 2020). Although the connection between epistemically suspect beliefs and health-related behavior might not be visible, holding more unfounded and anti-science beliefs, especially those related to pseudoscientific treatments, can lead to poorer health choices. Wrong choices related to health care can have fatal consequences, as documented by health-related complications and deaths of children when parents refused vaccination and antibiotics (Liliana Barbacariu, 2014; Saint-Victor & Omer, 2013), when conventional treatment was refused or delayed (Boström & Rössner, 1990; S. B. Johnson et al., 2018), or when downright harmful treatment was chosen (Farrington et al., 2018; Robbins, 2010). On the other hand, people with higher scientific reasoning skills believe less in the efficacy of complementary and alternative medicine and use it less often (Čavojová & Ersoy, 2019a).
The more obvious connection between scientific reasoning and health-related behavior is visible when we look at vaccination as one example of health-related behavior. Scientific reasoning had a small positive effect on three facets of vaccine acceptance (Sarathchandra et al., 2018).
Thus, although we expect that scientific reasoning will predict attitudes toward vaccination in our sample, we were interested also in another related question. There is a very low percentage of people who get voluntarily vaccinated against preventable diseases, such as seasonal flu (about 5 % in Slovakia), despite it being covered by health insurance companies, so we wondered whether people will change their attitudes toward vaccination. Therefore, in this study, we also examine the question, whether people with negative attitudes toward vaccination would be eager to take vaccination against COVID-19 if it were available.
Similarly to the concept of science literacy, Zeyer (2012) introduces the concept of health literacy, which addresses the connection between science understanding and health-related behaviors more directly. He claims that health literacy is inherently knowledge-based and that this reveals a strong link between scientific literacy and health literacy. Neter and Brainin (2019) examined the relationship between health literacy and health outcomes in 80 published studies and they found a consistent negative association between health literacy and mortality, a positive association between health literacy and medication management/adherence, and other diverse health-related behaviors such as physical exercise, vaccinations, cancer screening, self-care, appointment keeping, or using an inhaler.
Based on this indirect evidence related to scientific reasoning and health-related behavior, we expected that people with higher scientific reasoning will engage in generally recommended preventive behavior and there will be few differences between preventive behaviors during the recent outbreak of COVID-19 and preventive behavior against seasonal diseases, such as flu. This was based on the reasoning that generic preventive measures, such as eating more fruits and vegetables and exercising, are generally valid as increasing the immune system and that people with better scientific reasoning would understand the necessity of a healthy lifestyle better. We also expected that scientific reasoning will predict engaging in less questionable preventive behaviors, such as drinking strong alcohol as a disinfectant due to a better understanding of the working of the immune system and the spreading of disease. Lastly, we expected that scientific reasoning will not predict recommended preventive measures, as these we pushed forward by authorities and thus following them was likely influenced more by contextual factors irrespective of scientific reasoning.
range of health-related beliefs and behaviors over and above the general analytic thinking ability. We included beliefs and behaviors related to health in general as well as some that were specifically related to the current COVID-19 pandemic. Among health-related beliefs, we examined the attitudes toward vaccinations, conspiracy beliefs related to the origin, spread and potential cure of the COVID-19 disease, and some generic epistemically suspect beliefs related to health. Furthermore, we asked participants about the preventive measures they take regarding the current COVID-19 disease threat and asked them whether they took the same preventive measures in the past against the common flu. Based on the evidence outlined above, we expected scientific reasoning to be a better predictor of these beliefs and behaviors that general analytic thinking ability.
Methods

content.heading: Participants
content.text:
The data were collected as part of a larger study on beliefs and behaviors related to the current COVID-19 pandemic. In a previous study (Šrol et al., 2020), we focused on feelings of anxiety and lack of control regarding the COVID-19 pandemic and their relationship to an increased endorsement of various epistemically suspect beliefs. Neither scientific reasoning nor healthrelated behaviors – which are the focus of the present study – were analyzed there. The present sample consisted of 976 participants who filled in the online survey created in Qualtrics either through a query on social media or via an invitation from a participant recruitment agency.
However, as 193 of these participants did not pass attention check controls, their data were therefore omitted from all further analyses. The final sample consisted of 783 participants (417 female, 363 male, 3 preferred not to disclose their gender) who filled in the questionnaire
between 13th and 22nd March 20201. Participants were aged between 18 – 84 years (M = 42.00, SD = 16.84). Concerning education, most of the sample reported having finished high school with diploma (38.2%), or that they attended college which they finished after obtaining bachelor’s (10.6%), master’s (39.5%), or doctoral degree (4.5%). The rest of the sample either finished high school without a diploma (4.7%) or attainted only elementary education (2.6%).

content.heading: Materials
content.text:
Descriptive statistics and internal consistency estimates for all materials can be found in Table 1.
Scientific reasoning and general analytic thinking ability.
Scientific reasoning. Scientific reasoning abilities were measured using items based on the Scientific reasoning scale by Drummond and Fischhoff (2017). For the present study, we used six items that were developed by Bašnáková et al. ( n.d.) and which measured these six validity threats: blinding, causations vs correlation, confounding variables, construct validity, control group, ecological validity, random assignment to conditions. For example, the “causation vs correlation” item was about increasing birth rate (A researcher wants to find out how to increase natality. He asks for statistical information and sees that there are more children born in cities that have more hospitals. This finding implies that building new hospitals will increase the birth rate of a population. Agree/Disagree). This shorter version of SRS was used because it was shown to be more reliable in the Slovak population than the original 11-item SRS (Bašnáková et al., n.d.).
1 During this period, there were 32 – 185 confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Slovakia. On the 16th of March the Slovak government initiated harsh preventive actions which gradually started to take place. These included limiting all personal foreign travel, compulsory quarantine for people who came from abroad, closing of schools and most non-essential shops and services.

Three of the items were taken from the original Cognitive reflection test by Frederick (2005), but we changed their content to reduce the possibility that participants were already exposed to the items and knew their correct answers. The other three items were taken from the verbal version of the Cognitive reflection test (Sirota et al., 2019). The items of the cognitive reflection test are often used as indicators of the analytic thinking ability (e.g. Bronstein, Pennycook, Bear, Rand, & Cannon, 2018; Pennycook & Rand, 2019). The sum of correct answers on the six items was used as a measure of participant’s analytic thinking ability.

content.heading: Health-related beliefs:
content.text:
Coronavirus-specific conspiracy beliefs. Participants were given 10 statements that described various conspiracy theories or typical conspiracist ideas concerning the outbreak, spread, and potential cure of the new coronavirus. The average rating on a 5-point scale on these ten items was used as the endorsement of coronavirus-specific conspiracy beliefs.
Coronavirus-specific knowledge. Besides coronavirus-specific conspiracy beliefs, we were interested in whether participants will be able to distinguish between true and false information about COVID-19, so we also included eight knowledge items (4 true, 4 false). These items were intermixed with the coronavirus-specific conspiracy belief statements and participants responded to them using the same 5-point scale. We calculated the average rating on four true knowledge items and the average rating on four false knowledge items.
Generic health-related epistemically suspect beliefs. To measure the endorsement of generic epistemically suspect beliefs, we selected 8 items for mostly pseudoscientific and conspiracy beliefs related to health from a questionnaire of epistemically suspect beliefs by Šrol (n.d.). The items dealt with the effectiveness of various alternative treatments (homeopathy, reiki, oral use
pharmaceutical industry. Participants were asked to rate their agreement with the statements on a 5-point scale. We used average rating on the eight items as a measure of generic health-related epistemically suspect beliefs.
Anti-vaccination attitudes. Ten items were used to measure negative attitudes toward vaccination. Six were adapted from Wallace et al. (2019) and four items were constructed by the authors. Participants indicated their agreement on a 5-point scale (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree). Higher scores indicated stronger anti-vaccination attitudes.
Self-reported behavior related to health:
Vaccination. We asked participants whether they are vaccinated against the flu. 8.4 % indicated that they were vaccinated, 10.6 % indicated that they intended to get vaccination but did not manage to do it before it was too late and 81 % of participants were not vaccinated. Because of the low percentage of vaccinated participants, for the further analyses, we joined into one category both those who received flu shots and those who intended to get flu shots. Also, participants had to indicate whether they would get a vaccination against the new coronavirus if the vaccination had been available, on a 5-point scale (1 = definitely yes, 5 = definitely no).
Preventive behavior. We measured preventive behavior by two sets of questions. First, we asked participants to indicate what preventive measures they take specifically against the coronavirus and then we asked them to indicate what preventive measures they take usually against seasonal diseases, such as flu. Each set contained the same 19 behaviors (washing hands for at least 20 seconds, coughing into tissues, disinfecting surfaces, etc.) and participants answered either “yes” (1) or “no” (0). Based on the participants՚ answers we calculated two scores for both coronavirus-specific and general preventive behaviors in this
home and, if possible, work from home), 9 items for non-standard or scientifically unfounded measures (e.g. I drink at least 52% alcohol as a disinfectant). The percentage of individual preventive behaviors that our participants engaged in are in the Appendix A.1.
The relationships among the main variables in the study are first examined through the correlation analysis. We inspect the correlations between scientific reasoning, analytic thinking, epistemically suspect beliefs (specifically related to coronavirus, as well as more general healthrelated unfounded beliefs), anti-vaccination attitudes, and preventive behaviors (recommended, as well as unfounded). Next, we present multiple linear regression analyses conducted to test whether the outcome variables (beliefs related to health, preventive behavior) can be predicted by scientific reasoning over and above general analytic thinking ability.
cognitive predictors (scientific reasoning and analytic thinking) correlate with health-related beliefs and knowledge and with self-reported health-related behavior.
Correlations between scientific reasoning & analytic thinking and health-related beliefs & knowledge
Our main interest was in correlations of scientific reasoning with our outcome variables. As expected, scientific reasoning correlated negatively with coronavirus-specific conspiracy beliefs, general health-related unfounded beliefs, and anti-vaccination attitudes. The same pattern of negative correlations occurred with general analytic thinking, however, all observed
between scientific reasoning and accepting false facts about coronavirus as true, and the same pattern was observed with analytic thinking. On the other hand, correctly accepting coronavirus facts as true correlated positively only with scientific reasoning, albeit weakly, while there was no correlation with analytic thinking. Generally, people were able to correctly identify the most facts about coronavirus, as reflected in descriptive scores in Table 1, but the stronger correlation with scientific reasoning may suggest that more scientifically sophisticated people looking for more detailed information about coronavirus and thus were able to better recognize facts from false information.
Correlations between scientific reasoning & analytic thinking and self-reported healthrelated behavior
Scientific reasoning also correlated negatively with non-standard preventive measures both against coronavirus and flu to a similar extent (r = –.21 and r = –.28, respectively), but it also correlated negatively with recommended measures against both against coronavirus and flu, although in this case, the correlation was much stronger for flu than coronavirus (r = –.30, r = –.08, respectively). Again, correlations with analytic thinking showed a similar pattern with only one exception – there was no correlation between analytic thinking and recommended measures against coronavirus.
Negative correlations between scientific reasoning and preventive behavior were surprising, especially in the case with flu. However, the reason for these results is probably the period2 when data were collected. The data collection was launched on March 13th, when only the
2 It should be also noted that this period was also marked by transition of power after general election that took place on February 29, when no cases of COVID-19 were reported in Slovakia.
information was presented in media – for instance regarding the protective use of facial surgical masks. While the first information in mainstream media was that WHO does not recommend wearing surgical masks for self-protection, as soon as on March 16th the Slovak government issued a requirement to wear surgical masks at all public places. Thus, the negative correlation between scientific reasoning and recommended behavior can reflect the reluctance of more scientifically sophisticate people to engage in global panic by challenging some of the recommended measures as not effective, while less scientifically sophisticated people might accept more measures without question. Moreover, we suspect that while the reported behavior against the coronavirus is quite reliable, the reported behavior against seasonal diseases might be biased by the ongoing situation. For example, 30.6 % of people reported that they wear masks not to infect others also during flu season, but it was hardly possible to see anyone with a mask in the public during the previous years. Therefore, for further analyses, we chose only non-standard preventive behavior against coronavirus.
We also performed t-tests to analyze the differences in scientific reasoning and analytic
thinking between those who got or intended to get vaccinated against the flu and those who did not. We did not find any significant differences in scientific reasoning (t = 0.72, p = .472) nor general analytic thinking (t = -.0.83, p = .405) between the two groups.
Interestingly, neither we found any correlation between scientific reasoning and analytic thinking and the hypothetical question about willingness to get a vaccination against coronavirus was the vaccination available. This caught our attention and we performed several more exploratory analyses. We found a strong correlation between anti-vaccination attitudes and reluctance to take hypothetical vaccination against coronavirus (r = .45, p < .001), which suggests that people are quite consistent and generalize their reservations against vaccination also to the hypothetical new vaccination against coronavirus.
While correlational analyses above showed that both general analytic thinking and scientific reasoning play a role in measured health-related beliefs and preventive behavior, they were mutually correlated. Next, we wanted to examine whether the general analytic thinking and scientific behavior will both independently predict health-related beliefs. To reduce the number of analyses, we computed a composite score for health-related beliefs. For the first regression analysis, the composite score was calculated as the average score of all items comprising the three scales (coronavirus-specific conspiracy theories, health-related epistemically suspect beliefs and anti-vaccination attitudes). The composite score showed excellent internal reliability (M = 2.12, SD = .69, α = .93). For the second regression analysis, as an outcome variable, we used only non-standard preventive behaviors against coronavirus, because of the problems with the self-reported behavior described earlier.
In our regression analyses (Table 3) analytic thinking together with scientific reasoning explained 21.2 % of total variance for health-related beliefs and 5 % of total variance for nonstandard preventive behavior. Crucially, scientific reasoning emerged as a stronger predictor in comparison with analytic thinking in both regression analyses. This suggests that even though the effect of scientific reasoning seems to be stronger for epistemically suspect beliefs
think analytically.
Discussion
In this paper, we examined the effect of scientific reasoning on a broader range of healthrelated behavior and beliefs in the context of the recent COVID-19 outbreak. The most important finding of our study is that scientific reasoning predicts not only general pseudoscientific and conspiracy beliefs related to health – as was shown already in previous research (Čavojová et al., 2020; Čavojová & Ersoy, 2019b) – but also conspiracy beliefs related specifically to COVID-19. Crucially, scientific reasoning was a stronger independent predictor of unfounded beliefs (including anti-vaccination attitudes) than general analytic thinking. This result brings further support for the model of rationality proposed by Stanovich (2011) in that knowledge and understanding of science is at least as important as the propensity to engage in analytical thinking. Similarly, as other previous studies (Čavojová et al., 2020; Drummond & Fischhoff, 2019) we showed that scientific reasoning mindware is indispensable and it predicts health-related beliefs and behavior over the general tendency to think analytically.
More scientifically sophisticated people could better navigate through the constantly updating information about the coronavirus and evaluate which information are more likely to be true and what are conspiracy theories, as reflected by negative correlations with coronavirusspecific conspiracy beliefs and general health-related unfounded beliefs. They also showed fewer anti-vaccination attitudes and the knowledge of how vaccination works could probably help them to understand the news about the new coronavirus better.
Deeper understanding probably led also to a lower number of unfounded preventive behaviors – such as drinking 52% alcohol to disinfect “from the inside”, spraying chlorine around, or
decrease superstitious thinking and false analogies that form the bases of many harmful treatments (like drinking industrial bleach to get rid of internal parasites and viruses).
On the other hand, higher scientific reasoning also led to a lower number of recommended preventive measures, such as wearing masks, disinfecting household surfaces, and staying home. The observed negative relationship between scientific reasoning and self-reported preventive behavior has several possible explanations. It should be noted that the data collection took place during the most turbulent time in Slovakia – the outbreak of COVID-19 intersected with the transition of power from one government to the next and as the numbers of positively diagnosed patients began to increase, the new measures were introduced almost every day.
Thus, the negative relationship between scientific reasoning and the number of self-reported recommended preventive measures taken against COVID-19 could reflect the skepticism of more scientifically sophisticated people against some of the measures and reluctance to engage in panicky behavior. While some reports in the media stressed the emergency of the situation by pointing to a total number of deaths and situation getting out of hand in Italy, more cautious voices stressed the relatively low mortality rate by comparing the numbers to death rates caused by other diseases, such as flu and TBC. Understanding the numbers better and ability to evaluate the scientific evidence may lead scientifically more sophisticated people to rationalize their theories about the virus or to underestimate the risk of the virus, which is in line with other evidence for motivated reasoning in more sophisticated participants, when it comes to emotionally hot topics, such as politics and climate change (Kahan et al., 2012; Lodge & Taber, 2007).
This explanation could be supported also by our results related to vaccination behavior (getting a flu shot and eagerness to get vaccinated against the coronavirus). Interestingly, even
no difference in scientific reasoning (and general analytic thinking) between those who got or intended to get vaccinated against the flu this year and those who did not. It suggests that probably other factors – either emotional or contextual – are more important in the decision to get vaccinated. It may also reflect relatively low perceived risk of contracting the flu. Similarly, neither higher scientific reasoning nor general analytic thinking was related to the eagerness to get vaccinated against the new coronavirus if such vaccination would be possible. These results suggest that perceived risk of contracting the disease and experience severe symptoms may be more important for considering voluntary vaccinations.
Another possible explanation is that our way of measuring preventive behaviors was not reliable enough, as participants only indicated “yes” and “no” answers and in just a few days some of the preventive behaviors became the social norm irrespective of personal attitudes toward that norm. Thus, the number of self-reported preventive behaviors can reflect more contextual than individual factors.
This is also the main limitation of our study that due to the evolving situation we need to take the results about self-reported preventive behavior with caution. At the same time, we consider it also the main strength of our research, because it offers a glimpse of how scientific reasoning is useful during crisis times like we are currently experiencing, as it enables people to evaluate new evidence and not to fall prey to conspiracy theories and beliefs. Our findings have relevant consequences also for science education as they highlight the necessity of having sufficient scientific “mindware” to be able to navigate in the sea of rapidly updating information and evidence – not only for laypeople but even more so for decision-makers, who should understand the need to base the policies and protective measures on relevant scientific evidence.

content.text:
The unexpected COVID-19 outbreak and subsequent lockdown impositions are having a significant impact on people’s day-to-day life, confronting Western countries with hitherto unknown contagion threats and restrictions on freedoms. Given the serious effects of stress on physical and mental health, the stressful impact of the COVID-19 emergency represents an important public health issue. The present study assessed the stressful impact of the COVID-19 epidemic in Italy, identifying possible mediators of perceived stress (sociodemographic variables and stable psychological traits). High levels of perceived stress were found in the Italian population. Being female, having low income and living with other people were associated with higher levels of stress. Higher rates of emotional stability, self-control, positive coping style and internal locus of control were protective factors against psychological distress. These results may provide indications for early and targeted prevention and intervention programs.
Key words: stress, COVID-19, pandemic, epidemic, psychological distress, mental health

content.heading: Introduction
content.text:
SARS-Cov-2 (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus-2) is a strain of coronavirus that can infect humans, attacking the lungs and causing a range of symptoms from the common cold to Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)1. About 80% of the population recover with no special treatment (asymptomatic or mild pneumonia)2, while recent data confirmed that older people (>60 years old)3 and persons with previous specific medical conditions are more likely to develop serious respiratory distress that can lead to death (3-4%)4. The virus spreads very easily from person to person and, at the time of writing, no drugs or biologics have been proven to be effective for the prevention or treatment of COVID-19, the disease associated to SARS-Cov-25,6. SARS-Cov-2 was identified for the first time in the Chinese region of Wuhan in December 20196. Between December 2019 and April 2020, COVID-19 spread throughout the world, causing more than 2,300,000 infections and over 150,000 deaths7. On 11 March 2020, the World Health Organization (WHO) declared COVID-19 a pandemic8. To contain the number of the victims and prevent a collapse of the healthcare system, most countries’ national governments imposed strict restrictions on citizens’ freedoms, forcing people infected by the virus into self-isolation, and requiring everyone (infected or not) to stay at home, allowing movements in public only for reasons of absolute necessity. Among Western countries, the Italian government was the first to apply such restrictions, following Asian countries like China and South Korea, which were the first to deal with the COVID-19 emergency7. On 8 March 2020, the first “red zones” in Italy were locked down9. A few days later, the Italian government locked down the entire country, imposing10: i) self-isolation for everyone testing positive for SARS-Cov-2, even if asymptomatic and for anyone (e.g. roommates, family members) in close contact with them; ii) closure of all public places, including schools, restaurants, parks, and shopping centres; iii) the suspension of work activity or the activation of working from home, except for professional categories providing work essential for the community (e.g., healthcare, grocery stores, gas stations, law enforcement, production of basic
necessities); iv) a ban on leaving the home except for important reasons. As concerns the last point, only the following activities were considered sufficiently important: going to work (only for people providing one of the aforementioned essential services); grocery shopping (just one person per family with restricted frequency); health care needs; taking pets outside; jogging (these last three activities were later further restricted, allowing movement only within 200 metres from home to prevent people from using them to evade the restriction to stay at home).

content.heading: The psychological impact of the pandemic
content.text:
A few weeks after the spread of COVID-19 in China, the first scientific studies investigating the psychological impact of the outbreak highlighted that a significant percentage of the Chinese population reported mild to severe psychological impacts of the event (53.8%) with negative consequences on mental health such as anxiety, depressive symptoms and stress11,12. More broadly, the literature on the mental health response to infection outbreaks reports that pandemics are extremely stressful events, as people find themselves having to cope with totally unexpected, ambiguous and uncertain situations13. Two main aspects affect people’s mental state during pandemics. The first regards danger, i.e. the fear of contagion, which can lead to an increment in the perceived threat and sometimes to panic, behavioural contagion and emotional epidemic14,15. In this, a significant role is played by overexposure to the media: while the media can contribute to conveying a correct perception of the risk to the public, promoting healthy behaviours16, it can also generate confusion, psychological distress and panic, due to the broadcasting of speculative data and disturbing images17. The second aspect regards the multiple and rapid changes that occur in social, working and familiar habits, due to the self-isolation and social distancing measures imposed18,19. The longer the duration of self-isolation, the more frustration and boredom, along with concerns about infection, were identified as the major stressors during the isolation period18. Moreover, the importance of
providing adequate information on restrictive measures has been highlighted, to ensure that selfisolation is perceived as a voluntary and altruistic choice rather than a constraint imposed by law18. Well-documented psychological reactions to epidemics are emotional distress, anxiety-related behaviours, sleeping disorders, fear, anger, depression, health concerns, a sense of powerlessness and uncertainty14,19–24. Furthermore, studies examining the long-term consequences of infectious epidemics have shown that some individuals go so far as to develop symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD)13,25. One review indicated that post-traumatic stress symptoms may even persist for three years after the epidemic has ended18,23.
Stress is defined as an adaptive psycho-physical reaction in response to a physical, social or psychological stimulus, called “stressor”26. Stress-related responses are cognitive, emotional, behavioural and physiological. Depending on the type, timing and severity of exposure to stressful stimuli, stress may be a potential risk factor for a number of diseases, including psychiatric and cardiovascular ones27–31. An emergency like the COVID-19 outbreak can rightly be considered a severe stressor as a new and unexpected situation with serious potential effects on the health of oneself and one’s loved ones that is combined with social restrictions14. Nevertheless, events are not, in and of themselves, the precipitating cause of pathology and illness behaviour. The perception of stress, i.e. the degree to which one considers the situation as being stressful, accounts more for the varying responses to potentially stressful events32. In this sense, it might be important to implement strategies to detect vulnerable persons early and to promote effective prevention programs in order to treat them rapidly and limit future negative psychological outcomes. Therefore, identifying possible psychosocial risk and resilience factors for psychological distress due to the COVID-19 emergency is a significant step for health prevention and promotion33.
Risk and protective factors of psychological outcomes of the pandemic Studies related to the impact of COVID-19 in the Chinese population found that the psychological reaction to the outbreak was mediated by sociodemographic variables (e.g., gender, age, education
level and social connections)11,12,24,34,35. Sociodemographic risk factors for psychological distress included gender (female), age (18-30 or >60 years old), student status, education level, perception of the public health system, specific physical symptoms (e.g. coryza, cough, sore throat, headache) and a low reported level of health11,24,34. Considering just the student population, having an infected parent, economic hardships or delayed academic activities increased the risk of developing anxiety symptoms12. On the other hand, protective sociodemographic factors against psychological distress were: receiving accurate information (e.g., health information on the epidemic) and adopting preventive measures11. For Chinese students, living in urban areas, a stable family income, living with parents and good social support were found to be protective factors against anxiety12.
In addition to sociodemographic factors, a number of psychological constructs may also mediate individual reactions to a pandemic. Many studies have outlined the role of certain dispositional traits in modulating people’s responses to stressful events. One of the most highly studied resilience factors is the coping strategy. Coping is defined as one’s effort to solve personal and interpersonal problems in order to seek to master, minimize or tolerate stress and conflicts36. Distinct coping strategies are associated differently with emotional response37, physiological stress response38 and self-efficacy39,40. Investigations into the role of coping strategies in facing virus outbreaks found coping style influenced the perceived risk of contagion and vaccination intentions among Canadian adults during the 2009 H1N1 flu pandemic41. Coping strategies were also found to be associated with post-traumatic outcomes within the general population visiting community health care services during the national outbreak of SARS in Singapore23. As concerns emotional self-regulation and adaptation between self and the world, self-control may represent a significant protective factor. Empirical evidence indicates that people with high dispositional self-control have better outcomes in both psychological adjustment and impulse control42, suggesting that good self-control mitigates the influence of a negative environment.
Similarly, perceived control over life outcomes has been shown to be positively related to wellbeing and health-related quality of life, and negatively associated with emotional distress when faced with stressful events43,44. In this regard, the “locus of control”45 is the degree to which people believe that they have control over the outcome of events in their lives, as opposed to external forces beyond their control. Another significant factor influencing both personal risk perception of the epidemic threat and compliance with self-isolation restrictions might be Consideration of Future Consequences (CFC)46. Individual differences in CFC reflect “the extent to which people consider the potential distant outcomes of their current behaviours and the extent to which they are influenced by these potential outcomes”46. A meta-analysis indicated that CFC is an important construct to consider in research on health behaviours, as it is associated with intended and actual engagement in three health-related behaviours: health risk, health promotion and illness preventive behaviour47. Finally, among individual difference variables that might influence people’s reactions to COVID19, personality traits deserve attention. Several studies have highlighted an association between the Big Five personality traits48 and various health behaviours, such as sedentary behaviour49, sexual health50, physical activity51 and alcohol involvement52.
As reported above, several studies have investigated the psychological impact of COVID-19 on the Chinese population. However, it is important to remember that each country differs from others in many respects, such as social, cultural, political and economical aspects, to name just a few. Consequently, psychological responses may also vary within different contexts and communities, revealing peculiar qualitative and quantitative psychological reactions and psychological needs. For this reason, the present work analyses the psychological impact of the COVID-19 emergency in one Western country, Italy. It is worth noting that this is the first time since the last century that many Western countries are facing pandemic and mandatory self-isolation. The first aim of this study was to investigate the stressful impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and of the subsequent restrictions
imposed by the Italian government. The second aim was to investigate the association between certain stable psychological traits and people’s psychological distress to the emergency. To this end, participants were tested for coping strategies, self-control, consideration of future consequences, locus of control and personality traits. Sociodemographic variables were also considered as mediators. Moreover, with the final goal of anticipating treatment and improving the targeting and effectiveness of preventive interventions, we developed a predictive model for individual psychological responses to the COVID-19 pandemic, in terms of high or low perceived stress levels.

content.heading: Measures
content.text:
An ad hoc online questionnaire was designed to investigate the relation between behavioural and psychological reactions to the COVID-19 emergency and individual psychological traits. The questionnaire was organized in different sections that assessed the following:
• sociodemographic data: gender, age, education, cohabitation status, number of cohabitants,
employment status before and during the lockdown, family/cohabitation monthly income
• health condition: presence of pathologies enhancing the risk for COVID-19
• contact history with COVID-19: personal screening status (swab), possible personal positivity
status and disease course (hospitalization), positivity status and hospitalization of close people, loss of close people having died of COVID-19
• perception of the risks related to COVID-19: risk perception of contracting and transmitting
COVID-19, estimated possibility of avoiding COVID-19 infection, degree of concern for loved ones, degree of attention to physical symptoms
• perception of changes to daily life: degree of perception of change to emotional life, family life,
social life, work and daily life in general, and degree of feeling a limitation of personal freedom
• need for psychological support
• influence of the media and of active searches for information: frequency of actively seeking
information on COVID-19, main source of information
• compliance with restrictive measures: going out only when necessary, taking a walk in defiance
of the ban, going grocery shopping unnecessarily in defiance of the ban
• attitudes toward the future: perspective on the future resolution of COVID-19, considering
COVID-19 an opportunity for growth
An English version of the entire set of questions is available in the following repository: 10.5281/zenodo.3753552.
Subsequently, six standardized questionnaires were administered:
• The Italian Version of the ten-item Perceived Stress Scale (PSS-10)53. This is the most widely
used psychological instrument for measuring the perception of stress. Subjects were asked to answer ten questions on the frequency of stressful situations during the last month on a fivepoint scale (from 0=“Never” to 4=“Very often”)54,55. Examples of items are: “In the last month, how often have you been upset because of something that happened unexpectedly?”, “In the last month, how often have you felt that you were unable to control the important things in your life?”. Higher scores indicate higher levels of experienced stress. Moreover, in the present study, the score corresponding to 1.5 SD above the Italian population average score53 was used as a cut-off to divide participants into two classes: low level (Male PSS-10 score < 24.35; Female PSS-10 score < 24.55) and high level (Male PSS-10 score ≥ 24.35; Female PSS score10 ≥ 24.55) of perceived stress.
• The Italian Shortened Version of the Coping Orientations to the Problems Experienced (COPE-
NVI-25)56. This is a multi-dimensional inventory assessing individual differences in coping styles using 25 items rated on four-point scale, ranging from 1 (“I usually don’t do this at all”) to 4 (“I usually do this a lot”)57. The instrument distinguishes five different scales
corresponding to five different coping styles: social support, avoidance strategies, positive attitude, problem solving and turning to religion58. Example of items are: “I admit to myself that I can’t deal with it, and quit trying” (avoidance strategies), “I try to grow as a person as a result of the experience” (positive attitude). Higher scores in each scale indicate higher use of that specific coping strategy. In this study, the scales were also grouped into two major categories: functional coping and dysfunctional coping. According to the literature, positive attitude and problem solving are considered functional coping styles, as they are associated with selfefficacy, less distress, major psychological wellbeing, better quality of life and better ability to handle stress. On the other hand, social support, avoidance and turning to religion are considered dysfunctional coping styles, as they are not correlated with psychological wellbeing. Avoidance strategies, in particular, are associated with emotional distress and reduction of quality of life56,58.
• The Italian translation of the Brief Self-Control Scale (BSCS)42. This instrument measures
individual differences in the dispositional capacity for self-control using 13 items rated on a five-point scale, ranging from 1 (“Not at all”) to 5 (“Very much”). Examples of items are: “I do certain things that are bad for me, if they are fun” and “I am able to work effectively toward long-term goals”. Higher scores in the BSCS indicate a higher capacity for self-control and are correlated with better psychological adjustment, better interpersonal skills and better emotional responses42. In this paper, two subscales, reflecting two structure factors, were also taken into account: General self-discipline (GSD, nine items) and Impulse control (IC, four items)59,60. The first subscale measures a tendency to be disciplined and engage in effortful control, while the second measures resistance to short-term rewards or temptations to realize long-term objectives59,60.
• The Italian translation of the Consideration of Future Consequences Scale (CFC)46. This is a
twelve-item scale using five-point ratings, ranging from 1 (“extremely uncharacteristic”) to 5 (“extremely characteristic”) assessing the extent to which people emphasize the short-term or
long-term consequences of their current behaviours and the extent to which they are influenced by imagined outcomes. Examples are “I consider how things might be in the future and try to influence those things with my day-to-day behaviour” and “I am willing to sacrifice my immediate happiness or well-being in order to achieve future outcomes”. Individuals scoring highly on the CFC scale typically focus on the future implications of their behaviour, whereas those with a low score on the CFC typically focus more on their immediate needs and concerns46.
• The Italian Short Version of the Locus of Control (LOC) Scale61. This is a twenty-item
questionnaire developed to measure people’s generalized expectancies for internal versus external control of reinforcement rated on dichotomous options (“Yes”, “No”) similar to the original Rotter’s Internal-External locus of control scale45. Examples are: “To do well in life, luck is more important than commitment”, “In sports, the best always wins in the long run”. Subjects with an internal locus of control (higher score in Internal LOC Scale) tend to attribute outcomes they achieve in life, and events in general, to their behaviours, whereas those with a prevalent external locus of control (higher score in External LOC Scale) tend to attribute events to fate, to others or to other external causes45,62.
• The Italian Version of the ten-item Big Five Inventory (BFI-10)63. This instrument assesses
personality traits according to the Five Factor approach64. It uses ten items rated on a five-point scale, ranging from 1 (“strongly disagree”) to 5 (“strongly agree”) to measure five dimensions of personality: extraversion, agreeableness, conscientiousness, neuroticism (or, if reversed, emotional stability) and openness65. Examples are: “I see myself as someone who is outgoing, sociable” (extraversion) and “I see myself as someone who tends to be lazy” (conscientiousness). The higher the score on a scale, the more that specific dimension represents a characteristic trait of the subject’s personality.
The complete list of 74 variables that were extracted from the responses to the questionnaire is reported in supplementary information. The experiment was designed in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki.

content.heading: Participants
content.text: Data were collected between 20 and 31 March 2020. Participants were recruited online through a request on social media to join the research. They were asked to complete an anonymous online questionnaire regarding their personal experience with the COVID-19 emergency and their mental state. Inclusion criteria were: living in Italy at the time of data collection and being of age of majority. All participants were required to read and provide informed consent before beginning the online questionnaire. They received no compensation for participation. Two thousand seventy-two volunteers took part in the study. Of the 2072 participants, 19 were excluded for responding to the questionnaire twice, keeping only the first response of each of these participants. The final sample consisted of 2 053 participants, of which 1 555 females, 480 males and 18 “other”. The average age was 35.81 (SD=13.19, range 18-83) and the average education level was 15.35 (SD=3.43, range 5- 21). A more detailed description of the demographic characteristics of the sample is provided in the supplementary information. It has been calculated that a sample size of 2053 is sufficiently large to achieve, in a linear multivariable regression analysis with 18 predictors, at least a statistical power (1-β)=0.90, given a significance level α=.05 and an effect size 0.36466. Data are available in the following depository: 10.5281/zenodo.3753552.

content.heading: Statistics
content.text:
Data analysis was performed using JASP software67. The one sample t-test (t, two-sided) was performed in relation to the PSS-10 score to determine whether the sample true mean (μ) was statistically different from the known population mean (m0).
We ran a multivariable regression analysis to investigate the relationship between the PSS-10 score and the independent variables that have been hypothesized having an impact on the level of perceived stress. The collinearity assumption was checked before running the model. The analysis was performed using the stepwise variable selection method. This approach identified the predictors when their individual association with the outcome (PSS10) was significant (p<0.05). Results were reported using unstandardized coefficients, as recommended by Friedrich68. Pearson’s product-moment correlation (r) was adopted (or the point-biserial correlation (rpb) when one of the two variables was dichotomous) to further investigate the strength of the relation between each independent variable, especially those not explored by previous studies, and the level of perceived stress. The significance threshold of the p-value was set at .05, being explicit when the value was <.01 and <.001. Confidence intervals were also reported. The normality of the distribution of all variables was checked by examining the distribution plots and Q-Q plots and calculating the values of skewness and kurtosis (a distribution was considered normal when skewness was within the range [- 2, 2] and kurtosis was within the range [-7, 7]69. Note that the results of the Shapiro-Wilk test were not taken into account as this test is notoriously affected by large sample size, giving significant results even for very small deviations from normal distribution70). Based on these criteria, all the investigated variables met the normality assumption. Finally, to avoid multiple comparison issues, we employed a least absolute shrinkage and selection operator (LASSO) approach71,72. This machine regression method selected a small subset of predictors that had a significant association with our continuous outcome, considering the complex correlation structure of the independent variables. As in the multivariable linear regression, this method provides an association between each variable with the outcome, but differently from the linear models, it shrinks the coefficients to zero when the variables are not associated with the endpoint. We implemented LASSO using the R-package HCDI, (R version 3.6.3). To enhance the consistency of our results, we computed 95% confidence intervals (95% CI) for each estimate with
1,000 bootstraps. The tuning of the LASSO parameter, which controlled for the amount of regularization applied to the estimates, was selected by 10-fold Cross-Validation.

content.heading: Classification models
content.text:
Recently, researchers in different scientific fields, including clinical and social sciences, have emphasized how it can be useful to focus on prediction rather than explanation when data are analysed73. Attention to predictive models has increased mainly thanks to the significant spread of machine learning (ML), a branch of artificial intelligence that deals with training algorithms on samples of data (training set) in order to make predictions on completely new data (test set) without being explicitly programmed74. As concerns psychology, machine learning techniques are particularly useful to predict human behaviour, including high-risk behaviours, in order to improve the effectiveness and targeting of prevention75. One of the main advantages of using ML is that, unlike traditional statistics, it makes it possible to build very complex models considering many predictors (or independent variables). A second benefit is that it makes it possible to make inferences at the individual level, while traditional statistical methods focus on the group level. In brief, ML models make it possible to predict the behaviour of the individual subject, so that attention can be paid to the most critical individuals73. In this paper, ML algorithms are trained on psychosocial data to identify people who are more likely to show a high level of perceived stress during the COVID-19 emergency, and who are also at greatest risk of future development of psychological symptoms, including post-traumatic symptoms. For this purpose, the participants were split into two classes: high level vs. low level of perceived stress. The “high level of perceived stress” class included participants who obtained a PSS score of more than 1.5 SD above the Italian population mean (n=393), respectively for males and females. Conversely, the “low level of perceived stress” class included participants performing no more than 1.5 SD above the Italian population normative value in the PSS-10 (n=1642). It should be remembered that participants who responded “other” to the gender question (n=18) were
excluded from this analysis, as Italian normative values for the PSS-10 are available only for males and females separately53. As ML models are built to fit the data, it is important to test how an existing model fits new unseen data. So, part of the data (training set) is generally used to train and validate the model, while another part (test set) is set aside to test the model accuracy on new examples that have never been seen by the ML classifier74,76. This procedure guarantees the generalization of the model and increases the replicability of results77,78. In this work, 20%74,76 of the participants were randomly chosen and retained as test set. Therefore, the training set consisted of 1628 participants (314 with a high level of perceived stress and 1314 with a low level of perceived stress) and the test set consisted of 407 participants (79 with a high level of perceived stress and 328 with a low level of perceived stress). First, a feature selection was performed. This is a widely used procedure in ML and consists of selecting the best subset of predictors in order to maximize model accuracy79. It makes it possible to remove redundant and irrelevant features and to increase model generalization by reducing overfitting and noise in the data80. A good strategy for feature selection is to identify the subset of features containing ones highly correlated with the class to predict, but that are not correlated with each other79. This procedure was performed here using the Correlation-Based Feature Selector (CFS) used in WEKA 3.981. Through running this algorithm, the best predictors were identified. The class imbalance problem was addressed while running the classification algorithms. The ratio between participants with a “high perceived stress level” and participants with a “low perceived stress level” is 1:4. It is known that ML methods work best with balanced datasets, and require that class imbalance be accounted for especially when available training examples are limited, a condition that is frequently met by datasets of a large number of domains, including health and clinical psychology82. Having a different number of instances in the two classes may lead to the overall correct classification of the examples of the majority class and the complete misclassification of the instances of the minority class. At the same time, it is equally important to
build the model on a sample that is representative of the population, maintaining a proportion of the classes that reflects its real distribution82. One strategy to overcome these limits consists of altering the relative costs associated to misclassifying the minority and the majority classes, so that it compensates for the imbalance ratio of the two classes83. Here, the ML algorithms were set in such a way that an error made by the algorithm in classifying the minority class (high perceived stress level) weights four times more than an error in classifying the majority class (low perceived stress level). The cost-modifying strategy has been shown to provide better results than other methods in addressing the class imbalance problem, such as random oversampling of the minority class or random undersampling of the majority class83. Moreover, it should also be noted that, for the goal of this task, it is more beneficial to obtain a lower number of false negatives rather than false positives or having a model with high sensitivity rather than high specificity. In other words, it is more important to not miss people at risk than to treat people who are not at risk. Then, different ML models were trained and validated on the training sample (n=1628) through a ten-fold cross-validation procedure using WEKA 3.9 software81. The different algorithms (Logistic regression84, Support Vector Machine85, Naïve Bayes86, Random forest87) were chosen to be representative of different classification strategies to ensure that the results were stable across classifiers and did not depend on specific model assumptions (details on ML classifiers parameters are reported in supplementary information). K-fold cross validation is a resampling procedure that seeks to reduce variance in the model performance estimation with respect to using a single training set and a single validation set, reducing model overfitting. Ten-fold cross-validation consists of portioning the sample in k=10 subsets (folds), using nine of them to train the model and the last one to validate its accuracy. This procedure is repeated k=10 times, leaving one fold out each time as a validation set88. The final metrics of the model is obtained by averaging the metrics obtained in the k=10 validation subsets. Finally, the models developed from ten-fold cross validation were tested on the test sample (n=407).

content.heading: Results
content.text:
The main results obtained by the data analysis are reported in this section. A more complete descriptive analysis of each variable, including the composition of the high vs. low perceived stress samples, is reported in supplementary information.
Perceived stress in response to the COVID-19 emergency On the Perceived Stress Scale (PSS-10), the average score of the entire sample of participants was 18.81 (SD=6.25). Analysing males’ and females’ responses separately (note that participants who responded “other” to the question on gender were excluded from this analysis due to a lack of normative data), males obtained an average score of 16.71 (SD=6.91) and females obtained an average score of 19.44 (SD=6.79). To determine whether the mean of the sample statistically differed from the Italian population normative value (males: average=15.2, SD=6.1; females: average=16.3, SD=5.5)53 a one-sample t-test was run separately for male and female groups. Statistically significant results emerged for both males (t(479)=4.79, p<.001, d=0.22, 95% CI for Cohen’s d [0.13, 0.31]) and females (t(1554)=18.21, p<.001, d=0.46, 95% CI for Cohen’s d [0.41, 0.51]). The items of the PSS-10 showing a greater increase in participants with a high level of perceived stress (1.5 SD above the population mean) are those related to the loss of control over one’s life (M=3.09, SD=0.80) and the frequency of feeling nervous or stressed (M=3.51, SD=0.60) (see supplementary information for an item-by-item analysis).

content.heading: Multivariable regression analysis
content.text:
A first multiple regression analysis was run including the sociodemographic variables that recent literature11,12,24,34,35 show may have an impact on the level of perceived stress during a pandemic. The PSS-10 score was set as the dependent variable, while gender (be male), age, education, monthly income, number of family members and student status (be student) were entered as covariates. The final model accounted for a significant proportion of the variance in the level of perceived stress (R2
= .103, Adjusted R2 = .101, F-change(1,2029) = 12.009, p<.001). All of the aforementioned variables, except for be student, were found to contribute to the level of perceived stress. Results are reported in Table 1.
To better understand the role of stable psychological traits in predicting the level of perceived stress (PSS-10 score), a second multiple linear regression was run, adding to the previous model the score to the five coping styles measured by the COPE-NVI-25 (COPE positive, COPE problem, COPE avoidance, COPE religion and COPE support), the CFC score, the BSCS total score, the internal locus of control score measured by the LOC scale (internal LOC) and the scores for the five personality traits measured by the BFI-10 scale (BFI-10 agreeableness, BFI-10 conscientiousness, BFI-10 emotional stability, BFI-10 extraversion and BFI-10 openness). This second model accounted for a larger proportion of the variance in the level of perceived stress (R2 = .364, Adjusted R2 = .360, F-change(1,2022) = 5.509, p<.05) compared to the previous one. BFI-10 emotional stability, COPE positive, age, BCSC total score, gender (be male), COPE avoidance, CFC score, internal LOC, number of family members, COPE support, monthly income and BFI-10 conscientiousness were found to be significant predictors of the level of perceived stress during the COVID-19 epidemic (see Table 2). Education, COPE religion, COPE problem solving, BFI-10 agreeableness, BFI-10 extraversion and BFI-10 openness were excluded.
