content.heading: Correlational analysis
content.text:
In a second step, a series of correlations were computed in order to investigate more deeply the relation between the level of perceived stress and all the 74 collected variables, especially those for which information is not available in the literature. Results of the correlations between the PSS-10 score and each variable are extensively reported in the supplementary information.
Relation between perceived stress and sociodemographic variables The results showed a statistically significant negative correlation between the PSS-10 score and gender (being male: rpb=-0.17, p<.001, 95% CI [-0.21, -0.13]), education years of education: r=0.05, p<.05, 95% CI [-0.09, -0.003]), and age (r=-0.26, p<.001, 95% CI [-0.30, -0.22]). Analysing people over 60, who have higher risks associated to COVID-19 infection, the results highlighted that being over 60 negatively correlates with the PSS-10 score (rpb=-0.15, p<.001, 95% CI [-0.20, - 0.11]). To investigate whether the lower level of stress of participants over the age of 60 could be related to a lower risk perception of these subjects, the relation between age and the reported perception to being at risk of COVID-19 (1= “not at all” , 5= “very much”) was tested, obtaining a statistically significant positive correlation (r=0.13, p<.001, 95% CI [0.08, 0.17]). As concerns social variables, a statistically significant negative correlation was found between the PSS-10 score and living alone instead of with family or roommates (rpb=-0.09, p<.001, 95% CI [- 0.13, -0.05]). Moreover, the number of family members (or cohabitants) was positively correlated
with the PSS-10 score (r=0.13, p<.001, 95% CI [0.09, 0.17]). Finally, the results indicated that family/cohabitation monthly income is negatively correlated with the PSS-10 score (r=-0.08, p<.001, 95% CI [-0.12, -0.04]). With respect to employment status before the COVID-19 emergency, a statistically significant negative correlation emerged between the PSS-10 score and being a public employee (rpb=-0.05, p<.05, 95% CI [-0.10, -0.01]), a freelancer (rpb=-0.10, p<.001, 95% CI [-0.15, -0.06]) and retired (rpb=-0.13, p<.001, 95% CI [-0.17, -0.08]), while a positive correlation emerged between the PSS10 score and being a student (rpb=0.19, p<.001, 95% CI [0.15, 0.23]). Regarding employment status during the COVID-19 emergency, the results demonstrated that there was a statistically significant negative correlation between the PSS-10 score and working from home (rpb=-0.06, p<.05, 95% CI [- 0.11, -0.01]) and a significant positive correlation between the PSS-10 score and being home from work temporarily without pay (rpb= 0.07, p<.05, 95% CI [0.01, 0.12]).
Relation between perceived stress and health condition The results highlighted a statistically significant positive correlation between being affected by pathologies enhancing the risk of contracting COVID-19 (immunosuppression, cardiovascular diseases, pulmonary diseases, cancer and diabetes) and the PSS-10 score (rpb=0.05, p<.05, 95% CI [0.002, 0.09]). Analysing the above-mentioned pathologies separately, a significant correlation with the PSS-10 score emerged only for immunosuppression (rpb=0.08, p<.001, 95% CI [0.04, 0.12]) and pulmonary diseases (rpb=0.05, p<.05, 95% CI [0.004, 0.09]). No statistically significant results were obtained for other pathologies.
Relation between perceived stress and contact history None of the variables investigating the history of contact with COVID-19 were found to be significantly correlated with perceived stress (PSS-10 score): having been tested for the virus (rpb=0.04, p=.087, 95% CI [-0.01, 0.08]), having tested positive for the virus (rpb=0.06, p=.703, 95% CI [-0.25, 0.35]), knowing people having tested positive for the virus (rpb=-0.03, p=0.190, 95% CI [-
0.07, 0.01]), knowing people having been hospitalized for complications due to COVID-19 (rpb=0.04, p=.065, 95% CI [-0.08, 0.003]), and knowing people having died due to COVID-19 (rpb=0.001, p=.979, 95% CI [-0.04, 0.04]). However, note that just 0.34% of the sample tested positive for the virus, and none of them required hospital care.
Relation between perceived stress and risk perception (appraisal) A statistically significant positive correlation was found between risk perception (perception of being in danger for COVID-19, 1= “not at all”, 5= “very much”) and the PSS-10 score (r=0.16, p<.001, 95% CI [0.12, 0.20]). Conversely, a negative correlation emerged between the perception of being able to avoid the virus (1= “not at all”, 5= “very much”) and the PSS-10 score (r=-0.05, p<.05, 95% CI [-0.10, -0.01]). Moreover, the PSS-10 score was positively correlated with the perception of being a risk for others (1= “not at all”, 5= “very much”; r=0.08, p<.001, 95% CI [0.04, 0.13]) and with the degree of concern for loved ones (1= “not at all”, 5= “very much”; r=0.22, p<.001, 95% CI [0.18, 0.26]). Finally, the results highlighted a statistically significant positive correlation between the degree to which participants pay more attention than usual to physical symptoms (from 1= “not at all”, 5= “very much”) and the PSS-10 score (r=0.24, p<.001, 95% CI [0.20, 0.28]).
Relation between perceived stress and perception of change in daily life A statistically significant positive correlation was found between the PSS-10 score and the degree (from 1= “not at all”, 10= “very much”) of perception of change in various aspects of daily life: emotional life (r=0.25, p<.001, 95% CI [0.21, 0.29]), family life (r=0.20, p<.001, 95% CI [0.15, 0.24]), social life (r=0.15, p<.001, 95% CI [0.10, 0.19]), work (r=0.10, p<.001, 95% CI [0.06, 0.14]) and daily life in general (r=0.20, p<.001, 95% CI [0.16, 0.24]). A statistically positive correlation was also found between the amplitude of perception that the restrictive measures adopted by the Italian Government limit personal freedoms (from 1= “not at all”, 10= “very much”) and the PSS10 score (r=0.22, p<.001, 95% CI [0.18, 0.26]).
Relation between perceived stress and psychological traits A statistically significant negative correlation emerged between the PSS-10 score and functional coping styles (positive attitude and problem solving; r=-0.32, p<.001, 95% CI [-0.36, -0.28]), high self-control (r=-0.32, p<.001, 95% CI [-0.36, -0.28]) and internal locus of control (r=-0.16, p<.001, 95% CI [-0.21, -0.12]). Conversely, a positive correlation was found between the PSS-10 score and dysfunctional coping styles (social support, avoidance, turning to religion; r=0.15, p<.001, 95% CI [0.11, 0.20]). Moreover, as concerns personality traits, the PSS-10 score was negatively correlated with high agreeableness (r=-0.18, p<.001, 95% CI [-0.22, -0.13]), high conscientiousness (r=-0.21, p<.001, 95% CI [-0.25, -0.16]), high emotional stability (r=-0.47, p<.001, 95% CI [-0.51, -0.44]) and high extraversion (r=-0.10, p<.001, 95% CI [-0.15, -0.06]). Finally, no statistically significant associations were found between stress (PSS-10) and the consideration of immediate/long-term future consequences (CFC scale; r=-0.03, p<.124, 95% CI [-0.08, 0.01]).
Relation between perceived stress and need for support As concerns the need for support, it should be pointed out that a statistically significant positive correlation emerged between the PSS-10 score and the degree to which participants think that psychological support could be useful for facing the emergency (1= “strongly disagree” to 5= “strongly agree”): r=0.48, p<.001, 95% CI [0.45, 0.52]. Moreover, the need for support was associated with the score obtained on the different coping style scales of the COPE-NVI-25: COPE positive =-0.17, p<.001, 95% CI [-0.21, -0.13], COPE problem r=-0.06, p<.05, 95% CI [-0.10, - 0.01], COPE support r=0.20, p<.001, 95% CI [0.16, 0.24] and COPE avoidance r=0.14, p<.001, 95% CI [0.10, 0.19], except for COPE religion r=0.01, p=.620, 95% CI [-0.03, 0.05].
Influence of the media and the active search for information The results showed a statistically significant positive correlation between the frequency of actively seeking information on COVID-19 (0= “never or almost never”, 1= “less than once a day”, 2= “once a day”, 3= “maximum twice a day”, 4= “three to five times a day”, 5= “all day long”) and the
PSS-10 score (r=0.17, p<.001, 95% CI [0.13, 0.22]). Moreover, the analyses highlighted a relation between the PSS-10 score and the main source of information: seeking information from highly reliable sources (accredited sources like the WHO, Italian Ministry of Health, etc.; rpb=0.03, p=0.267, 95% CI [-0.02, 0.07]), seeking information from moderately reliable sources (traditional media like newspaper, television, etc.; rpb=-0.08, p<.001, 95% CI [-0.13, -0.04]), seeking information from poorly reliable sources (social media, friends, etc.; rpb=0.09, p<.001, 95% CI [0.05, 0.13]). Finally, it is important to note that a statistically significant positive correlation emerged between the frequency of actively seeking information on COVID-19 and the degree to which people pay more attention than usual to their physical symptoms (from 1 to 5; r=0.28, p<.001, 95% CI [0.24, 0.32]). The following results emerged when analysing the correlation between the degree to which people pay more attention than usual to physical symptoms and the main source of information: seeking information from highly reliable sources rpb=-0.06, p<.01, 95% CI [-0.10, -0.02], seeking information from moderately reliable sources rpb=0.02, p=.483, 95% CI [- 0.03, 0.06] and seeking information from poorly reliable sources rpb=0.07, p<.01, 95% CI [0.02, 0.11].
Relation between perceived stress and compliance with restrictive self-isolation measures Analysing compliance with the restrictive measures imposed by the Italian government, the results showed a statistically significant correlation between the PSS-10 score and some of the variables testing adherence to the government’s rules: going out only when necessary (“yes”: rpb=-0.05, p<.05, 95% CI [-0.10, -0.01]), taking walks in defiance of the ban (“yes”: rpb=0.06, p<.05, 95% CI [0.01, 0.10]) and going grocery shopping unnecessarily in defiance of the ban (“yes”: rpb=0.06, p<.01, 95% CI [0.02, 0.10]). A statistically significant correlation between non-adherence to the rules by taking walks in defiance of the ban and the appraisal that restrictive measures are a limitation of personal freedom also emerged: taking a walk in defiance of the ban (“yes”: rpb=0.10, p<.001, 95% CI [0.05, 0.14]. Moreover, adherence to the government’s rules was associated with
the score obtained for the BSCS (total score): going out only when necessary (rpb=0.07, p<.01, 95% CI [0.02, 0.11]), taking a walk in defiance of the ban (rpb=-0.13, p<.001, 95% CI [-0.17, -0.08]) and going grocery shopping unnecessarily in defiance of the ban (rpb=-0.17, p<.001, 95% CI [-0.21, - 0.12].
Relation between perceived stress and attitudes toward the future Statistically significant results emerged from the correlation between the perspective on the future resolution of the COVID-19 crisis (the emergency 1= “will end in two weeks”, 2= “will end in one month”, 3= “will last several months”, 4= “it will not be resolved until a vaccine is discovered”) and the level of perceived stress (PSS-10 score): r=0.05, p<.05, 95% CI [0.004, 0.09]. Moreover, a statistically significant negative correlation emerged between the PSS-10 score and the degree to which the participants believe that the emergency could be an opportunity for growth (1= strongly disagree to 5= strongly agree): r=-0.15, p<.001, 95% CI [-0.19, -0.10]. This attitude was found to be correlated with the score obtained for the different coping style scales of the COPENVI-25: COPE positive r=0.36, p<.001, 95% CI [0.32, 0.40], COPE problem r=0.12, p<.001, 95% CI [0.08, 0.16], COPE religion r=0.07, p<.01, 95% CI [0.03, 0.11], COPE support r=0.15, p<.001, 95% CI [0.10, 0.19] and COPE avoidance r=-0.07, p<.01, 95% CI [-0.11, -0.03].

content.heading: LASSO regression
content.text:
A LASSO regression model has been run adding as predictors the independent variables (n=53) that, according to the correlation analysis, resulted significantly correlated with the perceived level of stress (PSS-10 score, see supplementary information), plus the stable psychological traits measured by the psychological tests. The results are visualized in Figure 1 and extensively reported in supplementary information.
Machine learning classification models Ultimately, 74 variables from the entire questionnaire were considered to be perceived stress predictors. The entire list of predictors, along with their description, is provided in the
supplementary information. Of these 74 variables, the following 15 were identified as the best pool of predictors by the correlation-based feature selection procedure: age, monthly income, information search, attention to symptoms, emotional life change, general life change, need support, growth opportunity, COPE avoidance, COPE positive, COPE functional, BSCS total score, BSCS GSD, BSCS IC, BFI-10 emotional stability. Using these predictors, various ML algorithms were trained and tested according to the procedure described in the data analysis section. Classification results on the test set are reported in Table 4, where predictive performance is quantified by the following metrics: ROC area, accuracy, precision, recall and F-measure (F1 score). It is worth noting that the classifiers showed a ROC area ranging from 0.76 to 0.82 in the test set. However, the random forest highlighted a lower sensitivity (recall) for the “high perceived stress” class compared to the other classifiers, making it a weaker model than the others for the purposes of prediction.

content.heading: Discussion
content.text:
The current study measured the impact of the COVID-19 emergency, investigating the role of sociodemographic variables and stable psychological traits to predict the perceived stress level in response to the epidemic. The results confirmed that the COVID-19 crisis is perceived as a stressful experience: in the present sample, the level of perceived stress was higher than that of the general population in a non-emergency condition. Indeed, almost one-fifth of the sample scored above the normative data. These results are in line with Chinese literature on the psychological impact of COVID-1911,12 and to international literature on epidemic outbreaks14. The mean values in the
single items of the PSS-10 suggest that, in addition to feeling nervous and stressed, feeling unable to control one’s personal life is the feeling accounting most for perceived stress. This suggests that the unpredictability and uncontrollability characterizing the pandemic outbreak situation play a significant role in perceived stress during the crisis. Consistent with this, participants declared that the emergency had a strong impact on average on their daily routines. Limitations to personal freedom and changes to emotional were found to have a great impact on personal well-being and psychological distress. As regards risk appraisal, respondents feel quite able to avoid the virus on average. From the correlation analysis emerged that those with a higher risk perception are more likely to experience psychological distress. This appears to be independent of both direct and indirect contact history with the infection: indeed, having been infected or knowing infected people was not associated with higher levels of perceived stress, as might be expected. This result might further suggest that, rather than the infection per se, what people deem and feel as most threatening is the low sense of predictability and controllability related to a so-called “invisible enemy”. Consistent with this, the greater the stress, the more people are also concerned about the health of their loved ones (see correlation analysis). As concerns health condition, only having immunosuppression is predictive of a higher level of perceived stress. With regard to restrictive self-isolation measures, the results of the present study highlight the stressful impact of the government’s rules, indicating that people who consider the restrictive measures a limitation of their personal freedom and with low self-control are more likely to perceive higher levels of stress and to violate the rules. Consistent with other studies18, these results indicate the importance of adequate information on the utility and collective advantages of the restriction in order to actively involve people in the compliance decision. Note that almost 11% of respondents (see supplementary information) report going out only when necessary, but also going for walks in defiance of the ban. Thus, further investigations on the characteristics of this subsample and the effect of the social desirability would be worthwhile.
As regards the sociodemographic variables, the current study suggests that being female is associated with higher levels of stress. This result is consistent with previous literature indicating gender differences in the psychological response to COVID-1924,89 and other epidemics90, and is also in line with the normative data of the general population. On the contrary, higher income was associated with lower levels of perceived stress. This result is consistent with previous studies on this topic as well24,34; higher income might be associated with less concern about the economic effects of self-isolation or with more comfortable housing solutions. In the present sample, being older was associated with lower levels of stress. These findings might appear surprising, since they contradict the results obtained by the studies on the Chinese population24,34 and the fact that being older is a risk factor for higher COVID mortality. However, in a developmental perspective, several studies indicated that there are age-related differences and changes in patterns of coping and locus of control that are reflected in older adults’ higher selfcontrol and emotional self-regulation compared to younger participants92–94. In this sense, older people seem to feel less threatened by the virus, despite appraising the situation as risky like younger ones, as found in the present research. Note that older people might also be more used to staying at home, so their daily routine might be impacted less by the mandatory self-isolation. Data from previous investigations on age differences in the stress response to the SARS epidemic are also inconsistent95,96: socio-political and cultural aspects, such as differences in elder care services/policies, might account for these discrepancies among the studies. As concerns education, its role in predicting the level of perceived stress did not clearly emerged in this study. Indeed, previous researchers have found mixed results: according to recent studies on the Chinese population24,34, education did not seem to affect mental health, while data from a Spanish sample89 and from previous studies on psychological adjustment to SARS91 confirmed an association between a higher level of education and mental health. Living alone or living with few family members were other protective factors for perceived stress. We might argue that all these conditions both convey a sense of protection from contagion and offer continuity with pre-epidemic economic
and social conditions. Moreover, when cohabiting with family members, the aforementioned concern for loved ones might further contribute to increase perceived stress among people living with others. Media exposure was an important issue. Most of the sample (about 62%) reported seeking information on the epidemic more than once a day: during uncertain times, it is natural to seek information, trying to make sense of things and gaining some sense of control. However, in line with previous studies97–99, the current research confirms the importance of limiting “media overload” and of choosing reliable information. Indeed, a positive association was found between the frequency of information searches and perceived stress. Moreover, while consulting accredited sources of information was not related with stress levels, consulting unreliable sources was related with higher odds of perceiving distress. Interestingly, a further interplay between the search for information style, perceived stress and a “hypochondriac-like” reaction was found: the higher the frequency in seeking information and the more unreliable the source of information, the greater the attention to physical symptoms; while the lower the frequency in seeking information and the more reliable the source of information, the lower the attention to physical symptoms. This result suggests the importance of implementing appropriate media education programs during epidemics in order to prevent the detrimental consequences of media overload on psychological distress. Similar to other psychological tendencies, such as “cyberchondria”100, dysfunctional media search might affect only more vulnerable people, i.e. those seeking reassurance and control. As concerns psychological variables, emotional stability was found to be an important protective factor. According to the Five Factors Model64, people with high emotional stability are able to remain calm in response to stressful situations and to view problems in proportion to their importance. As a result, they tend to worry about problems to a lesser extent than people with low emotional stability101. Many studies have found an influence of emotional stability in buffering stress responses to adverse events102,103. Conscientiousness and agreeableness also seemed to predict psychological distress due to the COVID-19 emergency. Individuals who score highly on
agreeableness measures tend to dislike being involved in arguments or conflict with others and tend to be less suspicious of other people. They generally seek to pacify and mediate. In this sense, agreeable people might be more flexible and accepting when faced with unexpected and undesired situations, such as restrictions and changes to daily routines. Conscientious people are more likely to perceived lower levels of stress (see correlation analysis). According to literature, they are more aware of their actions and tend to exhibit more goal-oriented behaviours. In this sense, in times of self-isolation, they might have a greater tolerance to frustrations and impositions than less conscientious people. Unconscientious people, on the contrary, tend to engage in more impulsive behaviours101. Moreover, previous studies indicated that conscientiousness may influence adaptive behaviours especially in health-related programs104,105. In the present study, higher levels of dispositional self-control predicted lower levels of psychological distress in response to the COVID-19 emergency and greater adherence to the restrictions imposed. Given the restrictions to personal freedom and social life imposed during selfisolation, personal self-control skills may play a determining role in tolerance to restrictions. This result further suggests that self-regulatory processes may have a strong influence on directing people’s responses to the outbreak. The results regarding dispositional self-control are consistent with those regarding the emotional stability trait of the Big Five Model. These dimensions are often correlated110: this specific pattern of results may indicate the importance of personal skills like calm, emotional balance and sense of acceptance, rather than inhibitory processes. In this sense, practices enhancing emotional stability and acceptance, such as mindfulness training, could be useful in reducing the stressful impact of the emergency111,112. The results concerning coping styles are also in line with this. Besides confirming the protective effect of functional coping styles and the adverse impact of dysfunctional ones the results of the present study indicate that people who use a positive attitude as a coping strategy, in particular, are much less likely to experience psychological distress during the emergency, showing high rates of appraising the emergency as an opportunity and feeling a low need for psychological support. On
the contrary, people using avoidance strategies were more likely to experience higher levels of stress. These results are consistent with previous literature on the relation between coping and response to epidemics23,41,113,114. In the current study, consideration of future consequences was found to predict psychological response to the COVID-19 outbreak. This may suggest that during the emergency it is as relevant how people differ in focusing on the future implications of their behaviour as is the internal attitude that people use to cope with the future: in a situation of strong uncertainty, thinking about future perspectives may become a source of stress because it increases concerns. This results is consistent with previous studies that indicate associations between individual differences in CFC and personal abilities in self-control115. The results on the dispositional locus of control indicate that people with an internal locus of control are less likely to be stressed. Again, the results suggest that the more people are inclined to confidently rely on themselves, the better they cope with uncertainty and changes. Several studies indicate an association between internal locus of control and self-efficacy and emotional stability116,117. Furthermore, previous studies have indicated a relation between internal locus of control and positive appraisal of emerging infectious disease outbreaks90. Overall, the results of the present study identify some population subgroups that may be more vulnerable to the COVID-19 emergency. Using a pool of 15 psychosocial variables, it is possible to identify a good percentage of the people who developed a high level of stress to the COVID-19 pandemic with a sensitivity up to 0.734 (predictive models’ ROC area is between 0.76 and 0.82). This may allow the development of targeted prevention and intervention programs. Self-regulatory skills were shown to be a protective factor (emotional stability, internal locus of control, selfcontrol), indicating the importance of raising awareness of these issues during the emergency, and of possibly offering training and education to increase personal abilities in these areas (e.g. mindfulness programs). It would also be important to limit further sources of confusion, uncertainty
and anxiety. In this sense, particular attention should be paid to the issue of appropriate information in order to enhance people’s sense of control and manageability.

content.heading: Limits and future perspectives
content.text: We acknowledge that the current study is characterized by some shortcomings that should be considered when interpreting its findings. First, the participants were recruited through an online link that was posted and advertised on social media: online advertising guarantees the possibility of recruiting large samples, but may not guarantee sample representativeness. Second, all our investigations relied on an online self-reported questionnaire: the online format guarantees anonymity, but does not allow verification of the reliability of responses and participant understanding of the questions. Third, although many of the predictor variables were quite stable sociodemographic characteristics and psychological traits, the cross-sectional research design of the present study could not unequivocally confirm causal relationships between the factors being considered and perceived stress. Hopefully, the present research improves our understanding of some of the possible risk factors and protective factors that may influence people’s stress response to the COVID-19 outbreak. It is worth noting that the data in the present study are from an Italian population. Therefore, they were inevitably influenced by specific contextual and socio-cultural aspects. Further investigations involving people from different countries might deepen our understanding of the generalizability of the results and the effective influence of psychological traits. Future research could also invest effort in investigating the interplay and mutual interrelationships between single protective and risk factors. These further understandings could lead to the implementation of more targeted and then more effective prevention and intervention programs. Finally, work is needed identifying protective factors and risk factors for psychological responses during the post-epidemic period and in understanding the longitudinal psychological impact of disease outbreaks.

content.text:
This study investigates change in students’ social networks and mental health at the time of the COVID-19 crisis in April 2020. We surveyed multiple dimensions of social networks (pleasant interaction, friendship, social support, co-studying) and mental health indicators (depression, anxiety, stress, loneliness) before and during the crisis among Swiss undergraduate students (N=212). We find that interaction and costudying networks had become sparser, and more students were studying alone. Furthermore, students’ levels of stress, anxiety, loneliness, and depressive symptoms got worse. Stressors shifted from fears of missing out on social life to worries about health, family, friends, and their future. Exploratory analyses suggest that COVID-19 specific worries, isolation in social networks, lack of interaction and emotional support, and physical isolation were associated with negative mental health trajectories. The results offer starting points to identify and support students at higher risk of social isolation and negative psychological effects during the COVID-19 pandemic.

content.heading: Statement of Relevance
content.text:
As the COVID-19 pandemic is unfolding and social distancing measures are
implemented on national and organizational levels, little is known about how these measures will affect individuals’ social lives and mental health. In this study, we investigate how students’ social networks and mental health change in response to a strict lockdown of their university and Swiss public life. We collected survey data at the time of the crisis and the two preceding years. These data provide unique insights into social and psychological changes: Students’ social networks mostly remained stable, except for interaction and co-study networks. On average, students reported worse mental health than prior to the COVID-19 crisis, possibly due to shifts in individual stressors. We identify individual and social factors associated with changes in mental health, offering starting points for potential interventions to combat the illeffects of the COVID-19 pandemic on social isolation and individuals’ mental health.

content.heading: Introduction
content.text:
The COVID-19 pandemic has forced political leaders to take drastic measures
that affect how people interact with each other. In many countries around the world, individuals are required to reduce physical contact to others outside one’s household (social distancing; Anderson, Heesterbeek, Klinkenberg, & Hollingsworth, 2020). Additional measures include curfews, quarantines, and closing of non-essential stores, schools, and universities. As many universities declared a suspension of classroom teaching and switched to online teaching, the lives of students have changed drastically. While social distancing measures may successfully slow down the spread of the infection and relieve the public health systems (Glass, Glass, Beyeler, & Min, 2006), they may eventually increase the social isolation of students and affect their mental health. Being under a lot of pressure to perform academically, students are prone to developing mental health problems (Mikolajczyk et al., 2008). In line with recent (unpublished) studies, we thus examine the effects of the COVID-19 crisis on a student population (e.g., Fried, Papanikolaou, & Epskamp, 2020; Romero-Rivas & Rodríguez-Cuadrado, 2020). Specifically, we ask two questions: how the COVID19 crisis affects the social networks between students, and how changes in students’ social networks and daily life affect students’ mental health.
We investigate changes in social integration and mental health (depressive symp-
toms, anxiety, loneliness, and stress) of N = 212 students in two undergraduate study programs in Switzerland. At the time of data collection (early April 2020), universities had switched to online education, non-essential shops were closed, and social gatherings were restricted to groups of at most five people. Furthermore, in-person socializing with others beyond co-residents was advised against in Switzerland.
Integration in multiplex social networks is examined within the community of
students and beyond, including social contacts in the household, family, and friendship circles. Social networks and mental health outcomes are investigated at the time of the COVID-19 crisis, two weeks after Switzerland introduced social distancing measures

content.heading: STUDENTS UNDER LOCKDOWN 4
content.text: and a strict university lockdown was put into place. We examine changes in social integration and mental health through two lenses: within-person, using data collected during the two years prior to the COVID-19 crisis, and between-cohort, using data collected in one cohort of students in an undergraduate program a year earlier. We investigate the longitudinal associations between social networks and mental health markers with three pre-registered hypotheses predicting decreased social integration, higher survival chance of stronger, overlapping social ties, and mixed effects of the crisis on mental health (osf.io/4g98p). Furthermore, we explore individual and social factors associated with change in mental health during the COVID-19 crisis.

content.heading: Changes in Social Networks
content.text:
The social relationships of individuals are likely to be affected by the crisis in
different ways. Social relationships are conduits of social support (Cohen, Underwood, & Gottlieb, 2000). In times of crisis, social support may be more important than ever. But at the same time, physical proximity and opportunities for interaction are important in developing and fostering social ties (Doreian & Conti, 2012; Festinger, Schachter, & Back, 1950). As face-to-face interactions and random encounters are minimized due to the social distancing measures, it is likely that individuals focus on those relationships that are spatially close, most meaningful, or most established. Those may partly be found outside the student community, for example, in the household, in the family, and within established friendship circles (Bolger & Eckenrode, 1991).
In this article, we take into account multiple dimensions of social relations.
We assess change in five self-reported social networks within the student community: pleasant interactions, friendships, emotional support, informational support, and costudying. We chose those networks as they differ in function, intimacy, and stability. We assume that stronger relationships will be characterized by an overlap in multiple dimensions (Vörös & Snijders, 2017).

content.heading: STUDENTS UNDER LOCKDOWN 5
content.text:
We hypothesize that students at the time of the COVID-19 crisis nominate fewer
fellow students than before in multiple dimensions of their social networks (H1a). We expect that social networks between students are less connected, and thus will show a higher rate of students being socially isolated (H1b). We hypothesize that stronger ties are more likely to survive at the time of crisis, thus when they are characterized by a previous overlap in multiple relational dimensions (H2 ).

content.heading: Changes in Mental Health
content.text:
Prior research conducted with individuals in strict quarantine suggests severe
consequences for mental health (for a review see Brooks et al., 2020). It is unclear, however, to what extent these findings are comparable to the less severe distancing measures implemented under COVID-19.
Changes in social networks due to the COVID-19 crisis may directly affect in-
dividuals’ mental health. Most individuals have a fundamental motivation to socially interact (Baumeister & Leary, 1995). A reduction of social interactions, as is likely to be caused by the crisis and distancing measures, can lead to lower mental health (Kawachi & Berkman, 2001; Ryan & Deci, 2000).
A number of COVID-19-specific stressors could further affect individuals’ mental
health. Among those are worries about one’s own physical health, the health of others, the potential economic impact, and – in the case of students – the impact of a changed educational environment on the progress of their studies and future job market opportunities. However, some individual stressors may be reduced at the time of crisis, as society slows down (Rosa, 2014). Those may, for example, include the stress of work, such as rigid study time tables, or social stressors such as Fear of Missing Out (FoMO; Przybylski, Murayama, Dehaan, & Gladwell, 2013).
We expect that during the COVID-19 crisis, some aspects of students’ men-
tal health will improve (e.g., aspects of daily stress) while others will worsen (e.g., loneliness) (H3 ). To get a better understanding of factors explaining change in men-

content.heading: STUDENTS UNDER LOCKDOWN 6
content.text:
tal health, we further explore the impact of different individual and social factors on change in mental health. We consider COVID-19-related stressors, social network integration within the student community, social ties outside the student community, and demographic factors. The identified individual and social factors could be relevant starting points for future empirical studies and could inform potential interventions to combat the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic on social isolation and individuals’ mental health.
Methods

content.heading: Participants
content.text:
The participants were all students, starting their undergraduate studies in 2017,
in two different engineering / natural science programs (henceforth referred to as current year, Major I and Major II), and students starting in 2016 in one study program (previous year). Students in the previous-year cohort followed the same program as the current year, Major I.
In the current-year cohort, participants are selected on response to both of two
questionnaires in April 2020 (during the COVID-19 lockdown) and September 2019, while the sample from the previous-year cohort is selected from those responding to a questionnaire in April 2019. The sizes of these samples used in our analyses are respectively N1 = 70, N2 = 142, N3 = 54. All samples are mostly male, and have a majority of Swiss nationals (see Table 1).

content.heading: Procedure
content.text:
Data were collected (a) prior to the COVID-19 outbreak as part of the Swiss
StudentLife study (September 2017 to September 2019; Stadtfeld, Vörös, Elmer, Boda, & Raabe, 2019), and (b) two weeks after the university and Swiss public life were largely shut down in response to the crisis (April 2020). A comparable survey was administered in the previous year cohort who had started their undergraduate

content.heading: STUDENTS UNDER LOCKDOWN 7
content.text:
studies one year earlier but did not experience this lockdown (previous year cohort; April 2019). The April surveys took place about half-way through the Spring semester (the final semester for the undergraduate students in the sample), the September surveys at the beginning of the Autumn semester.
Surveys were conducted online using the Qualtrics software. The students were
invited by email and SMS with personalized links, and informed of the compensation of 30 Swiss Francs per survey (approximately 31 USD or 28.5 EUR in April 2020). The amount equals the compensation for participation in one hour of experimental research at the same institution. Each questionnaire was open for one week, within which students could respond at their convenience. In this period, students were reminded to participate twice. The questionnaire was administered in German, the language of instruction at the Swiss university where the study was conducted.
The first two pages of the questionnaire always stated the purposes and uses of
the data, and asked for consent to these. The students were asked if they would like to receive an information email if their mental health as measured by psychometric scales was above a threshold indicative of a potential clinical relevance. After this, they filled out the questionnaire, lasting a median of 49 and 50 minutes for the current

content.heading: STUDENTS UNDER LOCKDOWN 8
content.text: year cohort in September 2019 and April 2020, and 58 minutes for the previous year cohort in April 2019. The questionnaire in April 2020 was reduced in terms of content (with a small number of COVID-19 related items added), but the ordering and formulation of questions remained identical. The data collection and intended uses were approved by the institutional ethics committee of ETH Zürich (approval numbers 2016-N-27 and 2017-N-42).

content.heading: Materials and variable construction
content.text:
Cohort network items. To explore changes on complete social networks,
various questions about individuals’ relations to others within the cohort were asked. Focal relations include perceived pleasant interactions with other students (in the following: Interaction), friendships, co-studying, reception of informational support, and reception of emotional support. Furthermore, participants were asked about their communication with others in the cohort; in particular with whom they had contact face-to-face (Physical communication), over messaging applications (Messaging), by video or audio (Calls), or by social media applications that do not fall under the previous categories (Social Media). The precise wording of these items is provided in the Supplementary Table 1. For all of these social network items, a name generator approach was applied (Robins, 2015): participants could fill in up to 20 auto-completing text fields, in which names of all students within that cohort’s major program were listed. Each name reported was treated as a tie from the respondent to that individual within the respective network.
All network items were included in both surveys for the current-year cohort,
and for the survey in the previous-year cohort, with the exception of the physical and calls contact networks.
For each type of network captured by these items, we construct two key measures
to test Hypotheses 1a and 1b: the outdegree of each respondent, i.e. the number of ties that each participant reports in each network, and the proportion of out-isolates, i.e.

content.heading: STUDENTS UNDER LOCKDOWN 9
content.text:
the fraction of all participants who reported no ties in a network. To test Hypothesis 2, we use the overlap of multiple ties within pairs of individuals collected in September 2019 as a signal of tie strength.
Personal network items. To examine individuals’ personal networks (ego
networks, Crossley et al., 2015), respondents were asked about people who are important to them during the COVID-19 crisis. Here, participants could still name fellow students but also others, for example, a partner, family members, housemates, colleagues, or friends. Translated versions of all personal network items used in our analyses are available in the Supplementary Materials.
Respondents were prompted to fill in pseudonyms that they would recognize for
up to 10 individuals (personal network size). After indicating their names, respondents were asked a number of follow-up questions. They were asked about contexts in which they communicate with these individuals (six multiple-choice options): Within the household, outside of the household, by telephone, by FaceTime/Skype or similar, over messaging applications, or other (with an open text box to further specify the context). They were asked about the roles that these individuals fulfil (e.g., partner, family member, friend, etc.; multiple-choice), and whether they receive emotional support from each person on a 7-point ordinal scale, ranging from completely disagree (1) to completely agree (7). Additionally, participants were asked how often they communicated with these people in-person, by phone, or over messaging applications on a 7-point ordinal scale, ranging from 1 (not at all) to 7 (multiple times a day). These ego network items were only asked in the April 2020 questionnaire of the current year cohort.
COVID-19 items. A battery of items presented in the April 2020 wave cap-
tured the extent of participants’ experiences of stressors relative to the time before the COVID-19 crisis, on topics including one’s own health, family and friends, one’s personal finances, the economy, and one’s career prospects. Other items in this battery captured the extent to which respondents fear missing out on social activities,

content.heading: STUDENTS UNDER LOCKDOWN 10
content.text:
feel socially isolated, feel competition among students, feel supported by other students, and the extent to which they face personal problems they previously suppressed compared to the time before the crisis. All answer categories were on the same 7- point scale, ranging from -3 (much less than before) to 3 (much more than before). The midpoint of the scale was 0 (equally). Full item formulations are listed in the Supplementary Materials.
Furthermore, specific to the temporal context under study, participants in the
April 2020 questionnaire were asked questions pertaining to health and health guidelines. First, they were asked whether they have had any symptoms consistent with COVID-19 infection, which they answered with a multiple choice list of symptoms. Following this, participants were asked whether someone they are close to is in an at-risk group, with a yes/no response. They were additionally asked how strictly they are adhering to federal guidelines against the disease’s spread, using a five-point scale ranging from 1 (not at all) to 5 (always).
Mental health scales. Depressive symptoms were measured by the German
version of the Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression scale (Hautzinger & Bailer, 1993). This measure comprises 20 items on a 4-point scale ranging from 0 (occurred never or rarely) to 3 (occurred often or always). Each item reflects the frequency of a symptom in the past week, with symptoms including “I felt that everything I did took a lot of effort”, and “I felt depressed”. Depression is scored as the sum of all items, thus ranging from 0 to 60. Cronbach’s alpha of the measure is α = .91.
Anxiety was measured by the German version of the Generalized Anxiety
Disorder-7 scale (Löwe et al., 2008; Spitzer, Kroenke, Williams, & Löwe, 2006). This 7-item measure has responses on a 4-point scale ranging from 0 (not at all) to 3 (nearly every day), regarding the frequency of experiencing each symptom in the past two weeks. Examples include having “trouble relaxing”, and “feeling afraid as if something awful was about to happen”. Anxiety is sum-scored from all the items – ranging from 0 to 21. Cronbach’s alpha of the measure is α = .88.

content.heading: STUDENTS UNDER LOCKDOWN 11
content.text:
Stress was measured by the German version of the Perceived Stress Scale-10
(Klein et al., 2016). This measure comprises 10 items on a 5-point scale, ranging from 0 (never) to 4 (very often), each capturing the frequency of a marker of stress over the past month. Examples include how often the respondent felt “able to control irritations in your life”, or were “upset because of something that happened unexpectedly”. The stress score is computed as the sum-score of all items, therefore ranging from 0 to 40. Cronbach’s alpha of the measure is α = .86.
Loneliness was measured by the short, German version of the UCLA Loneliness
Scale (Döring & Bortz, 1993; Luhmann, Bohn, Holtmann, Koch, & Eid, 2016). This scale contains 9 items with responses on a 4-point scale ranging from 1 (Never) to 4 (Always), capturing how often respondents experience feelings of loneliness. Items include “How often do you feel that you lack companionship?” and “How often do you feel that there are people you can talk to?”. The loneliness score is computed as the mean score of all items. Cronbach’s alpha of the measure is α = .86.
Extraversion. In our exploratory analysis on changes in mental health, we
further control for the general sociability of individuals. We proxy this sociability with extraversion, measured by the 8-item subscale of the German version of the Big Five Inventory (Lang, Lüdtke, & Asendorpf, 2001). Responses for each item, capturing the extent to which a statement reflected the respondent’s self-perceptions, ranged from 1 (Very well) to 5 (Not at all). Examples of items include “I see myself as someone who is talkative” and “I see myself as someone who is full of energy”. The extraversion score was computed as the mean of the items. This measure had a Cronbach’s alpha of α = .86.
Factors for exploring changes in mental health. Multiple blocks of vari-
ables are included in an analysis of the change of the four mental health indicators from September 2019 until April 2020, to capture known and hypothesized stressors during the COVID-19 crisis. We include variables grouped into four blocks.
First, since concerns developing as a result of the virus may have implications

content.heading: STUDENTS UNDER LOCKDOWN 12
content.text:
for mental health, all items described above on COVID-19 related stressors crisis were included as potential factors. Two items on perceived additional stress and perceived additional relaxation were assessed but not used in the exploration of mental health changes, as those were identified as theoretically too close to the dependent variables.
Second, we identify those who did not report anyone (out-isolation) in the
friendship, pleasant interactions, emotional support, informational support, and costudying networks. These variables are included as social isolation (as indicated by being an isolated node in the network) may have negative individual consequences (Okamoto et al., 2011).
Third, personal network characteristics are included as covariates. We include
the number of individuals named in the personal network questions (personal network size; ranging between zero and ten). Further, physical isolation in personal networks is captured by whether one is not living with someone who they indicate as being important since the lockdown (isolated household variable). We evaluate how often individuals have face-to-face contact with an important individual (minimal physical contact; measured as the maximum reported amount of face-to-face contact among all individuals in the personal network). Additionally, the mean level of emotional support provided by the individuals in the personal network is included (mean emotional support). Furthermore, two other specific COVID-19-related items were used to explore changes in mental health, specifically: at-risk status of close others and adherence to the federal health administration’s guidelines to prevent the spread of the disease.
Fourth, demographic and personal attributes were included to understand
whether certain demographic categories or sub-populations might be particularly at risk beyond other factors: non-Swiss nationality, single relationship status, female gender, and extraversion.
Finally, covariates were included for all measures of mental health in September
2019 to prevent biases due to previous poor mental health. Also, we controlled for

content.heading: STUDENTS UNDER LOCKDOWN 13
content.text: the study major, as the cohorts might differ in their general levels of mental health.

content.heading: Analysis
content.text:
Assessing changes in social networks. To assess within-person changes on
social networks, the entire current-year cohort (N = 212) in April 2020 are compared to the most recent previous observation (September 2019). The within-person comparisons of outdegree (H1a) and isolation proportions (H1b) of the observed network dimensions are used to test hypotheses one. The expected within-person decrease in outdegree between the two time points is examined by one-sided, paired-samples t-tests. The expected increase in proportion of out-isolates is examined within-group by McNemar’s test (McNemar, 1947) with continuity correction to account for a low number of observations. Further qualitative and structural differences in the network are examined through use of multiplex network visualizations. While this strategy allows for identification of changes, it does not distinguish between change due to general trends within the cohort, or changes brought about by the COVID-19 crisis and social distancing measures.
To build stronger evidence of the effects related to the COVID-19 crisis, we also
compare the current-year cohort, Major I (N = 86) in April 2020, to the previous-year cohort (N = 54) in April 2019 in between-cohort tests. We select on all respondents of Major I of the current-year cohort for better comparability between cohorts on size and gender balance, and to avoid potential effects of different majors. To test the expected lower mean outdegree in each network in the current year compared to the previous, we apply one-sided, independent-samples t-tests with Welch’s correction since group sizes are different and variance should thus not be assumed equal. To test the expected higher proportion of out-isolates in the current year compared to the previous, we use one-sided, two-sample z-tests (e.g., Agresti & Finlay, 2009, pp. 187), with Yates’ continuity correction to adjust for our relatively small sample.
Additional testing of between-cohort difference allows better inference than from

content.heading: STUDENTS UNDER LOCKDOWN 14
content.text:
the within-person comparisons alone. However, despite matching the samples on their major program, there are nonetheless differences in baseline mental health, network structures, composition and time that limit our ability to infer causality. These differences are discussed in the results section and Supplementary Materials, Figure 3.
To test hypothesis two, on the survival of social ties, we count the number of
overlapping social network dimensions within each pair of individuals in September 2019. We then evaluate the survival rate of each number of overlapping dimensions (i.e., 1-4) relative to the baseline survival rate of the network. To obtain Confidence Intervals evaluating statistical significance, we apply bootstrapping (DiCiccio & Efron, 1996).
Assessing changes in mental health. Similar to the assessment of changes
in social networks, the changes in mental health are evaluated based on within-person and between-cohort comparisons. The within-person comparisons are carried out using two-sided paired t-tests comparing the April 2020 assessments of mental health dimensions to those of September 2019.
In the between-cohort comparison, mental health dimensions of the current-year
cohort, Major I (N = 86) in April 2020, are compared to the measures of the previousyear cohort (N = 54), assessed in April 2019. These between-cohort comparisons are carried out to provide better evidence of whether changes in mental health are liked to the social distancing measures, rather than general study-progress related trends. Nevertheless, we note that it might not be valid to compare these two cohorts to one another due to prior differences in the general trends (see Supplementary Material Figure 3).
Also, the items on COVID-19 related stressors (see section COVID-19 items)
are examined descriptively. Together with the overall mental health changes, these items on COVID-19 stressors are used to test hypothesis three.

content.heading: STUDENTS UNDER LOCKDOWN 15
content.text:
Predictors of change in mental health. The relative importance of factors
relating to COVID-19 specific stressors, student networks, personal networks, and demographic variables is explored using linear regression models. The dependent variables are the individual differences between the September 2019 and the April 2020 wave on the four mental health dimensions. Positive values in the dependent variables indicate that the April 2020 scores were higher than those of September 2019. Given the high number of candidate variables relative to the sample size, we apply stepwise backwards selection procedure to preserve statistical power (Draper & Smith, 1998). In this procedure, first, a fully specified model is estimated. Then, the independent variable with the highest p-value is removed and the model is being reestimated. The removal of variables is continued until there is no independent variable with a p-value higher than a certain cutoff (in our case this is .30). To support the robustness of our analyses, we additionally report the results of the full model in the Supplementary Material Table 2. Bivariate association tests (Pearson and Spearman Rank-Order correlations) also presented in the Supplementary Material Table 3.
While the initial selection of variables was based on theoretical considerations
and expected relevant controls, the reported levels of significance should not be overemphasized, given the relatively high number of candidate variables and risk of model overfitting. The reported findings are to be understood as an exploration of risk factors, and do not serve as hypothesis tests.

content.heading: Changes in Social Networks
content.text:
Figure 1 presents a test of Hypotheses 1a and 1b. It indicates that social net-
works between students changed during the COVID-19 crisis. Panel A compares the average number of nominations (outdegree) across five self-reported networks (pleasant interaction, friendship, co-studying, informational support, emotional support) in September 2019 (prior to the COVID-19 lockdown) and April 2020 (at the time

content.heading: STUDENTS UNDER LOCKDOWN 17
content.text:
of the lockdown). Students reported on average 0.80 fewer interaction partners and 0.46 fewer study partners. These differences are found to be significant using onesided, paired t-tests (Interaction: t(211) = 4.15, p < .001; Co-study: t(211) = 3.60, p < .001) among students who participated in both data collection waves (N = 212). Hence, with regards to pleasant interaction and co-study networks, we find support for hypothesis 1a (students nominate fewer fellow students). Friendship networks appeared to remain stable, while informational support and emotional support nominations slightly increased. Panel B shows the proportion of students who did not name a single contact in each of the networks (out-isolates). The proportion is significantly higher in the study network. Instead of 22.6% of the students 39.2% now report not to have a study partner (McNemar’s χ2(1) = 21.81, p < .001). Hypothesis 1b (more students are socially isolated) is thus supported only for the co-study network. The network comparisons indicate that functional social networks between students (interaction and studying) decreased in density, while friendship and support networks remained stable.
Panel C and D of Figure 1 show the results of comparisons between the so-
cial networks of those students who were in Major I (N = 86) to the students from the same study program in the previous year (N = 54). In both cases the data were collected in April of the third study year, once in 2019 and once in 2020 (during the COVID-19 crisis). The direction is similar to the within-cohort comparison: Students in the semester affected by COVID-19 reported less contacts in each network, except for emotional support (Panel C), and were more likely to indicate that they were isolated, thus did not have a single contact in each of the five social networks (Panel D). The differences between the two cohorts reflect similar patterns of differences. Pleasant interaction and co-studying networks were significantly lower in outdegree, but no significant differences were found in the proportion of outisolates (using one-sided, independent-sample t-tests of lower outdegree in the current year compared to previous, Panel C; Interaction: t(112.07) = 1.73, p = .043;
STUDENTS UNDER LOCKDOWN 18
Friend: t(101.23) = 1.46, p = .074; Co-study: t(89.09) = 1.80, p = .038; Info. support: t(121.45) = 0.85, p = .199; Emot. support: t(125.08) = 0.00, p = .499; and one-sided, independent-sample z-tests of greater proportion of isolates in the currentyear cohort in Panel D; Interaction: χ2(1) = 1.74, p = .093; Friend: χ2(1) = 0.23, p = .316; Co-study: χ2(1) = 0.37, p = .271; Info. support: χ2(1) = 1.64, p = .100; Emot. support: χ2(1) = 0.36, p = .275).
Figure 2 visualizes the reported interaction networks between students at the
time of the COVID-19 crisis. As a consequence of the university lockdown and Swiss policies on social distancing, only few face-to-face interactions were reported by students (Panel A). Yet, students had pleasant interactions in general (MInteraction = 5.62 ties, see Fig 1, Panel A). They reported to interact through text messaging, voice and

content.heading: STUDENTS UNDER LOCKDOWN 19
content.text: video calls, and through social media (MMessaging = 2.81;MCalls = 2.94,MSocial Media = 0.41 ties). The union of these networks is indicated by blue ties (any interaction). Messaging, calls and social media ties are shown in red, green and yellow, respectively. The relative network density and overlap between them is shown in a Venn diagram in Figure 2. The interaction networks were overlapping, but not identical. 85% of the call ties and 90% of the messaging ties were reported as pleasant interactions. 64% of the messaging ties were also reported as call ties, and 70% of the call ties as messaging ties. Seventy-five percent of the physical interactions were overlapping with any of the digital communication networks. Additional Venn diagrams showing these overlaps can be found in the Supplementary Material Figure 1. It appears that while physical interactions were rarely possible, students conducted their social interactions largely in the digital realm. Overall, however, the number of reported interactions dropped, as reported above. Additional network visualizations that illustrate tie change and social isolation in the co-study and social support networks are provided in the Supplementary Materials.

content.heading: STUDENTS UNDER LOCKDOWN 20
content.text:
Figure 3 presents a test on Hypothesis 2, suggesting that weaker, one-
dimensional ties (i.e., zero overlapping social dimensions in September 2019) were less stable than stronger ties with more overlapping dimensions. It reports the empirical probability of interaction and studying ties to survive, thus to be reported in April 2020 after being reported in September 2019. Panel A shows that while in general 66.6% of the interaction ties survived (dashed line), the survival rate was only 45.4% for ties that did not coincide with any other of the four network relations (friendship, studying, informational, or emotional support). When interaction was reported with two to four of these networks in September 2019, the tie survival rate was between 84.9 and 87.2%. The pattern is similar in Panel B, which compares survival rates of co-studying ties. Ties that did not coincide with interaction, friendship, informational, or emotional support only had a 5.9% survival rate, while ties that overlapped with all four dimensions survived in 57.1% of the cases. The average survival rate was 44.7%.

content.heading: Changes in Mental Health
content.text:
Here, we first describe how students rated a set of COVID-19 related stressors
that specifically ask whether they feel more or less strained by a particular factor since the COVID-19 crisis. Then, we describe within-person and between-cohort comparisons of mental health changes with regards to depressive symptoms, anxiety, stress, and loneliness.
Table 2 shows the distributions and means of responses on thirteen COVID-
19-related stressors. The following effects are evaluated with one-sample t-tests (H0 : M = 0) as reported in Table 2. Students felt significantly more socially isolated, slightly more that they were missing out on something, more worried about family and friends, slightly more worried about their own health, more worried about the economy, slightly more worried about their financial situation, more worried about their future career, and more affected by personal problems that were usually ignored.

To investigate the comparability of the two cohorts, we explored trends in
cohort-level mental health trajectories over the past two years. Figure 3a-c in the Supplementary Materials shows the mean trajectories and 95% confidence intervals of different mental health measures for those waves that were assessed at the same time with regards to the study progress. In most waves, the two cohorts did not differ significantly from one another (i.e., overlapping 95% Confidence Intervals). Only with regards to stress there appears to be a difference: the previous year’s cohort seems to be more stressed in general. The trends seem aligned through time, indicating seasonal and study-related factors that affect both cohorts. However, it appears that depression, stress, and loneliness (but not anxiety) at the time of the COVID-19 crisis worsen above the general trend, and that the co-studying outdegree (but not the interaction outdegree) decreases more than the general trend. These differences, however, are not statistically significant, as indicated by overlapping confidence intervals.
In sum, the descriptive results of the COVID-19 items support the expectation
that some aspects of students mental health decrease (e.g., social isolation, general worries) while other stressors (e.g., Fear of Missing Out, student competition) are reduced during the COVID-19 crisis, as proposed in Hypothesis 3. The overall levels of mental health in comparison with the September 2019 wave show a clear decreasing trend. It is possible that partly these trends are unrelated to the COVID-19 crisis, as no significant differences with regards to mental health are found in a between-cohort comparisons, conducted on a smaller sub population.
Explaining changes in mental health
Here, we describe the results of regression analyses on the change of mental
health dimensions between September 2019 and April 2020 using a variety of explanatory variables including COVID-19-specific stressors, social networks between

students, personal social networks, and demographic variables.
Students who participated in the September 2019 and April 2020 surveys re-
ported an average increase in depressive symptoms of 4.70 (SD = 7.21, total scale range 0-60), an increase in anxiety of 0.75 (SD = 3.47, total scale range 0-21), an increase in stress of 2.76 (SD = 5.78, total scale range 0-40), and an increase in loneliness of 0.14 (SD = 0.33, total scale range 1-4).
Table 3 shows the results of backwards-selected regression models predicting
these differences. Estimates of the full models as well as bivariate correlations of all independent variables with the dependent variables are reported in the Supplementary Material Table 2 and Table 3. For reasons of parsimony, in the following, mainly the significant predictors are discussed. It should be noted that this is an exploratory analysis, not intended to provide evidence for particular hypotheses. The results are discussed by each of the four predictor categories: the COVID-19 related stressors described above, measures of social integration in the social networks between students, measures of personal network integration, and demographics variables.
The results on COVID-19 related stressors indicate that students who worry
more about their family and friends are more likely to become more depressed (b = 1.54, t(130) = 2.68, p = .008) and more stressed (b = 0.96, t(159) = 2.19, p = .030). Worries about one’s future career contributed to higher levels of anxiousness (b = 0.45, t(164) = 2.22, p = .027) and stress (b = 1.36, t(159) = 3.69, p < .001). The presence of personal problems that were usually suppressed was a strong positive predictor of an increase in depression (b = 4.10, t(130) = 6.03, p < .001), anxiety (b = 1.49, t(164) = 6.31, p < .001), and stress (b = 0.93, t(159) = 2.01, p = .047). No other COVID-19 related stressors was associated with changes in mental health. Although social isolation and worries about the economy increased since the COVID19 crisis (see Table 2), these factors did not predict changes in mental health in this multivariate regression model (for details see Table 3).

content.heading: STUDENTS UNDER LOCKDOWN 27
content.text:
The results regarding the effects of being isolated in social networks between
students on mental health change are found next in Table 3. Social isolation is associated with changes in anxiety: Being an out-isolate (i.e., having no outgoing ties) in the friendship network in April 2020 was predictive of lower levels of anxiety (b = −2.46, t(164) = −2.31, p = .022), while being an out-isolate in the interaction network (b = 2.22, t(164) = 2.06, p = .041) and the informational support network (b = 2.38, t(164) = 3.60, p < .001) was predictive of higher levels of anxiety. It should be noted that the subset of students who were isolated only in the friendship network but not in the interaction and information support network is very small (N = 4). Thus, for most students isolation in student social networks is associated with an increase in anxiety. Further, being an out-isolate in the friendship network is associated with increasing loneliness trajectories (b = 0.27, t(161) = 2.05, p = .042). Characteristics of personal networks assessed during the COVID-19 crisis are also associated with changes in mental health. Individuals with smaller personal networks appear to become more lonely (b = −0.27, t(161) = −2.48, p = .014). Those students who live alone (i.e., are isolated from their personal network in their household) are more likely to report an increase in depressive symptoms (b = 3.19, t(130) = 2.08, p = .039), and those who interact less with individuals in their personal network tend to be more anxious (b = −0.33, t(164) = −2.60, p = .010). We further find that those with more emotional support were less depressed (b = −1.14, t(130) = −2.10, p = .038) and less lonely (b = −0.07, t(161) = −2.70, p = .008). Demographic variables are also associated with mental health trajectories. Individuals not in a romantic relationship were more likely to become more lonely (b = 0.10, t(161) = 2.05, p = .042). Female students are found to be more likely to become more depressed (b = 3.05, t(130) = 2.51, p = .013), anxious (b = 2.04, t(164) = 2.20, p = .030), stressed (b = 1.32, t(159) = 2.82, p = .005), and lonely (b = 0.15, t(161) = 2.68, p = .008) in these regression models.

content.heading: Discussion
content.text:
In this study, we investigate the change in social networks (social interactions,
social support, study collaboration, friendship) and mental health (depression, anxiety, loneliness, stress) of students in two undergraduate programs at a Swiss university at the time of the COVID-19 crisis. At this point, the university had been under lockdown for about two weeks. The Swiss government had further implemented a number of social distancing measures and individuals were demanded to stay at home. We compare measures on social networks and mental health to (i) those of the same students seven months earlier (prior to the COVID-19 outbreak; within-person comparison) and (ii) those collected in a different student community with the same study progress (final undergraduate year) at the same university and in the same study program exactly one year earlier (between-cohort comparison). Finally, in exploratory analyses, we identify a number of individual and social factors associated with changes in mental health in this period.
In within-person comparisons of social networks and in line with H1, we ob-
serve that students nominated fewer others in social interaction networks and co-study networks and were more likely to be isolated in co-study networks. Friendship and social support networks did not change significantly. In between-cohort comparisons of social networks, we similarly observe significantly lower connectivity (outdegree) in pleasant interaction and co-study networks, but no significant differences in proportion of socially isolated individuals. Stronger social ties, those characterized by overlap with other dimensions half a year earlier, were more likely to be maintained during the social distancing phase, in line with H2. Overall, most students remained well-integrated after two weeks of physical distancing and it appeared that while face-to-face interaction was unattainable, digital communication was very common. However, the increasing number of isolated individuals in two of the networks (interaction and studying) suggest that some individuals might be at higher risk of facing negative social consequences.

content.heading: STUDENTS UNDER LOCKDOWN 29
content.text:
In within-person comparisons of mental health dimensions, we find that students
were on average more depressed, slightly more anxious, more stressed, and felt more lonely than half a year earlier. While measures of mental health suggest a decline, some students reported that the crisis situation affected their lives positively with regards to Fear of Missing Out and competition among the students. These findings are in line with H3, that students perceived both positive and negative changes due to the situation. In between-cohort comparisons of mental health measures no significant differences were observed, although the trends appear similar.
Finally, we identify factors affecting negative and positive mental health pro-
gressions. In particular females were more likely to be affected negatively by the situation. Further, it appears that a worsening of mental health measures was associated with more worries about one’s family and friends, more worries about the future career, being faced with problems usually suppressed, living alone, and less contact and support from the personal network. These findings are in line with studies showing those individuals who worry more (Van Os, Park, & Jones, 2001), who are more socially isolated (Cacioppo, Hawkley, & Thisted, 2010), and receive less social support (Cohen, 2004; Hefner & Eisenberg, 2009) are more likely to develop mental health problems. Those individuals are also more at risk for serious health conditions (Cohen, 2004; Holt-Lunstad, Smith, Baker, Harris, & Stephenson, 2015).
A limitation of this study is that the observational research design does not
allow us to make causal claims. Some of the changes may be related to general trends within the study program. Students were in the final year of their undergraduate studies and might feel more strained because they have to pass final exams and get active on the job market. While the comparison to a cohort of students in the previous year indicated no mental-health differences, this comparison is limited due to differences in demographic distributions and cohort-related factors. However, the fact that COVID-19-specific stressors were associated with change in mental health, gives us confidence that indeed the COVID-19 crisis had a negative impact on the

content.heading: STUDENTS UNDER LOCKDOWN 30
content.text:
social networks and mental health of the students under lockdown.
Another limitation concerns the application of the backwards selection proce-
dure for regression models explaining changes in mental health. Selecting on statistical associations is a data-driven approach which may lead to non-replicable results (Thompson, 1995). The exploratory findings were not guided entirely by theoretical expectations and might be specific to the empirical context of the current study. However, we hope to encourage replications of the research design in different settings and further theoretical elaboration. At the time of writing, the COVID-19 crisis is still unfolding, which is further limiting the generalizability of our findings.

content.heading: Conclusion
content.text:
Students’ social networks and mental health trajectories cannot be understood
independently of each other (Elmer, 2020). It is therefore important to study how the COVID-19 crisis and related measures affect the social networks and mental health of students. It appears that the university lockdown and social distancing measures negatively affect the social integration of some individuals, partly leaving them isolated, while in fact more social support might be needed to cope with the additional stress factors.
Some students might be at higher risk of social isolation and the development
of mental health problems during the COVID-19 crisis. In particular, when they live by themselves, have less direct contact to close family members and friends, receive less social support, and have a weaker integration in the social networks of students. These observations as well as those of similar studies are crucial to develop targeted interventions to support students who are potentially at risk. These could include digital forms of study groups, peer group sessions, mentoring, and psychological counseling (Duan & Zhu, 2020).
The flattening of the infection curve during the COVID-19 pandemic requires
strict public health measures, such as social distancing, closure of public institutions,

content.heading: STUDENTS UNDER LOCKDOWN 31
content.text:
and a reduction of social life. But when implementing such measures, it is important to consider and counteract potential negative effects on individuals’ social networks and mental health.
